THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT TO BE ADDRESSED IS EDUCATION. 
THE MISSION OF THE SOUTHWEST HUMAN RESOURCE AGENCY IS TO MEET THE NEEDS OF FAMILIES AND INDIVIDUALS IN OUR SERVICE AREA BY DELIVERING SOCIAL SERVICES AND RESOURCES. SOUTHWEST HUMAN RESOURCE AGENCY FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM HAS ALWAYS ACHIEVED MORE VSYS THAN THE MINIMUM REQUIRED BY THE GRANT.  IT HAS ALWAYS BEEN OUR GOAL TO SERVE ALL ELIGIBLE CHILDREN. 
AN ESTIMATED 35 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS WITH THE PRIMARY FOCUS BEING EDUCATION.  THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ONE-ON-ONE TUTORING & MENTORING; ASSISTING IN CLASSROOMS TO HELP IMPROVE ACADEMICS, LITERACY SKILLS, PROVIDING COMFORT, AND IMPROVING SCHOOL READINESS SKILLS TO SPECIAL NEEDS CHILDREN. THE VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE APPROXIMATELY 17 STATIONS THROUGHOUT CHESTER, DECATUR, HARDEMAN, HARDIN, HAYWOOD, HENDERSON, MADISON, AND MCNAIRY COUNTIES.
THE VOLUNTEERS WILL HAVE SERVED AT LEAST 70 CHILDREN THROUGH ONE-ON-ONE MENTORING AND TUTORING AT THE END OF THE ONE YEAR PROGRAM PERIOD.  THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES WILL BE THE STUDENTS IN K-12 ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS WILL HAVE IMPROVED ACADEMICS SKILLS, AND THE HEAD START CHILDREN WILL HAVE IMPROVED SCHOOL READINESS SKILLS.  
THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES AT THE END OF THE THREE YEAR GRANT WILL BE THAT 201 CHILDREN WILL BE SERVED.
THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $217,178 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $21, 717 IN NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES.

FIRST TENNESSEE HUMAN RESOURCE AGENCY (FTHRA) IS A PUBLIC NON-PROFIT AGENCY CHARTERED BY THE STATE IN 1974 WITH THE MISSION TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR PEOPLE OF NORTHEAST TENNESSEE THROUGH EFFECTIVE DELIVERY OF SOCIAL SERVICES. FTHRA SERVES THE MOSTLY RURAL APPALACHIAN COUNTIES OF CARTER, GREENE, JOHNSON, HAWKINS, HANCOCK, SULLIVAN, UNICOI AND WASHINGTON PROVIDING A VARIETY OF NEEDS-BASED SERVICES TO LOW INCOME AND AT-RISK PEOPLE LIVING IN OUR SERVICE AREA. FTHRA HAS SUCCESSFULLY ADMINISTERED FGP IN GREENE COUNTY FOR OVER 15 YEARS AND GREENE COUNTY HAS MAINTAINED AN ACTIVE FGP FOR OVER 50 YEARS THROUGH VARIOUS SPONSORING AGENCIES.  FTHRA'S BOARD OF DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, AND FGP STAFF HAVE DETERMINED THAT THE BEST WAY TO UTILIZE FGP RESOURCES IS TO CONTINUE TO CONCENTRATE OUR EFFORTS IN GREENE COUNTY.THE MISSION OF THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS TO ADVANCE VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES FOR SENIOR CITIZENS SO THAT THEY MAY SERVE SPECIAL-NEEDS YOUTH THROUGH COLLABORATIONS WITH WORK SITES IN OUR SERVICE AREA.  AN ESTIMATED 60-65 UNDUPLICATED FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE GREENE COUNTY; ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ASSISTING IN CLASSROOMS, ASSISTING IN HEAD START PROGRAMS, CARING FOR INFANTS, TUTORING IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS.  THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION.  WE ANTICIPATE 350 CHILDREN/YOUTH WILL SHOW IMPROVED LITERACY AND MATH SKILLS. WE ALSO ANTICIPATE IMPROVED CLASSROOM ENGAGEMENT AND ATTENDANCE.  VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE AS POSITIVE ROLE MODELS, PROVIDING UNCONDITIONAL ACCEPTANCE, LOVE AND ATTENTION.  IN PRE-K CLASSES, VOLUNTEERS WILL FOCUS ON EARLY LITERACY, SOCIAL/EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT, SCHOOL READINESS; ENCOURAGING POSITIVE SOCIAL INTERACTION AND COMMUNICATION THROUGH READING, GAMES, AND TEACHING SELF-HELP SKILLS.  VOLUNTEERS IN K-8 GRADES WILL FOCUS ON LITERACY SKILLS; HELPING STUDENTS WITH READING, WORD RECOGNITION, AND PHONICS, AS WELL AS IMPROVEMENT IN ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT AND PERFORMANCE IN LITERACY.  THE 18 + VOLUNTEER WORK SITES BENEFIT CONSIDERABLY FROM HAVING A FGP VOLUNTEER; IT IS COST-EFFECTIVE FOR THE WORK SITES TO UTILIZE VOLUNTEERS THROUGH FGP SINCE WE PROVIDE CRIMINAL BACKGROUND CHECKS (INCLUDING FINGER PRINTING CHECKS), ANNUAL PHYSICAL EXAMS, ORIENTATION/MONTHLY TRAINING, ETC..  THE 2011 STATE OF THE CHILD IN TENNESSEE REPORT IDENTIFIES THE NEED FOR ONE-ON-ONE INTERACTION AS THE FOUNDATION FOR BRAIN STIMULATION.  GREENE COUNTY AND GREENEVILLE CITY SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENTS, SUPERVISORS AND DAY CARE CENTER DIRECTORS HAVE ECHOED THOSE FINDINGS; A VOLUNTEER PROVIDING ONE-ON-ONE ATTENTION IN EDUCATIONAL SETTINGS IS A MUCH NEEDED COMPONENT OF THE INDIVIDUALIZED INSTRUCTIONAL PLANS OF THE YOUNG CHILDREN. FOR THE CHILDREN WHO ARE FORTUNATE TO HAVE A FOSTER GRANDPARENT, THE NURTURING, SPECIAL TUTORING, GUIDANCE AND INDIVIDUAL ATTENTION CAN MAKE ALL THE DIFFERENCE IN POSITIVE GROWTH AND SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT.  THIS, IN TURN, IMPACTS THE CHILD'S FAMILY IN A BENEFICIAL WAY.  FOSTER GRANDPARENTS GIVE CHILDREN THAT MUCH-NEEDED ATTENTION THAT CAN CHANGE LIVES.  
BY USING TEACHER OBSERVATION FORMS AND LOGS, ASSIGNMENT PLANS AND ASSIGNMENT PLAN EVALUATIONS, SURVEYS, STAFF OBSERVATIONS, AS WELL AS REPORT CARDS, PRE-SCHOOL TESTING, MID-TERM TESTING, AND END-OF-YEAR EVALUATIONS, OUR PROGRAM WILL DETERMINE WHETHER YOUTH HAVE SHOWN INCREASED RESPONSIVENESS, IMPROVED DEVELOPMENT OF SKILLS AS DETERMINED BY THE TEACHERS SUCH AS LANGUAGE, LETTER, COLOR, NUMBER, AND NAME RECOGNITION, ETC.

IN THIS APPLICATION, OUR PROJECT FOCUS WILL PRIMARILY BE ON THE AREA OF EDUCATION-SCHOOL READINESS. IN ORDER TO FULLY BENEFIT FROM THE INSTRUCTION PROVIDED, OUR 72 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE IN AREAS NOT ONLY PREPARING CHILDREN FOR KINDERGARTEN, BUT IN AREAS WHERE CHILDREN ARE ALREADY RECEIVING SCHOOL INSTRUCTION. THESE AREAS INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO ASSISTING IN BOTH THE CLARKSVILLE-MONTGOMERY COUNTY COMMUNITY ACTION AGENCY - HEAD START PROGRAM (CMCCAA-HSP) WHICH SERVES 267 PRE-KINDERGARTEN STUDENTS AND CLARKSVILLE-MONTGOMERY COUNTY SCHOOL SYSTEM (CMCSS) WHICH SERVE 33,528 STUDENTS COUNTY WIDE. HEAD START EARLY CHILDHOOD LEARNING AND KNOWLEDGE CENTER DEFINES SCHOOL READINESS AS -- "IS FOUNDATIONAL ACROSS EARLY CHILDHOOD SYSTEMS AND PROGRAMS. IT MEANS CHILDREN ARE READY FOR SCHOOL, FAMILIES ARE READY TO SUPPORT THEIR CHILDREN'S LEARNING, AND SCHOOLS ARE READY FOR CHILDREN. HEAD START VIEWS SCHOOL READINESS AS CHILDREN POSSESSING THE SKILLS, KNOWLEDGE, AND ATTITUDES NECESSARY FOR SUCCESS IN SCHOOL AND FOR LATER LEARNING AND LIFE. PHYSICAL, COGNITIVE, SOCIAL, AND EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT ARE ALL ESSENTIAL INGREDIENTS OF SCHOOL READINESS. MANAGERS, TEACHING STAFF, CAREGIVERS, FAMILY ADVOCATES, AND FAMILIES CAN LEARN MORE ABOUT CREATING ENRICHING AND SUPPORTIVE LEARNING ENVIRONMENTS FOR YOUNG CHILDREN AGES BIRTH TO 5." IN ORDER TO FULLY BENEFIT FROM THE INSTRUCTION PROVIDED IN KINDERGARTEN AND BEYOND, CHILDREN MUST COME TO SCHOOL WITH MANY FUNDAMENTAL SKILLS ALREADY ESTABLISHED. YEARS OF RESEARCH ON CHILD DEVELOPMENT AND EARLY LEARNING SHOW THAT SEVERAL INTERRELATED AREAS OF DEVELOPMENT INCLUDE: APPROACHES TO LEARNING; HEALTH AND PHYSICAL WELL-BEING; LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION DEVELOPMENT, AND COGNITIVE AND GENERAL KNOWLEDGE. THESE AREAS OF DEVELOPMENT ARE IMPORTANT BECAUSE THEY BUILD ON ONE ANOTHER AND FORM THE FOUNDATION FOR LEARNING AND SOCIAL INTERACTION. WHILE NO UNIFORM SINGLE "READINESS" ASSESSMENT IS WIDELY USED FOR ALL ASPECTS OF DEVELOPMENT, OUR FGP PROGRAM WILL USE THE SCREENING TOOLS IDENTIFIED WITH BOTH THE CMCCAA-HS AND CMCSS. THESE TOOLS INCLUDE THE HEAD START EARLY LEARNING OUTCOMES FRAMEWORK THAT SUPPORT CHILDREN'S OUTCOMES AND CMCSS ASSESSMENTS SUCH AS UNIVERSAL SCREENER, COMMON ASSESSMENTS, AND BRIGANCE ASSESSMENT. THESE ASSESSMENTS ALLOW BOTH CMCCAA-HSP AND CMCSS TO PROVIDE INSTRUCTION TAILORED TO THE NEEDS OF THE INDIVIDUAL STUDENT WHILE MEETING THE STANDARDS SET BY THE OFFICE OF HEAD START AND THE TENNESSEE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION. OUR GOAL AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT IS THAT WE ANTICIPATE THAT 181 HEAD START AND EARLY ELEMENTARY CHILDREN WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS IN TERMS OF SOCIAL AND/OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
AN ESTIMATED 51 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE. SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE: SUPPORTING CHILDREN IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF SOCIALIZATION SKILLS, PROBLEM SOLVING SKILLS AND BUILDING SELF-ESTEEM. THROUGH ONE ON ONE MENTORING THE FGP WILL ENHANCE THE EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE AND ENCOURAGE PROGRESS IN SCHOOL READINESS  IN LITERACY SKILLS AND IMPROVE ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE IN READING AND MATH.
THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS SCHOOL READINESS FOR THE ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED YOUNG CHILDREN AND THE EDUCATIONAL AND BEHAVIORAL OUTCOMES OF ELEMENTARY, MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS WITH SPECIAL OR EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS.
AT THE END OF THE THREE YEAR GRANT, STUDENTS IN GRADES K-12 THAT PARTICIPATE IN THE MENTORING OR TUTORING OF THE CNCS SUPPORTED SERVICE LEARNING PROGRAM WILL DEMONSTRATE IMPROVED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT.
THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $313,550. WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $34,839.  IN KIND FUNDS. THE $$34,839. IN-KIND MATCH IS THE SAME MATCH AS THE LAST GRANT CYCLE DUE TO MATCH BEING WAIVED FOR THE INCREASE IN STIPEND AND THE $4000 ADDITIONAL PERMANENT MONEY THIS MATCH WILL COME IN THE FORM OF VOLUNTEER MEALS, RECOGNITION PROGRAM, WELLNESS EXAMS, AND DONATIONS FROM THE COMMUNITY AT LARGE.

AN ESTIMATED 70 UNDUPLICATED FOSTER GRANDPARENT (FGP) VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE. OF THIS NUMBER, ALL FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ASSISTING IN CLASSROOMS AND TUTORING AT-RISK CHILDREN ONE-ON-ONE OR IN SMALL GROUPS, PRIMARILY IN RICHLAND COUNTY. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION, WITH OBJECTIVES OF SCHOOL READINESS FOR HEAD START PROGRAMS, AND KINDERGARTEN- GRADE 12 SUCCESS FOR ELEMENTARY AFTERSCHOOL AND SUMMER SCHOOL PROGRAMS.  AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, AROUND 700 CHILDREN WILL COMPLETE A CNCS-SUPPORTED EDUCATION PROGRAM AND WILL REPORT ON GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS OR IMPROVED ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE. THE CNCS INVESTMENT OF $350,937.00 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $61,518.
SENIOR RESOURCES, INCORPORATED (SRI), THE LEGAL APPLICANT,  HAS BEEN ESTABLISHED AS A NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION IN THE SC MIDLANDS COMMUNITY SINCE 1967.   FGP BEGAN IN COLUMBIA IN 1967 AND SINCE HAS BEEN SPONSORED BY SENIOR RESOURCES SINCE 1984; THUS IT IS WELL-ESTABLISHED IN THE COMMUNITY. THE MISSION OF SENIOR RESOURCES IS TO PROVIDE COORDINATED SERVICES, RESOURCES AND PERSONAL CHOICES TO PROMOTE HEALTHY, INDEPENDENT LIVING THROUGH THE SUPPORT OF STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS.  RESEARCH SHOWS THAT VOLUNTEERING PROMOTES A PERSONAL SENSE OF PURPOSE AND ACCOMPLISHMENT, WITH HIGHER LEVELS OF HAPPINESS, SELF-ESTEEM AND LIFE SATISFACTION. THE LONGITUDINAL STUDY PUBLISHED BY CNCS IN 2018 INDICATED THAT SENIOR CORPS VOLUNTEERS WERE HEALTHIER, LESS DEPRESSED, AND LESS SOCIALLY ISOLATED THAN THOSE WHO DID NOT SERVE. FGP OF THE MIDLANDS IS ALSO UNIQUELY POSITIONED AND QUALIFIED DUE TO BEING HOUSED IN AN ORGANIZATION THAT OFFERS COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAMS AND SERVICES IN ESTABLISHED RELATIONSHIPS WITH EXISTING AGING SERVICE PROVIDERS, STATE AND LOCAL OFFICES ON AGING, AND CURRENT VOLUNTEER STATIONS.

THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS SAVE THE CHILDREN PROJECT IS K-12 SUCCESS AND SCHOOL READINESS. OUR LITERACY INITIATIVE IS THE HALLMARK OF OUR LITERACY BLOCK, WHICH CONSISTS OF GUIDED INDEPENDENT READING PRACTICE (GIRP) AND EMERGENT READER LITERACY PROGRAMS CONSISTING FOR 30 MINUTES OF UNINTERRUPTED TIME, FOUR DAYS A WEEK. THE SHORTFALL IN READING PROFICIENCY IS ESPECIALLY PRONOUNCED AMONG CHILDREN LIVING IN POVERTY IN LOW-INCOME COUNTIES, AND POOR COMMUNITIES, MAKING A QUALITY EDUCATION BEYOND REACH. OUR GOAL IS TO IMPROVE CHILDREN'S ABILITY TO READ FOR ACADEMIC, PERSONAL AND EVENTUALLY, CAREER PURPOSES. SAVE THE CHILDREN'S LITERACY PROGRAM PROVIDES CHILDREN IN KINDERGARTEN THROUGH SIXTH GRADE WITH AN OPPORTUNITY TO INCREASE THEIR READING ACHIEVEMENT BY SUPPLYING THE TOOLS NEEDED TO DEVELOP ESSENTIAL READING SKILLS.  
SAVE THE CHILDREN SEEKS TO ENGAGE 27 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS IN THE GIRP AND EMERGENT READER LITERACY PROGRAM TO SERVE 234 CHILDREN IN 11 PARTNER SCHOOLS IN KINDERGARTEN THROUGH SIXTH GRADE. VOLUNTEERS WILL EACH WORK WITH SIX CHILDREN DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR ON READING READINESS SKILLS FOR APPROXIMATELY 30 MINUTES OF UNINTERRUPTED TIME, FOUR DAYS A WEEK DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR. THE STUDENTS TARGETED FOR INTERVENTION STRUGGLE IN SCHOOL LARGELY BECAUSE THEY DON'T HAVE THE FAMILIARITY WITH BOOKS AND LANGUAGE THAT ARE THE BUILDING BLOCKS FOR LITERACY. 
TWENTY (65%) FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL ASSIST INDIVIDUAL CHILDREN IN GIRP BY HELPING THEM CHOOSE BOOKS ACROSS THEIR READING RANGE AND EXPLORE EACH CHILD'S INDIVIDUAL INTERESTS. VOLUNTEERS WILL LISTEN TO THE CHILD READ, PROVIDE OCCASIONAL SUPPORT WITH WORDS OR VOCABULARY AND ASK HIGHER-LEVEL THINKING QUESTIONS. THE QUESTIONS QUICKLY DETERMINE IF THE STUDENT UNDERSTANDS AND PROVIDE SUPPORT TO ENSURE THAT CHILDREN MAINTAIN A MONTHLY AVERAGE OF 90% ON ACCELERATED READER QUIZZES. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL HELP PARTICIPATING STUDENTS TO DEVELOP READING STRATEGIES BY PREVIEWING READING MATERIAL, HELP EMERGING CHILDREN IN K-1ST GRADE FOCUS ATTENTION ON PICTURES IN STORIES, AND ASSIST GRADES 2ND-4TH IN THE PREDICTION AND SUMMARIZING OF BOOKS. BUILDING STRONG INDEPENDENT READING SKILLS IN CHILDREN WILL LEAD TO INCREASED VOCABULARY DEVELOPMENT CRITICAL FOR SUCCESSFUL READERS.
SEVEN (35%) FOSTER GRANDPARENTS PLACED IN THE EMERGENT READER MODULE (GRADES KINDERGARTEN AND 1ST) WILL ASSIST WITH SIGHT WORDS, LETTER RECOGNITION, AND SHARED GUIDED READING ACTIVITIES. VOLUNTEERS TUTORING CHILDREN IN SIGHT WORDS WILL USE FLASH CARDS, SIGHT WORD BINGO, PHRASE CARDS, AND WORD BASEBALL TO HELP BEGINNING READERS READ AT LEAST 100 SIGHT WORDS CONSISTENTLY. VOLUNTEERS WORKING WITH CHILDREN USING LETTER RECOGNITION MODULES WILL ENGAGE IN THE ALPHABET SONG IDENTIFYING LETTERS UTILIZING CHARTS, AND OTHER RECOGNITION ACTIVITIES REQUIRING IDENTIFICATION OF UPPER/LOWER CASE LETTERS. 
AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, SAVE THE CHILDREN WILL HAVE 27 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERING IN 11 PARTNER SCHOOLS IN BARNWELL COUNTY DISTRICT 19, BARNWELL COUNTY DISTRICT 29, BARNWELL COUNTY DISTRICT 45, CLARENDON COUNTY DISTRICT 2, FLORENCE DISTRICT 7 AND ORANGEBURG COUNTY DISTRICT 3 AND ORANGEBURG COUNTY DISTRICT 5. AT THE END OF THE FISCAL YEAR, SAVE THE CHILDREN FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR REINFORCING EMERGENT LITERACY SKILLS AND IMPROVING READING SKILLS OF 234 (85%) CHILDREN. WITH THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL COMMUNITY SERVICE FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $173,936, SAVE THE CHILDREN WILL LEVERAGE AN ADDITIONAL $18,190 IN FUNDING TO SUPPORT THE LITERACY PROGRAM. WORKING CLOSELY WITH THE SAVE THE CHILDREN'S USP COMPTROLLER GROUP'S FINANCE OFFICE IN LEXINGTON, KENTUCKY, FINANCIAL OVERSIGHT IS EXERCISED AT ALL TIMES TO ENSURE EFFECTIVE USE OF RESOURCES. THE AGENCY ADHERES TO STRICT PERSONNEL POLICIES AND FINANCIAL PROCEDURES TO GUIDE OUR OPERATIONS. WE HAVE A PROVEN TRACK RECORD OF USING RESOURCES EFFICIENTLY AND EFFECTIVELY IN THE MOST COST EFFECTIVE WAYS POSSIBLE TO MANAGE THE PROGRAM.

THE APPALACHIAN FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS REQUESTING $427,033 FROM THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE FOR THE GRANT CYCLE 2020-2021 AND WILL MAINTAIN 79 VSY'S, WHILE CONTRIBUTING $55,329 FROM IN-KIND AND OTHER NON-FEDERAL SOURCES. OUR MISSION IS TO PROVIDE MEANINGFUL VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES FOR LOW-INCOME SENIOR CITIZENS THAT WILL ENHANCE THEIR LIVES AND, AT THE SAME TIME, ENHANCE AND IMPROVE THE LIVES OF THE SPECIAL NEEDS CHILDREN THEY SERVE. OUR PRIMARY GOAL IS IMPROVED CHILD LITERACY. THERE IS A CONTINUING NEED FOR FOSTER GRANDPARENTS TO SERVE CHILDREN IN KINDERGARTEN THROUGH SEVENTH GRADE IN THE PUBLIC SCHOOLS IN ALLEGHANY, ASHE, AVERY, WATAUGA, AND WILKES COUNTIES. LOCAL SCHOOL OFFICIALS HAVE IDENTIFIED THEIR CONTINUED NEED FOR ONE-ON-ONE ASSISTANCE WITH CHILDREN WHO ARE STRUGGLING TO REACH THE REQUIRED READING LEVEL. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS HAVE BEEN REQUESTED BY PRINCIPALS IN ALLEGHANY, ASHE, AVERY, WATAUGA, AND WILKES COUNTIES. WE ANTICIPATE THAT OF THE 200 CHILDREN TUTORED BY A FOSTER GRANDPARENT IN OUR PROGRAM, AT LEAST 150 WILL IMPROVE THEIR READING AND LITERACY SKILLS BY THE END OF THE SCHOOL YEAR. THIS OUTCOME WILL BE MEASURED USING BEGINNING-OF-THE-YEAR, MID-YEAR, AND END-OF-THE-YEAR ASSESSMENT FORMS COMPLETED BY CLASSROOM TEACHERS.
HEAD START OF THE BLUE RIDGE OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION SERVES APPROXIMATELY 164 LOW-INCOME AND AT-RISK, PRESCHOOL CHILDREN AND THEIR FAMILIES ANNUALLY. FEDERAL HEAD START PERFORMANCE STANDARDS REQUIRE ALL HEAD START PROGRAMS TO COMPLETE DEVELOPMENTAL SCREENINGS IN ORDER TO IDENTIFY CHILDREN WHO NEED DISABILITY SERVICES AND RESOURCES. APPROVED DEVELOPMENTAL SCREENING TOOLS INCLUDE: AGES AND STAGES, FIRST STEPS, BRIGANCE, AND LAP D. THESE TOOLS ADDRESS THE PRIMARY DOMAIN AREAS RELATED TO COGNITIVE ABILITIES, LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION SKILLS, SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT, AND FINE AND GROSS MOTOR SKILLS. BASED ON RESULTS FROM THESE ASSESSMENT TOOLS, BLUE RIDGE OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION HEAD START STAFF IDENTIFY CHILDREN WHO NEED EXTRA ASSISTANCE WITH SPECIFIC DELAYS AND/OR DISABILITIES.  MANY OF THE HEAD START CHILDREN SERVED BY FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS FACE ADDITIONAL CHALLENGES, SUCH AS LIVING IN HOUSEHOLDS WITH AN UNEMPLOYED PARENT, OR WITH NO PARENT PRESENT.  THEY ALSO TYPICALLY FACE NEGATIVE CIRCUMSTANCES LIKE SOCIOECONOMIC HARDSHIP, PARENTAL DIVORCE OR SEPARATION, PARENTAL DEATH, PARENTAL INCARCERATION, FAMILY VIOLENCE, NEIGHBORHOOD VIOLENCE, LIVING WITH SOMEONE WHO IS MENTALLY ILL OR SUICIDAL, OR LIVING WITH SOMEONE WHO HAS A SUBSTANCE ABUSE PROBLEM, ALL OF WHICH COMPOUND THE NEED FOR ONE-ON-ONE ASSISTANCE WITH LEARNING (KIDS COUNT DATA BOOK 2019).  
 IT IS LIKELY THAT WITHOUT INTERVENTION, THE IDENTIFIED CHILDREN WOULD NOT ACQUIRE THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO BE SUCCESSFUL IN SCHOOL.  THE RESOURCES AND FUNDING FOR EXTENSIVE ONE-ON-ONE INTERVENTION ARE NOT CURRENTLY AVAILABLE TO THE HEAD START PROGRAM. THE APPALACHIAN FOSTER GRANDPARENTS PROVIDE ASSISTANCE TO TEACHERS IN THE HEAD START CENTERS IN ASHE, AVERY, AND WATAUGA COUNTIES, AND SPECIFICALLY TO THE CHILDREN ENROLLED IN THESE PROGRAMS.  AN ASSIGNMENT PLAN INSTRUMENT WILL BE COMPLETED BY THE HEAD START STAFF AND RETURNED TO THE APPALACHIAN FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM OFFICE.
THERE ARE 20, 111 CHILDREN AGES 3 -- 5 IN NORTH CAROLINA AND 254 CHILDREN ARE IN DEVELOPMENTAL DAY CARE FACILITIES IN ASHE, ALLEGHANY, AVERY, WATAUGA, AND WILKES COUNTIES (NORTH CAROLINA PUBLIC SCHOOLS EXCEPTIONAL CHILDREN DIVISION CHILD COUNT REPORT, DECEMBER 2019). THESE CHILDREN ARE FUNCTIONING BELOW GRADE-LEVEL AND REQUIRE INDIVIDUALIZED AND SMALL-GROUP SUPPORT FROM FOSTER GRANDPARENTS TO HELP THEM MEET DEVELOPMENTAL GOALS. IN THE PAST, SCHOOL PERSONNEL HAVE REPORTED THAT THE ONE-ON-ONE ASSISTANCE OF FOSTER GRANDPARENTS HAS BEEN IMPORTANT TO CHILDREN WHO OTHERWISE WOULD NOT HAVE ANY DEDICATED SPECIAL ASSISTANCE. OUR GOALS INCLUDE HELPING THE CHILDREN IMPROVE THEIR ABILITY TO FOCUS ON LEARNING WHILE IN THE CLASSROOM AND HELPING THEM BEC

LAND OF SKY REGIONAL COUNCIL (LOSRC) IS A MULTI-COUNTY, LOCAL GOVERNMENT PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT ORGANIZATION IN NORTH CAROLINA. IT IS ONE OF 16 SUCH ORGANIZATIONS IN THE STATE AND SERVES REGION B, WHICH INCLUDES BUNCOMBE, HENDERSON, MADISON AND TRANSYLVANIA COUNTIES. THE PROFESSIONAL STAFF CARRIES OUT APPROVED PROGRAMS AND PROVIDES LOCAL GOVERNMENTS WITH GRANT AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE THROUGH THE DEPARTMENTS OF AREA AGENCY ON AGING, MOUNTAIN MOBILITY, ECONOMIC & COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT, AND MOUNTAIN WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT.

LOSRC'S MISSION IS TO PROVIDE CREATIVE REGIONAL SOLUTIONS TO RELEVANT AND EMERGING ISSUES IN BUNCOMBE, HENDERSON, MADISON AND TRANSYLVANIA COUNTIES WHILE PROVIDING A STANDARD OF EXCELLENCE IN THE DELIVERY OF FEDERAL, STATE, AND REGIONAL SERVICES FOR OUR MEMBER COMMUNITIES. 

EDUCATION CUTS, LARGER CLASSROOM SIZES, INCREASING DEMANDS AND EXPECTATIONS ON BOTH TEACHERS AND STUDENTS ARE JUST A FEW EXAMPLES OF CHALLENGES TEACHERS FACE DAILY.  AS PUBLIC SCHOOLS AND SMALL NON-PROFIT CHILDCARE CENTERS STRUGGLE TO MEET THESE CHALLENGES, THE NEED FOR VOLUNTEERS IS EVER INCREASING.  THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM CAN HELP MEET THIS NEED BY PROVIDING VOLUNTEERS TO SERVE ONE-ON-ONE WITH OVER 116 SPECIAL NEEDS AND AT-RISK CHILDREN IN OUR COMMUNITY.  

AN ESTIMATED 65 FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE.  OF THIS NUMBER, 56 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS.  TO MEET OBJECTIVES IN SCHOOL READINESS, 32 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL ASSIST IN CLASSROOMS OF EARLY EDUCATION PROGRAMS AND HEAD START CENTERS SPECIALIZING IN SPECIAL AND EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS.  TO MEET OBJECTIVES IN K-12 SUCCESS, 24 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL TUTOR IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS.  SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ASSISTING IN CLASSROOMS, ASSISTING IN CLASSROOM- HEAD START, AND TUTORING- PUBLIC SCHOOLS.  AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, 92 CHILDREN IN SCHOOL READINESS AND K-12 SUCCESS PROGRAMS, 56 AND 36 CHILDREN RESPECTIVELY, WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SOCIAL AND/OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND IMPROVED ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE, AS A RESULT OF THEIR RELATIONSHIP WITH A FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEER.  NINE FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL ASSIST IN CLASSROOMS CARING FOR INFANTS.  THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $336,405 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $40,775 OF NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES.

BLUE RIDGE COMMUNITY ACTION, INC (BRCA) IS A PRIVATE, NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION ESTABLISHED IN 1965 TO ADDRESS AND RESPOND TO THE CONCERNS AND NEEDS OF LOW -INCOME FAMILIES AND INDIVIDUALS WITHIN THE COMMUNITIES THEY SERVE. COMMUNITY ACTION AGENCIES (CAAS) ARE NON-PROFIT PRIVATE AND PUBLIC ORGANIZATIONS ORIGINALLY ESTABLISHED UNDER THE ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY ACT OF 1964 TO FIGHT AMERICA?S WAR ON POVERTY.  TODAY THERE ARE NEARLY 1,000 CAA?S ACROSS THE UNITED STATES.  WITH THE UNDERSTANDING THAT PROBLEMS OFTEN DON'T COME ALONE AND THEREFORE AREN?T SOLVED ALONE, BRCA WORKS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE COMMUNITY TO IDENTIFY CONCERNS AND SOLVE PROBLEMS.  THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT (FG) GRANT APPLICATION REQUESTS 42 VOLUNTEERS TO SERVE 5 COUNTIES IN WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA: ALEXANDER, BURKE, CALDWELL, CATAWBA AND MCDOWELL COUNTIES.  TOTAL ANNUAL FUNDING ANTICIPATED IS $302,198  THAT INCLUDES $271,983 FEDERAL AND $30,215 GRANTEE AND COMMUNITY DONATIONS.  SERVICE CATEGORIES  ADDRESSED ARE :   PRE-ELEMENTARY  (AGES 0-5), ELEMENTARY EDUCATION AND INTELLECTUAL DISABILITIES.  COMMUNITY NEEDS INCLUDE SUPPORTING EARLY INTERVENTION IN LOCAL HEAD START AND DAY CARE PROGRAMS TO INCREASE CHILDREN'S SUCCESS IN KINDERGARTEN. HEAD START AND PRE-SCHOOL CHILDREN IDENTIFIED THROUGH DEVELOPMENTAL ASSESSMENT PLANS, RECEIVE GREATER KINDERGARTEN SUCCESS.  IN SCHOOL, FG VOLUNTEERS WILL MENTOR SPECIAL NEEDS CHILDREN, IDENTIFIED BY THEIR TEACHERS, IN ACTIVITIES TO STRENGTHEN LITERACY, ACADEMIC CONFIDENCE AND INCREASE EOG READING SCORES WITH THE FINAL OUTCOME OF PASSING TO THE NEXT GRADE LEVEL OR ACHIEVING IEP GOALS.  THE INTELLECTUALLY DISABLED SERVICE AREA WILL ASSIST RIDDLE CENTER RESIDENTS THROUGH INCREASING SOCIAL ACTIVITIES, CLASS SITE ACHIEVEMENTS AND CONFIDENCE AND SAFETY FOR RIDDLE CENTER RESIDENTS WITH OUTCOMES TO ENRICH THEIR QUALITY OF LIFE AND REFLECT PROGRESS IN THEIR PERSONAL CARE PLAN GOALS.

WAYNE ACTION GROUP FOR ECONOMIC SOLVENCY (WAGES) IS THE SPONSOR ORGANIZATION FOR THE WAGES FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM. IT IS A PRIVATE NON-PROFIT AGENCY THAT SERVES THE COMMUNITIES OF WAYNE COUNTY, NORTH CAROLINA. IT IS A COMMUNITY ACTION AGENCY DEDICATED TO HELPING WAYNE COUNTY MOBILIZE RESOURCES TO COMBAT POVERTY. WAGES WAS CHARTERED BY A RESOLUTION OF THE WAYNE COUNTY COMMISSIONERS ON NOVEMBER 15, 1965.

THE AGENCY HELD ITS FIRST BOARD OF DIRECTORS MEETING ON NOVEMBER 19, 1965; OFFICERS WERE ELECTED AND A CONSTITUTION AND BY-LAWS WERE ADOPTED.  THE FIRST OFFICE WAS OPENED ON MAY 1, 1966 IN GOLDSBORO, THE COUNTY SEAT OF WAYNE COUNTY, NC. THE AGENCY CONTINUES TO BE GOVERNED BY A BOARD OF DIRECTORS WHICH IS COMPOSED OF ONE-THIRD PUBLIC OFFICIALS, ONE-THIRD REPRESENTATIVES OF LOW-INCOME INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES, AND ONE-THIRD PRIVATE COMMUNITY GROUPS AND ORGANIZATIONS.
 
WAGES IS DEDICATED TO HELPING PEOPLE IMPROVE THEIR QUALITY OF LIFE AND HEALTH AND GAIN INDEPENDENCE. WAGES ADVOCATES FOR THE DISADVANTAGED, ENCOURAGES PEOPLE TO RAISE THEIR SELF-ESTEEM THROUGH EDUCATION; PROVIDES SERVICES AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR VOLUNTEERISM; AND MOBILIZES COMMUNITY, PUBLIC AND PRIVATE RESOURCES.

AN ESTIMATED 100 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE. OF THIS NUMBER 95 VOLUNTEERS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME BASED ASSIGNMENTS. SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE PROVIDING SERVICES WHICH IMPROVE SCHOOL READINESS FOR ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED PRE-K STUDENTS IN HEAD START CLASSROOMS AND CHILDCARE CENTERS AS WELL AS ENHANCE THE EDUCATIONAL SUCCESS OF CHILDREN IN GRADES K-3.

THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT AT LEAST 135 STUDENTS WILL SHOW IMPROVED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT, INCREASED SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL SKILLS AND SCHOOL READINESS. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $503,062 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $50,338.00.

THE GOAL OF THE STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA, ACCORDING TO GS115C-83, IS TO ENSURE THAT EVERY STUDENT READ AT OR ABOVE GRADE LEVEL BY THE END OF THIRD GRADE AND CONTINUE TO PROGRESS IN READING PROFICIENCY SO THAT HE OR SHE CAN READ, COMPREHEND, INTEGRATE, AND APPLY COMPLEX TEXTS NEEDED FOR SECONDARY EDUCATION AND CAREER SUCCESS.

IN WAYNE COUNTY ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS DURING THE 2018-2019 SCHOOL YEAR, EIGHT SCHOOLS WERE DETERMINED TO BE LOW PERFORMING SCHOOLS, ACCORDING TO THE NC SCHOOL REPORT CARDS. SIX OF THE EIGHT SCHOOLS RECEIVED A GRADE D WHICH SHOWS THE OVERALL SCORE OF THE SCHOOL'S ACHIEVEMENT ON STATE TESTS AND STUDENT'S ACADEMIC GROWTH. PRINCIPALS FROM FIVE ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS AND ONE CHARTER SCHOOL, ALL WITH GRADE D, HAVE ACCEPTED FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS TO WORK ONE-ON-ONE WITH IDENTIFIED SPECIAL NEEDS STUDENTS. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL FOCUS ON IMPROVING STUDENTS READING SKILLS THROUGH ONE-ON-ONE ASSISTANCE. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS PLACED AT THOSE ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS WILL ASSIST IN INCREASING READING PROFICIENCY WHILE FOSTERING A POSITIVE ATTITUDE OF THE COUNTY'S LOW-INCOME OR ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED ELEMENTARY STUDENTS.
 
WAGES HEAD START AND EARLY HEAD START PROGRAM SERVES 618 ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED AND AT-RISK CHILDREN TO PREPARE THEM FOR SUCCESS IN KINDERGARTEN AND IN LIFE (WAGES 2018 COMMUNITY ASSESSMENT). FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL PROVIDE ASSISTANCE BY ENGAGING THEM ONE-ON-ONE, MODELING AND REINFORCING APPROPRIATE BEHAVIOR AND ENCOURAGING SELF-HELP SKILLS. FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS SERVING AT SEVEN HEAD START CENTERS WILL MENTOR AND PROVIDE SUPPORT TO PREPARE IDENTIFIED SPECIAL NEEDS CHILDREN FOR SUCCESS IN KINDERGARTEN.

FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE AS POSITIVE ROLE MODELS AND WILL FACILITATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL AND/OR EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL ENGAGE IN ACTIVITIES WHICH ENCOURAGE SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL EMBRACE PRE-SCHOOL CHILDREN WHO HAVE BEGUN TO GAIN A SENSE OF SELF, AND WHO HAVE STRONG EMOTIONS DURING THESE DEVELOPMENTAL YEARS. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL PRO

A TOTAL OF 55 FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM VOLUNTEERS WILL ASSIST APPROXIMATELY 60 CHILDREN ONE-ON-ONE. SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL CONTINUE TO INCLUDE:  1) SUPPORTING LITERACY AND MATHEMATICAL DEVELOPMENT; 2) HELPING WITH CLASS ASSIGNMENTS AND HOMEWORK; 3) PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL ASSISTANCE TO CHILDREN IN SUMMER PROGRAMS; 4) WORKING WITH DEVELOPMENTALLY DISABLED CHILDREN ON MANIPULATIVES, SPEECH, AND MOTOR SKILLS; AND 5) HELPING PRE-ELEMENTARY CHILDREN IN AREAS OF PHONOLOGICAL & PRINT AWARENESS, ALPHABET KNOWLEDGE, AND SOCIAL RELATIONSHIPS. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES EDUCATIONAL NEEDS WITHIN THE COMMUNITY, FOCUSING PRIMARILY ON ACADEMIC AND BEHAVIORAL GROWTH FOR CHILDREN WHO ARE AT RISK.  THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES FOR CHILDREN IN EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION CENTERS AND CHILDREN WITH DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES OR DELAYS [THOSE WITH OTHER HUMAN NEEDS] WHO ENROLLED IN THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS BASED ON THEIR SOCIAL AND/OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT.  AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES FOR YOUTH IN ELEMENTARY EDUCATION AND THOSE IN SUMMER PROGRAMS WHO COMPLETE PARTICIPATION IN THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS PROGRAM WILL SHOW ACADEMIC SUCCESS DEMONSTRATED BY AN IMPROVED PERFORMANCE IN LITERACY AND/OR MATH. THIS PAST YEAR CNCS INVESTED  $263,065 SUPPLEMENTED BY $98,577 OF NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES. THE FY21  ESTIMATED OF  $287,162 FUNDING LEVEL SUPPLEMENTED BY AN ESTIMATED $94,377 OF NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES WILL ENSURE A CONTINUED SUCCESSFUL PROGRAM AND OUTCOMES.  ADDITIONALLY, OUR FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM VOLUNTEERS ARE CURRENTLY PLACED AT 21 STATIONS THROUGHOUT WAKE COUNTY AS FOLLOWS: 4 EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION CENTERS; AND 17 PUBLIC ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS. THE OUTCRY FOR ADDITIONAL GRANDPARENTS IN THE SCHOOLS HAS INCREASED EXPONENTIALLY.  FURTHERMORE, AT THE END OF FY 2019 PERFORMANCE PERIOD, 96% OF THE STUDENTS SERVED BY THE PROGRAM COMPLETED A CNCS SUPPORTED EDUCATION PROGRAM WITH 100% IMPROVED ACADEMICALLY IN LITERACY AND/OR MATH AS WELL AS THOSE ASSESSED IN THE EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION PROGRAMS.

GREENE LAMP COMMUNITY ACTION, A 501 (C)3 NONPROFIT, INCORPORATED IN 1965 IS RESPECTFULLY SUBMITTING AN APPLICATION FOR THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS PROGRAM TO SERVE GREENE AND LENOIR COUNTIES, RESPECTIVELY. THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM, WHICH BEGAN IN LENOIR AND GREENE COUNTIES IN 1972, PROVIDES MOTIVATED, LOVING AND EXPERIENCED TUTORS AND MENTORS TO CHILDREN AND YOUTH. OUR FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL PROVIDE ONE-ON-ONE INTERACTION AND SERVE BETWEEN 15-40 HOURS A WEEK TO OFFER EFFECTIVE SERVICES TO THE YOUTH AND CHILDREN BEING SERVED. FROM THE INITIAL DATE TO THE PRESENT TIME, APPROXIMATELY FIVE HUNDRED VOLUNTEERS HAVE SERVED IN GREENE AND LENOIR COUNTIES TOTALING OVER 3 MILLION HOURS. APPROXIMATELY FIFTY-SEVEN (57) FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS, HOWEVER, THIS NUMBER MAY INCREASE DUE TO COMMUNITY NEEDS. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION. SOME OF THEIR SERVICE ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL SUPPORT, SERVING PEOPLE WITH INTELLECTUAL DISABILITIES, JUVENILE JUSTICE, LITERACY AND MENTORING. AT THE COMPLETION OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, GREENE LAMP ANTICIPATES AN INCREASE IN CHILDREN DEMONSTRATING SCHOOL READINESS GAINS, IMPROVED ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE, IMPROVED SOCIAL/EMOTIONAL SKILLS AND IMPROVED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT.  THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $336,840.00 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $37,426.00 OF ANTICIPATED NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES. STUDIES SHOW THAT VOLUNTEERING HELPS SENIORS LIVE LONGER AND WILL PROMOTE A MORE POSITIVE OUTLOOK ON LIFE.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
THE SOUTHERN MISSISSIPPI PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT DISTRICT (SMPDD), ONE OF TEN PLANNING DISTRICTS IN THE STATE, HAS A BRANCH OFFICE LOCATED IN HATTIESBURG, MISSISSIPPI. THIS BRANCH OFFICE HOUSES THE WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT DEPARTMENT, A MEDICARE WAIVER PROGRAM, ADULT PROTECTION SERVICES, THE MISSISSIPPI ACCESS TO CARE (MAC) PROGRAM, AND A WORKFORCE INVESTMENT ACT YOUTH PROGRAM. THESE DEPARTMENTS ARE TIED DIRECTLY TO OUR EFFORTS TO IMPROVE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND THE LIVES OF OUR CITIZENS THROUGHOUT THE FIFTEEN COUNTY SERVICE AREA. THE MAIN OFFICE, LOCATED IN GULFPORT, MS, HOUSES ALL THE LISTED ABOVE AS WELL AS THE AREA AGENCY ON AGING, THE SENIOR COMMUNITY SERVICE EMPLOYMENT PROGRAM (SCSEP), AND VARIOUS OTHERS DEPARTMENTS NECESSARY TO ACHIEVE THE MISSION ENVISIONED BY OUR BOARDS AND EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR. IT IS THROUGH THE AREA AGENCY ON AGING THAT THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM OF SMPDD IS MOST SUCCESSFUL. 


MISSISSIPPI'S STATE PLAN FOR THE EVERY STUDENT SUCCEEDS ACT (ESSA) WILL REFLECT MANY OF THE STATE'S EDUCATIONAL PRIORITIES STATED IN THE MISSISSIPPI STATE BOARD OF EDUCATION'S 5-YEAR STRATEGIC PLAN BY: 
1.	INCREASING STUDENT GROWTH AND PROFICIENCY IN ALL TESTED AREAS THROUGH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND STATE SUPPORT 
2.	FOCUSING ON EDUCATIONAL EQUITY THROUGH INCREASED ACCESS AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR ALL STUDENTS TO CLOSE OPPORTUNITY AND ACHIEVEMENT GAPS 
3.	ENSURING HIGH-QUALITY CLASSROOM INSTRUCTION AND SCHOOL LEADERSHIP THROUGH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND MEANINGFUL FEEDBACK FROM EDUCATORS 
4.	SETTING THE EXPECTATION THAT EVERY STUDENT GRADUATES FROM HIGH SCHOOL AND IS READY FOR COLLEGE AND CAREER 
5.	EXPANDING ACCESS TO HIGH-QUALITY EARLY LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES FOR OUR 4-YEAR OLD STUDENTS 
6.	USING DATA EFFECTIVELY TO MAKE DECISIONS IN THE BEST INTERESTS OF STUDENTS 
7.	SUPPORTING AND IMPROVING UNDER-PERFORMING SCHOOLS THROUGH LOCAL AND STATE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND INTERVENTION

THE MISSISSIPPI STATEWIDE ACCOUNTABILITY SYSTEM IS A SINGLE "A" THROUGH "F" SCHOOL AND DISTRICT ACCOUNTABILITY SYSTEM BASED ON THE REQUIREMENTS OF MISSISSIPPI CODE 37-17-6 AND THE FEDERAL ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ACT OF 1965 (ESEA). THE ACCOUNTABILITY SYSTEM ASSIGNS PERFORMANCE CLASSIFICATIONS BASED ON: (A) STUDENT ACHIEVEMENT, (B) STUDENT GROWTH, (C) GRADUATION RATES, (D) PARTICIPATION RATE, AND (E) OTHER OUTCOME MEASURES.  HATTIESBURG PUBLIC SCHOOLS SCORED A "D" AND MARION COUNTY SCHOOLS SCORED A "C" IN THE 2018-2019 SCHOOL YEAR. 

IN ADDITION, MISSISSIPPI HAS ONE OF THE HIGHEST DROPOUT RATES IN THE NATION. MANY OF THESE YOUTH FIND THEIR WAY TO OUT-OF-SCHOOL PROGRAMS FOR OCCUPATIONAL TRAINING AND GEDS. EMPLOYMENT FOR THESE INDIVIDUALS IS ONLY A GLIMMER IN THE FUTURE, NOT A CERTAINTY IN LIGHT OF THE UNEMPLOYMENT RATE, THE LACK OF SUPPORT, SKILLS, AND TRAINING. THIS PROJECT CAN AIDE, IF ONLY BY EXAMPLE, THE CHARACTERISTICS NECESSARY TO ALLOW THESE CHILDREN THE PROMISE OF A SELF-SUFFICIENT TOMORROW. 

AN ESTIMATED 40 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE. ALL VOLUNTEERS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS.  THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM OF SMPDD WILL ADDRESS THE EDUCATION FOCUS AREA WITH SCHOOL READINESS AND K-12 SUCCESS OBJECTIVES.  AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, WE ANTICIPATE BETTER SCHOOL ATTENDANCE, MORE POSITIVE BEHAVIOR, BETTER GRADES AND PROMOTION TO NEXT GRADE LEVEL OR CLASSROOM.  THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $207,137 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $18,468 OF NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES.

THE YAZOO COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS VOWS ITSELF AND COUNTY GOVERNMENT AS BEING A SERVICE ORGANIZATION FULLY COMMITTED TO IMPROVING THE OVERALL QUALITY OF LIFE FOR ALL THE CITIZENS OF YAZOO COUNTY. ALL SERVICES, PROGRAMS AND FUNCTIONS OF OUR GOVERNMENT MUST SEEK TO EMPOWER THE CITIZENS OF YAZOO COUNTY TO LIVE INDEPENDENT, HEALTHY, PROSPEROUS AND ENJOYABLE LIVES. THE YAZOO COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS REALIZES THE GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT OF YAZOO COUNTY IS INTEGRAL AND A NECESSARY COMPONENT OF MISSISSIPPI'S OVERALL GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT. THE YAZOO COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS BECAME THE SPONSOR OF THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (YCFGP) IN 2005.  THERE ARE CURRENTLY 32 VOLUNTEERS IN THE PROGRAM SERVING A TOTAL OF 1044 HOURS ANNUALLY.  THE YAZOO COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISOR REQUEST THE AMOUNT OF $168,043 FROM CNCS TO CONTINUE THE DAY TO DAY OPERATION OF THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM. THE YAZOO COUNTY FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROJECT WILL ADDRESS PRIMARILY THREE SERVICE CATEGORIES: EDUCATION, MENTORING AND TUTORING. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA FOR THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION.  THE YCFGP WILL PLACE 32 VOLUNTEERS IN THE ELEMENTARY SCHOOL SYSTEM, HEAD STARTS, MENTAL HEALTH FACILITIES AND OUT OF SCHOOL LEARNING SITES. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO IMPROVE SCHOOL READINESS FOR ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED YOUNG CHILDREN; TO IMPROVE EDUCATIONAL AND BEHAVIORAL OUTCOMES OF STUDENTS AND LOW ACHIEVING ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS; TO HELP IMPROVE CHILDREN'S SAFETY AND WELFARE; AND TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR POSITIVE RELATIONSHIPS WITH ADULTS AND PEERS AND ENHANCE POSITIVE CHARACTER TRAITS.  DUE TO THE FGP VOLUNTEER SERVICE BENEFICIARIES WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS IN TERM OF SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT; IN TERMS OF LITERACY AND IMPROVEMENT OF CHILDREN'S SAFETY, WELFARE AND HEALTH AND ENHANCE POSITIVE CHARACTER TRAITS.

THE LAUDERDALE COUNTY FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM, SPONSOR IS MULTI COUNTY COMMUNITY SERVICE AGENCY, INC. (MCCSA), A 501?3 NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION. THE MISSION OF MCCSA IS TO BE A CATALYST FOR GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT FOR DISADVANTAGED INDIVIDUALS, AND AN INSTRUMENT FOR CHANGE IN THE COMMUNITY. THE LAUDERDALE COUNTY FGP OFFICE IS LOCATED AT 2906 ST. PAUL STREET IN MERIDIAN, MS. THE CONTACT PHONE NUMBER IS (601)483-4838 AND CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE SENIOR CORPS DIVISION IS ITS? FUNDING AGENT.
AN ESTIMATED 90 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL PARTICIPATE IN THE LCFGP, AND A MINIMUM OF 78 UNDUPLICATED FGPS IN NATIONAL PERFORMANCE BASED OUTCOME MEASURES IN THE EDUCATIONAL FOCUS AREA. THE FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL ENGAGE CHILDREN AND YOUTH WITH SPECIAL AND EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS, AND THOSE WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM THE ONE TO ONE ATTENTION GIVEN BY THE FGP VOLUNTEERS. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE TUTORING, MENTORING, ASSISTING IN THE CLASSROOM, OR ENGAGE IN PROVEN EDUCATIONAL-RELATED SUPPORTIVE SERVICES. EDUCATION IS THE FOCAL POINT OF THE PROGRAM, AND WILL OCCUR AT 28 DESIGNATED VOLUNTEER STATIONS IN LAUDERDALE, CLARKE, JASPER, AND KEMPER COUNTIES.
SCHOOL READINESS IS THE OBJECTIVE FOR PRE-SCHOOLS, HEAD START CENTERS AND A DOMESTIC VIOLENCE SHELTER. THE OBJECTIVE OF LCFGP IS SUCCESS FOR KINDERGARTEN THROUGH 12TH GRADE AT RISK CHILDREN AND YOUTH IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS, FAITH-BASED SCHOOLS, AND OTHER EDUCATIONAL FACILITIES WHICH INCLUDES AFTER SCHOOL PROGRAMS. FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL ASSIST THE ASSIGNED AT-RISK CHILDREN AND/OR YOUTH WITH COGNITIVE ACTIVITIES INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO PUZZLES, COLORING ACTIVITIES, READING COMPREHENSION, AND WRITING. THEY WILL ALSO ASSIST IN STORY-TELLING, TEACH AND RECOGNIZE ALPHABETS, NUMBERS, SHAPES, AND OTHER CLASS WORK ASSIGNED BY THE TEACHER. THE FGP WILL REINFORCE LEARNING THROUGH POSITIVE ENCOURAGEMENT, MODELING SOCIAL SKILLS AND GOOD BEHAVIOR.
THE EXPECTED OUTPUT IS TO ASSIST THE STUDENTS TO COMPLETE CNCS-SUPPORTED EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS, AND THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES SHOULD BE 200 AT RISK CHILDREN AND YOUTH WITH IMPROVED LITERACY SKILLS, ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE AND ENGAGEMENT, AS WELL AS, IMPROVED SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL SKILLS.

THE LAUREL-JONES COUNTY COUNCIL ON AGING, INC. HAS SERVED AS THE SPONSOR OF THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM SINCE 1972. THE MISSION OF THE LAUREL -- JONES COUNTY COUNCIL ON AGING IS TO PROMOTE VOLUNTEER SERVICES BY SENIOR CITIZENS IN THE PINE BELT AREA. THROUGH ITS SPONSORSHIP OF THE FGP OF THE PINE BELT THE LAUREL -- JONES COUNTY COUNCIL ON AGING, INC. ENCOURAGES CITIZEN INVOLVEMENT, CIVIC RESPONSIBILITY AND VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES FOR RESIDENTS AGE 55 AND OLDER. SERVICE AREAS AFFECTED BY THE FGP PROGRAM OF THE PINE BELT INCLUDE JONES AND WAYNE COUNTIES IN SOUTH MISSISSIPPI. VOLUNTEER ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ONE-ON-ONE TUTORING OF ELEMENTARY STUDENTS IN MATH AND READING IN THE JONES AND WAYNE COUNTY SCHOOL SYSTEMS, ENHANCING SOCIAL AND COGNITIVE SKILLS WITH STUDENTS AND PROVIDING ONE-ON-ONE EDUCATIONAL SUPPORT FOR STUDENTS IN SPECIAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS AT ELLISVILLE STATE SCHOOL AND KIDS KINGDOM LEARNING CENTER.  WITH THE ASSISTANCE OF THE FGP VOLUNTEERS IN TUTORING AND MENTORING THE CHILDREN RECEIVING THESE SERVICES WILL IMPROVE OR MAINTAIN THEIR FUNCTIONING LEVEL, SHOW IMPROVED READING AND OR MATH SKILLS AND BE PROMOTED TO THE NEXT LEVEL IN SCHOOL.
93 FGP WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME BASED ASSIGNMENTS. SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE (1) ASSISTING IN CLASSROOMS (2) TUTORING IN PUBLIC SCHOOL (3) SCHOOL BASED MENTORING. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THE PROJECT IS EDUCATION. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, 93 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL HAVE SERVED APPROXIMATELY 1,300 STUDENTS. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $598,220.00 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $147,972.00 IN NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES.

BEGINNING IN 1965 AS A DIRECT RESULT OF THE WAR ON POVERTY, COMMUNITY ACTION COUNCIL (THE COUNCIL) HAS HAD A LONG AND SUCCESSFUL HISTORY OF OFFERING OPPORTUNITIES THAT HELP INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES WORK TOWARD SELF-SUFFICIENCY. WITH NEARLY 17 PERCENT OF RESIDENTS IN THE SERVICE AREA OF THE PROPOSED FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) LIVING BELOW THE FEDERAL POVERTY THRESHOLD, THERE REMAINS A STRONG NEED FOR THE COUNCIL TO CONTINUE OFFERING SENIOR VOLUNTEER PROGRAMS THAT OFFER A STIPEND FOR SERVICE ACTIVITIES WHICH ALIGN CLOSELY WITH THE COUNCIL'S MISSION. 
THE COUNCIL'S FGP PROGRAM WILL ANNUALLY RECRUIT AND EQUIP AN ESTIMATED 28 FGP VOLUNTEERS TO SERVE UNDER THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF EDUCATION AND K-12 SUCCESS IN AT LEAST 11 STATION SITES. OF THE TOTAL NUMBER OF UNDUPLICATED VOLUNTEERS, AT LEAST 86 PERCENT (OR 24 FGP VOLUNTEERS) WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS UNDER THE PERFORMANCE MEASURE CATEGORY OF SCHOOL READINESS. FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL WORK ONE-ON-ONE WITH PRESCHOOL- AND SCHOOL-AGE CHILDREN ENROLLED IN ONE OF THE COUNCIL'S HEAD START CENTER-BASED PROGRAMS OR PARTNERSHIP SITES, OTHER NON-PROFIT CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTERS OR THE LOCAL PUBLIC SCHOOL SYSTEM, WHO HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS HAVING SPECIAL OR EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS. AN ADDITIONAL 2 FGP VOLUNTEERS, OR 7 PERCENT, WILL BE STATIONED WITHIN A FAITH-BASED CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTER. THE FGP VOLUNTEERS IN THESE ASSIGNMENTS WILL FACILITATE ACTIVITIES WITH THE CHILDREN THAT STRENGTHEN ACADEMIC SKILLS SUCH AS LITERACY AND NUMERACY, BUILD FINE AND GROSS MOTOR SKILLS, AND HELP REINFORCE IMPORTANT SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL SKILLS NECESSARY FOR SUCCESS LATER IN LIFE. ADDITIONALLY, NOT MORE THAN 2 FGP VOLUNTEERS, OR 7 PERCENT OF THE TOTAL, WILL SERVE UNDER THE PERFORMANCE MEASURE CATEGORY OF K-12 SUCCESS. THESE VOLUNTEERS WILL WORK WITH THE SCHOOL-AGE CHILDREN BY PROVIDING TUTORING AND MENTORING SERVICES IN ORDER TO ENHANCE AND SUPPORT THE CHILDREN'S ENROLLMENT AND SUCCESS IN SCHOOL. TOGETHER, THE COUNCIL ANTICIPATES THAT 100 PERCENT OF FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS, SUPPORTING APPROXIMATELY 112 CHILDREN ANNUALLY. 
AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT PERIOD, THE COUNCIL ANTICIPATES THAT, AS A RESULT OF THESE ACTIVITIES, AT LEAST 85 PERCENT OF CHILDREN ASSIGNED TO A FOSTER GRANDPARENT WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS AND ENTER SCHOOL WITH THE DESIGNATION OF "READY TO LEARN." THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE (CNCS) FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $166,110 ANNUALLY WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY AT LEAST $17,000 IN NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES.

AN ESTIMATED 69 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE.   OF THIS NUMBER 69 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME BASED ASSIGNMENTS .  SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE: MENTORING, SOCIAL BEHAVIORAL SKILLS, SCHOOL PREPAREDNESS, MOTOR INTELLECTUAL SKILLS AND COMMUNICATION SKILLS.  THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION.  AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, WE WILL HAVE 69 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS SERVING IN THE FOCUS AREA OF EDUCATION.  THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $339,762 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $57,259.00.

AT THE END OF THE PROGRAM CYCLE, WE ANTICIPATE THE FOLLOWING OUTCOMES:
*40 CHILDREN IN HEAD START WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SOCIAL AND/OR DEVELOPMENTAL BEHAVIORS
*20 CHILDREN IN DAYCARE FACILITIES WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SOCIAL AND/OR DEVELOPMENTAL BEHAVIORS
*2 CHILDREN IN SPECIAL EDUCATION CLASSROOMS WILL IMPROVE IN ACADEMICS
*40 CHILDREN IN THE PUBLIC SCHOOL SYSTEM WILL DEMONSTRATE IMPROVED ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE IN LITERACY AND/OR MATH.

SINCE 1965, MACON-BIBB COUNTY ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY COUNCIL, INC. (MBCEOCI) HAS PROVIDED COMPREHENSIVE, HIGH-QUALITY EARLY CHILDHOOD, FAMILY, AND COMMUNITY SERVICES TO ELIGIBLE CHILDREN AND FAMILIES THROUGHOUT MACON-BIBB AND MONROE COUNTIES IN THE STATE OF GEORGIA. IT IS THE MISSION OF MBCEOCI TO REDUCE POVERTY BY PROVIDING COLLABORATIVE COMPREHENSIVE SERVICES AND RESOURCES THAT EMPOWER ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED FAMILIES TO ACHIEVE SELF-SUFFICIENCY. OUR EXPERIENCE AS A FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) GRANTEE HAS AFFORDED US THE OPPORTUNITY TO HAVE PROFOUND COMMUNITY CONNECTIONS AND A CLEAR UNDERSTANDING OF THE NEEDS OF THE FAMILIES, CHILDREN AND STAFF INVOLVED WITH OUR PROGRAM. TODAY, MBCEOCI'S FGP PROGRAM IS FUNDED FOR FORTY (40) VOLUNTEERS. THE VOLUNTEERS PROVIDE ONE-ON-ONE SERVICE TO YOUTH AND YOUNG CHILDREN UP TO THE AGE OF TWENTY (20) THAT MAY BE AT-RISK, ACADEMICALLY CHALLENGED OR THOSE WHO HAVE DROPPED OUT OF SCHOOL. MBCEOCI PARTNERS WITH EXPERIENCED AND QUALIFIED PROVIDERS TO PREPARE THE YOUTH FOR SUCCESS IN SCHOOL AND PROVIDE THEIR FAMILIES WITH A FULL RANGE OF INTEGRATED AND INTENSIVE SUPPORT SERVICES TO HELP THEM BECOME SELF-SUFFICIENT. ONE HUNDRED PERCENT (100%) OF THE VOLUNTEERS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME-BASED ASSIGNMENTS WITH THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF EDUCATION.  VOLUNTEERS WILL BE PLACED IN LOCAL SCHOOLS TO INCREASE GRADE LEVEL PERFORMANCE THAT LEADS TO AN INCREASE IN GRADUATION RATES, AS WELL AS A REDUCTION IN THE HIGH SCHOOL DROPOUT RATE. THE VOLUNTEERS WILL ASSIST YOUTH BY TUTORING AND MENTORING WHERE NEEDED TO PREPARE THEM FOR THEIR FUTURE THROUGH EDUCATION. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT 70% OF YOUTH AND YOUNG CHILDREN RECEIVING SERVICES WILL ADVANCE TO THE NEXT LEVEL OR GRADE WITHOUT THE NEED FOR ADDITIONAL SERVICES. ONGOING SERVICES WILL BE PROVIDED, IF NEEDED. WITH A TOTAL BASE FUNDING OF $253,147 AND $26,059 OF IN-KIND, MBCEOCI PROPOSES TO ENHANCE THE QUALITY OF ITS CURRENT SERVICES IN MACON-BIBB COUNTY IN GEORGIA BY CONTINUING TO PARTNER AND ALIGN THE ORGANIZATION WITH APPROPRIATE RESOURCES TO HELP STRENGTHEN FAMILIES AND OUTCOMES. THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS ESSENTIAL THROUGHOUT MACON-BIBB COUNTY. IT WILL BE OUR HONOR TO CONTINUE TO PROVIDE THIS PROGRAM TO THE COMMUNITY AND PROVIDE MAXIMUM EFFECTIVENESS FOR THE YOUTH AND FAMILIES THAT WE SERVE.

THE MISSION OF COMMUNITIES IN SCHOOLS (CIS), THE NATION'S LEADING DROPOUT-PREVENTION ORGANIZATION, IS TO SURROUND STUDENTS WITH A COMMUNITY OF SUPPORT, EMPOWERING THEM TO STAY IN SCHOOL AND ACHIEVE IN LIFE. CIS HAS A RESEARCH-BASED AND PROVEN-EFFECTIVE MODEL TO FACILITATE AND SUPPORT EDUCATION PROGRAMMING INSIDE A SCHOOL OR COMMUNITY CENTER THAT HELPS ASSESS NEEDS AND COORDINATE RESOURCES THAT REMOVE BARRIERS TO A STUDENT'S SUCCESS. THE GOAL OF THE CISFL FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROJECT IS TO INCREASE TUTORING AND SCHOOL READINESS FOR AT-RISK STUDENTS IN THE FORM OF FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS.  FOSTER GRANDPARENTS SERVING UNDER THE K-12 SUCCESS WORK PLAN IN PUTNAM COUNTY WILL ASSIST AT-RISK CHILDREN WHO ARE STRUGGLING WITH PRE-LITERACY AND GRADE LEVEL LITERACY CHALLENGES. UNDER THE SCHOOL READINESS WORK PLAN, ASSIGNMENTS WILL BE WORKING WITH CHILDREN WHO MAY HAVE EMOTIONAL BONDING ISSUES OR COGNITIVE, AFFECTIVE, OR PSYCHO-MOTOR DELAYS. THE ROLE OF THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE TO BUILD THE SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL SKILLS OF THE CHILDREN THEY ARE SERVING. 

COMMUNITIES IN SCHOOLS OF FLORIDA IS REQUESTING FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $196,868 TO SUPPORT 33 VSYS WITH A MINIMUM OF 33 VOLUNTEERS. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS IN PUTNAM COUNTY WILL BE SERVING AT NINE (9) PUBLIC SCHOOLS.

THE PROJECT'S ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES ARE AS FOLLOWS: 1. CHILDREN RECEIVING LITERACY TUTORING WILL MAKE THE NECESSARY GAINS IN SKILLS AS MEASURED THROUGH I-READY AND/OR THE FLORIDA STANDARDS ASSESSMENT TO BE PROMOTED TO THE NEXT GRADE.  FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL UTILIZE FLASH CARDS, LETTER TILES, WORD LISTS, EDUCATIONAL GAMES, AND TEACHER PROVIDED WORKSHEETS TO TEACH CHILDREN THEIR COLORS, SHAPES, LETTERS, NUMBERS, AND MATHEMATICAL FUNCTIONS.

2. CHILDREN SERVED IN SCHOOL READINESS WORK PLANS WILL MAKE ADEQUATE GAINS IN THE AREAS OF SOCIAL/EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO BE PROMOTED TO THE NEXT LEVEL OR BE KINDERGARTEN READY. THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL HELP TO BUILD THESE SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL SKILLS BY ACTIVITIES WHICH MAY INCLUDE HOLDING/ROCKING TO PROVIDE COMFORT TO A CRYING CHILD, READING TO CHILDREN, HELPING CHILDREN CUT AND PASTE, PROVIDING PRAISE AND ENCOURAGEMENT AS CHILDREN LEARN THEIR SHAPES, COLORS AND LETTERS, SING SONGS, AND PRACTICE WRITING THEIR NAMES. OTHER ACTIVITIES MAY INCLUDE PARTICIPATING IN A CHILD'S DRAMATIC PLAY, OR ENGAGING THEM IN BUILDING BLOCK OR PUZZLES. VOLUNTEERS WILL REINFORCE APPROPRIATE SOCIAL SKILLS SUCH AS SHARING AND TAKING TURNS. THEY WILL ALSO HELP CHILDREN TALK ABOUT THEIR FEELINGS, RESOLVE CONFLICT, AND FOLLOW CLASSROOM RULES.

DURING THE  THE 2020-2023 GRANT CYCLE, COMMUNITIES IN SCHOOLS OF FLORIDA WILL CONTINUE TO COORDINATE THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM WITH THE SUPPORT OF THE PUTNAM COUNTY SCHOOL DISTRICT AND THE FGP ADVISORY COUNCIL.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:

SENIORS IN SERVICE OF TAMPA BAY, INC. WAS INCORPORATED IN HILLSBOROUGH COUNTY IN 1984 AS A NON-PROFIT 501(C)3 ORGANIZATION.   OUR MISSION IS TO PROVIDE SOLUTIONS TO COMMUNITY CHALLENGES BY ENGAGING VOLUNTEERS AGED 55+.  WE HELP DISADVANTAGED CHILDREN, FRAIL ELDERS, ADULTS WITH DISABILITIES, OVERWHELMED CAREGIVERS, STRUGGLING VETERANS AND HUNGRY FAMILIES IN HILLSBOROUGH, PINELLAS AND PASCO COUNTIES.  OUR SENIOR-AGED VOLUNTEERS ALSO BENEFIT FROM STAYING ACTIVE AND PURPOSEFUL.  FISCALLY SOUND AND INNOVATIVE, WE ARE RECOGNIZED FOR OUR IMPACT AND SAVINGS TO OUR COMMUNITY.  OUR PURPOSE FOR THIS PROPOSAL IS TO HELP DISADVANTAGED CHILDREN SUCCEED THROUGH THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM.  

AN ESTIMATED 105 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE. OF THIS NUMBER, 105 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS.  SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE TUTORING CHILDREN IN PRE-K THROUGH 5TH GRADE FOR IMPROVEMENT IN LITERACY, SCHOOL READINESS AND SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL SKILLS.  THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION.  AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, 80% OF CHILDREN SERVED WILL SHOW IMPROVEMENT IN LITERACY, SCHOOL READINESS AND/OR SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL SKILLS AS EVALUATED BY THE TEACHER.   THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $681,849 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY A TOTAL OF $74,451 IN NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES.

THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM OF TUSCALOOSA COUNTY PROVIDES INCOME ELIGIBLE SENIORS, 55 YEARS OLD OR OLDER, THE OPPORTUNITY TO VOLUNTEER IN NEIGHBORHOOD SCHOOLS, HEAD START AND NON-PROFIT OR FAITH-BASED DAY CARE CENTERS BY PROVIDING TUTORING, MENTORING AND ASSISTING SPECIAL NEEDS AND OR AT-RISK CHILDREN, IN ONE ON ONE OR SMALL GROUP SETTINGS.   

THE MAJOR OBJECTIVE FOR THIS PROGRAM IS LITERACY AS IT RELATES TO FLUENCY/COMPREHENSION AND SCHOOL ATTENDANCE.  THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA FOR THIS PROJECT IS K-12 SUCCESS.  AN ESTIMATED 34 VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE AS FOSTER GRANDPARENTS.  HISTORICALLY, THE ACTUAL NUMBER OF UNDUPLICATED FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL CHANGE DURING THE YEAR DUE TO UNFORESEEN ILLNESSES, DECLINING HEALTH AND/OR DEATH.  WE MONITOR PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS' ATTENDANCE TO PREVENT THIS FROM ADVERSELY AFFECTING OUR ATTAINMENT OF THE REQUIRED 29 VSYS FOR THE GRANT CYCLE.
AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT CYCLE, THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOME IS TO HAVE A MINIMUM OF 29 UNDUPLICATED VOLUNTEERS, WORKING 12 TO 35 HOURS PER WEEK WITH 80% OF THE STUDENTS ACHIEVING SUCCESS IN LITERACY WHICH WILL ENSURE THEIR PROMOTION TO THE NEXT GRADE LEVEL AND OR EXCEED CURRENT EDUCATIONAL STANDARDS.  THE CURRENT CNCS TWELVE MONTH FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $167,253 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY A MINIMUM OF 10% NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES.  WE WILL BE REQUESTING ADDITIONAL FUNDING LOCALLY AND THROUGH THE STATE TO ASSIST US IN MEETING THE NEEDS OF THIS COMMUNITY'S CORE CONCERN OF LITERACY.

OUR VOLUNTEERS RECEIVE PRE AND ONGOING MONTHLY TRAINING FROM RETIRED SCHOOL ADMINISTRATORS, EDUCATORS AND OTHER PROFESSIONALS IN CHILD CARE SERVICE AREAS FROM BOTH PRIVATE AND PUBLIC SECTORS.  MOST OF OUR FOSTER GRANDPARENTS SERVE AS VOLUNTEERS IN THEIR NEIGHBORHOOD SCHOOLS WHICH LENDS ITSELF TO A STRONGER COMMITMENT TO THE STUDENTS THEY SERVE IN THE CAPACITY OF MENTORS, TUTORS.  THEY ARE REFERRED TO BY CURRENT AND FORMER FGP VOLUNTEERS, SCHOOL ADMINISTRATORS AND EDUCATORS.  THEY SERVE IN OUR SCHOOLS AS AN EXTRA PAIR OF EARS, EYES AND HANDS IN THE CLASSROOMS. 

THE TUSCALOOSA CITY SCHOOLS STRATEGIC PLAN (LEARNING REIMAGINED) ESTABLISHED READING PROFICIENCY AS A PRIORITY. 
ACCORDING TO TEST SCORES FROM THE 2016 ADMINISTRATION OF THE ACT ASPIRE TEST FOR THIRD-GRADE STUDENTS, ONLY 39 PERCENT OF TOTAL STUDENTS WERE DEEMED PROFICIENT IN READING. UPON CLOSER REVIEW OF THESE FINDINGS SHOWS AN ACHIEVEMENT GAP EXISTS AMONG BLACK AND WHITE STUDENTS.  

THE SYSTEM IS PLACING A TARGETED PRIORITY IN CLOSING THE ACHIEVEMENT GAP THAT EXISTS IN THE TCS THROUGH BETTER TRAINED READING COACHES AND FREE SUMMER SCHOOLS.  THE SYSTEMS ALSO HAVE EXTENDED DAY PROGRAMS STAFFED BY CERTIFIED TEACHERS WHO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL ACADEMIC FOLLOW-UP. 

AS PART OF THE STRATEGIC PLAN, THE SCHOOL SYSTEM IS PARTNERING WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS IN BUSINESS, FAMILIES, AND FAITH-BASED ORGANIZATIONS TO ESTABLISH A COMMUNITY FOCUS ON READING. 
TO SUPPORT THE TCS GOAL IN READING, THE SYSTEM ESTABLISHED THE READING BY THIRD GRADE COALITION COMPRISED OF ALL COMMUNITY PARTNERS WITH THE GOAL OF ESTABLISHING A TRUE READING CULTURE IN THE CITY OF TUSCALOOSA.  THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM OF TUSCALOOSA COUNTY IS ONE OF THE MANY COMMUNITY PARTNERS.
THE SYSTEM REPORTED THAT STUDENTS WHO STRUGGLE IN READING WILL NOT BE AS SUCCESSFUL IN THEIR LEARNING AFTER THIRD GRADE.  TO ALLEVIATE THESE FINDINGS, GOVERNOR KAY IVEY SIGNED THE ALABAMA LITERACY ACT IN JUNE, 2019.  THIS LAW "MANDATES THAT ALL K-3 CHILDREN IN ALABAMA PUBLIC SCHOOLS BE SCREENED FOR LITERACY DEFICITS INCLUDING DYSLEXIA.  ADDITIONALLY, STUDENTS WHO EVIDENCE CHARACTERISTICS OF DYSLEXIA AS DETERMINED BY THE DYSLEXIA SCREENING MUST BE PROVIDED WITH DYSLEXIA-SPECIFIC INTERVENTION. A LITERACY PLAN MUST BE DEVELOPED BY THE STUDENT'S TEACHERS AND PARENTS AND PARENTS MUST BE APPRISED OF STUDENT PROGRESS REGULARLY."

A STRONG, ORGANIZED AND SHARED COMMUNITY INITIATIVE WITH A FOCUS ON READING WILL HAVE AN EDUCATIONAL IMPACT ON OUR STUDENTS AND AN ECONOMIC IMPACT

WYOMING SENIOR CITIZENS, INC.(WSCI), WAS FOUNDED IN 1975 AND IS A NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION WHOSE PURPOSE IS TO MEET THE NEEDS WYOMING'S OLDER RESIDENTS AND HELP THEM MAINTAIN THEIR INDEPENDENCE.  THE POPULATION OF WYOMING IS ONLY 582,658 WITH 16.1% OF THE POPULATION OVER 65.  WSCI SERVES THE ENTIRE STATE OF WYOMING THROUGH THE SENIOR COMPANION PROGRAM, LONG-TERM CARE OMBUDSMAN AND ELDER ABUSE PROGRAMS, WYOMING HEALTH INSURANCE INFORMATION PROGRAM, SENIOR MEDICARE PATROL PROGRAM, NATIONAL FAMILY CAREGIVER SUPPORT PROGRAM, AND THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM.

WSCI IS REQUESTING $332,804 FOR THIS PROJECT PERIOD IN ORDER TO SUPPORT 52 FEDERAL VOLUNTEER SERVICE YEARS OR VSYS.  THE PROGRAM STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS WILL MENTOR TROUBLED TEENAGERS AND YOUNG MOTHERS, CARE FOR PREMATURE INFANTS OR CHILDREN WITH DISABILITIES, AND HELP CHILDREN WHO HAVE BEEN ABUSED OR NEGLECTED.  THE PROGRAM STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS WILL ALSO WORK TO SERVE THOSE CHILDREN WITH EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS, AND TEACH OTHER CHILDREN TO READ THROUGH ONE-ON-ONE TUTORING.  WSCI ANTICIPATES RECEIVING $24,152 IN STATE FUNDING AND AN ESTIMATED $12,826 FROM OTHER SOURCES TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE SUCCESS OF THIS PROGRAM.

THE FOCUS OF THIS APPLICATION WILL BE HEALTHY FUTURES OF WYOMING'S YOUTH THROUGH THE INVOLVEMENT OF GRANDPARENT MENTORS OVER AGE 55.  THE GOAL IS TO NOT ONLY HELP THE CHILDREN SUCCEED, BUT BUILD THE CONFIDENCE AND SELF WORTH OF THE SENIOR VOLUNTEERS AS WELL.  ONE OF THE TRULY FORGOTTEN RESOURCES IN OUR COMMUNITIES IS THE KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERIENCE HELD BY OUR ELDERS.  USING THEM AS A RESOURCE TO HELP AND SUPPORT OUR YOUTH IS A WIN-WIN FOR EVERYONE.  

THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS PROGRAM WILL SERVE 6 OF 23 COUNTIES IN WYOMING AND UTILIZE VOLUNTEER STATIONS TO ASSIST IN TRAINING AND MANAGEMENT OF THE VOLUNTEERS.  AN ESTIMATED 69 UN-DUPLICATED VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE OVER 200 CHILDREN THROUGHOUT THE AFFECTED COUNTIES.  FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL VOLUNTEER BETWEEN 15-40 HOURS PER WEEK MENTORING THE CHILDREN AS WELL AS TUTORING WITH READING AND MATH.  THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, WSCI ANTICIPATE 200 CHILDREN WILL INCREASE IN MATH AND OR READING SKILLS DUE TO THE MENTORING OF FOSTER GRANDPARENTS. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $309,803 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY AN ESTIMATED $35,000 FROM STATE AND LOCAL FUNDS.

COMMUNITY NEED:  SACRAMENTO AND PLACER COUNTIES HAVE BOTH DEMONSTRATED A NEED FOR IMPROVEMENT AND SUPPORT IN THE AREA OF EDUCATION. ACCORDING TO THE 2018 CALIFORNIA CHILDREN?S REPORT CARD, STUDENTS STATEWIDE CONTINUE TO LAG BEHIND NATIONALLY ON ACHIEVEMENT MEASURES WITH CALIFORNIA BEING RANKED 40TH IN GRADE LEVEL READING, AND 42ND IN GRADE LEVEL MATH. ACHIEVEMENT VARIES BY INCOME, AND PERFORMANCE FOR CHILDREN WHO ARE BLACK AND LATINO FALLS BEHIND THAT OF THEIR PEERS WHO ARE ASIAN AND WHITE. 
WITHIN THE TWO COUNTIES, THERE ARE CURRENTLY 40.5% OF THE RESIDENTS WITH INCOMES BELOW POVERTY LEVEL. ADDITIONALLY, A LARGE AMOUNT OF THE HOMES ARE SINGLE INCOME AND/OR SINGLE PARENT HOMES. MANY OF THE PARENTS AND CAREGIVERS ARE TRYING TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR THEIR FAMILIES AND DO NOT HAVE THE TIME FOR MUCH ELSE.  DESPITE CALIFORNIA?S HIGH PER CAPITA INCOME, THE STATE CONTINUES TO LAG BEHIND THE NATIONAL AVERAGE IN SCHOOL FUNDING. THIS INADEQUATE FUNDING DOES NOT MEET SCHOOLS? NEEDS, AND AS A RESULT THERE ARE LESS TEACHERS AND OTHER CARING ADULTS TO SUPPORT STUDENTS. THIS IS CRITICAL FOR STUDENTS WHO NEED LANGUAGE DEVELOPMENT SUPPORT, LIVE IN POVERTY, OR FACE OTHER RISK FACTORS SUCH AS BEING PART OF THE FOSTER CARE SYSTEM.
MANY OF CALIFORNIA?S POOREST KIDS DO NOT HAVE ACCESS TO PUBLICLY-FUNDED PROGRAMS, DESPITE BEING ELIGIBLE. HIGH-QUALITY EARLY LEARNING PROGRAMS HAVE BEEN SHOWN TO NARROW THE ACHIEVEMENT GAP AND ARE ESPECIALLY BENEFICIAL TO CHILDREN OF LOW INCOME FAMILIES. SINCE 1972, PEPPERDINE UNIVERSITY HAS SUCCESSFULLY SPONSORED THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP). FGP IS AN INNOVATIVE, MULTIGENERATIONAL VOLUNTEER PROGRAM THAT PAIRS ELDERLY CITIZENS WITH AT-RISK YOUTH FROM IMPOVERISHED, UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES WITHIN THE GREATER LOS ANGELES (LA) AREA. THROUGH A SYMBIOTIC MODEL, FGP SIMULTANEOUSLY PROVIDES COMPANIONSHIP FOR ELDERLY VOLUNTEERS AND MENTORSHIP TO YOUTH WITH SPECIAL NEEDS AND DIFFICULT CIRCUMSTANCES. FGP PRIMARILY FOCUSES ON EDUCATIONAL IMPROVEMENT, WORKING TO PROMOTE SCHOOL READINESS AND SUCCESS IN YOUTH (K-12). FGP PURPOSEFULLY TARGETS POPULATIONS IN HIGHLY IMPOVERISHED NEIGHBORHOODS OF SOUTH CENTRAL LA. MORE THAN 38% OF LA COUNTY RESIDENTS LIVE IN ECONOMIC HARDSHIP, WHILE 18% LIVE BELOW THE FEDERAL POVERTY LINE ($28,290 ANNUALLY FOR A FAMILY OF FOUR). COMPARATIVELY, WITHIN FGP'S PRIMARY SERVICE AREA, A STARTLING 52% OF FAMILIES LIVE BELOW THE FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL. UNDER CONDITIONS OF SIGNIFICANT POVERTY, CHILDREN EXPERIENCE ENHANCED RISK OF DEVELOPMENTAL DELAYS, ESPECIALLY IN THE CRITICAL AREAS OF LANGUAGE, LITERACY, AND EMOTIONAL REGULATION. THROUGH ITS INNOVATIVE STRUCTURE, FGP WORKS TO MITIGATE EDUCATIONAL CHALLENGES AND RISKS FOR VULNERABLE YOUTH BY PROVIDING A SOURCE OF MENTORSHIP AND SUPPORT FROM ITS FOSTER GRANDPARENTS. IN ORDER TO CONTINUE ITS IMPORTANT WORK THROUGH THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM, PEPPERDINE IS REQUESTING SUPPORT FROM THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE TO INCREASE ITS CAPACITY AND, CONSEQUENTLY, ITS IMPACT.
  PEPPERDINE IS WELL EQUIPPED TO TAKE ON 64 VOLUNTEERS, GIVEN ITS CURRENT STATUS AS THE HOST INSTITUTION FOR VOLUNTEERS WHO WERE DISPLACED FOLLOWING THE CLOSING OF A JUMPSTART PROGRAM. ACCORDINGLY, PEPPERDINE HAS ESTABLISHED RELATIONSHIPS WITH SEVEN OF NEW VOLUNTEER STATIONS, AND IS WELL PREPARED TO ADD AN ADDITIONAL 8 VOLUNTEERS TO THE CURRENT 58 WHO HAVE JOINED OUR ROBUST TEAM OF 104 VOLUNTEERS. QUICK SUCCESS IN PLACEMENT AND TRANSITION HAS BOLSTERED THE IMPACT OF THE FGP AT PEPPERDINE UNIVERSITY, AND CONTINUES TO MAKE UNPRECEDENTED STRIDES IN STUDENT OUTCOMES. IN ORDER TO CONTINUE TO IMPROVE EDUCATIONAL OUTCOMES FOR HIGH-RISK YOUTH, PEPPERDINE'S FGP WILL FURTHER INCREASE ITS IMPACT IN THE LOS ANGELES COMMUNITY BY PERMANENTLY ADDING AN ADDITIONAL 64 VOLUNTEERS TO ITS EXISTING 104 SENIOR CITIZENS (FGP VOLUNTEERS) WHO ARE PAIRED WITH YOUTH FROM THE FOLLOWING TARGETED GROUPS: 1) HEAD START PROGRAMS FOR YOUNG CHILDREN AGES 3-5; 2) SPECIALIZED EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FOR DISADVANTAGED AND/OR DISABLED YOUTH; 3) K-12 STUDENTS NEEDING ADDITIONAL ASSISTANCE IN LANGUAGE DEVELOPMENT AND LITERACY; AND 4) VULNERABLE YOUTH NEEDING ADULT SUPPORT WHILE PARENTS ARE BEING TREATED FOR SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND/OR MENTAL HEALTH ISSUES. THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL FACILITATE A WIDE ARRAY OF EDUCATIONAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL ACTIVITIES WITH THEIR YOUTH PARTNERS INCLUDING: ASSISTING IN HEAD START AND K-12 CLASSROOMS,  READING,  TUTORING, MENTORING, SOCIALIZING (PLAYING EDUCATIONAL GAMES, READING, TALKING, WALKING, LISTENING, AND SHARING MEALS), AND SUPPORTING YOUTH WHOSE PARENTS ARE RECEIVING REHABILITATIVE TREATMENT. ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT AND ADDITION OF 64 VOLUNTEERS INCLUDE INCREASED SCHOOL READINESS, ENHANCED LANGUAGE AND LITERACY SKILLS, IMPROVED CLASSROOM PARTICIPATION, HEIGHTENED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT, AND GREATER SOCIAL AND BEHAVIORAL SKILLS FOR PARTICIPATING YOUTH.

WORKFORCE CONNECTIONS, INC. (WCI) IS A NON-PROFIT COMMUNITY PARTNER DEDICATED TO PROVIDING SERVICES AND TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES TO JOB SEEKERS AND BUSINESSES THROUGHOUT WESTERN WISCONSIN FOR OVER 35 YEARS.  WCI IS COMMITTED TO CONNECTING PEOPLE, WORK, AND TRAINING TO PROMOTE SELF-SUFFICIENCY.    
NEARLY 20% OF CHILDREN IN WISCONSIN LIVE IN POVERTY (UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN).  THE AFFECTS OF POVERTY ON CHILDREN SHOW IN THE FORM OF INABILITY TO LEARN IN THE CLASSROOM AT THE SAME LEVEL AS THEIR PEERS, LONG-TERM HEALTH ISSUES, AND THE INABILITY TO BE SELF-SUFFICIENT LATER IN LIFE.  ADULTS, 55 AND OLDER, ALSO FACE CHALLENGES SUCH AS THE RISING COST OF LIVING, HEALTHCARE COSTS, AND LONELINESS.  THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM WILL HELP TO ADDRESS THESE COMMUNITY CONCERNS BY ENLISTING THE VOLUNTEER SERVICES OF SENIORS TO TUTOR CHILDREN TO HELP THEM IMPROVE MATH AND LITERACY SKILLS.   IN RETURN, FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL RECEIVE PROGRAM BENEFITS, A SENSE OF PURPOSE, AND HEALTH BENEFITS.
AN AVERAGE OF 28 FGP VOLUNTEERS PER YEAR WILL SERVE IN THE 5 COUNTIES OF WESTERN WISCONSIN:  LA CROSSE, PEPIN, BUFFALO, JACKSON, AND JUNEAU THROUGHOUT THE 3-YEAR PROGRAM.  THE 3-YEAR VOLUNTEER TALLY IS LIKELY TO TOTAL APPROXIMATELY 50-60 VOLUNTEERS.  FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS THROUGHOUT SCHOOLS AND OTHER NONPROFIT AGENCIES IN THE 5-COUNTY AREA.  VOLUNTEER ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE TUTORING PRIMARILY IN MATH AND LITERACY BUT MAY INCLUDE OTHER CORE SUBJECTS.  THIS TUTORING WILL RESULT IN 75% OF CHILDREN SERVED EXPERIENCING IMPROVED MATH AND LITERACY SCORES BY AT LEAST ONE GRADE. 
UPON COMPLETION OF THE 3-YEAR PROGRAM, APPROXIMATELY 300 CHILDREN WILL HAVE BEEN TUTORED WITH AT LEAST AN 75% SUCCESS RATE.  THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $168,077 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $23,749 OF NON-FEDERAL SOURCES.

IN 1965, THE WISCONSIN LEGISLATURE RECOGNIZED THE NEED FOR A SERVICE UNIT BETWEEN SCHOOL DISTRICTS AND THE STATE SUPERINTENDENT. COOPERATIVE EDUCATIONAL SERVICE AGENCY 10 (CESA 10) IS ONE OF 12 IN WISCONSIN AND PROVIDES SERVICES TO MEMBER SCHOOL DISTRICTS AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT THROUGHOUT THE STATE. THE MISSION OF CESA 10 IS TO ASSIST DISTRICTS WITH SERVICES THEY WOULD OTHERWISE HAVE DIFFICULTY PROVIDING, OR SERVICES THAT ARE MANDATED BY STATE OR FEDERAL GOVERNMENT. SINCE 1965, CESA 10 HAS TRADITIONALLY OFFERED SERVICES IN SPECIAL EDUCATION, INSTRUCTIONAL SERVICES, AND EDUCATIONAL TECHNOLOGY. IN THE LATE 90'S, THE FACILITIES MANAGEMENT DEPARTMENT WAS CREATED BASED ON SCHOOL-IDENTIFIED NEEDS, AND IS NOW PROVIDING SERVICES TO SCHOOL DISTRICTS STATEWIDE.

CESA 10 HAS BEEN PROVIDING THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) TO SCHOOLS SINCE 1987.  DURING THE 2019-20 SCHOOL YEAR, THE PROJECT PAIRED 38 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WITH MORE THAN 150 CHILDREN IN SEVEN COUNTIES IN WEST CENTRAL WISCONSIN. THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS LOGGED MORE THAN 25,000 HOURS IN THE CLASSROOM.

VOLUNTEERING IS GOOD FOR THE COMMUNITY AND FOR VOLUNTEERS.  HOWEVER, OLDER AMERICANS WHO HAVE LOW-INCOMES AND LEVELS OF EDUCATION OFTEN HAVE BARRIERS TO VOLUNTEERING, INCLUDING VULNERABILITY TO POOR HEALTH OUTCOMES.  ACCORDING TO A 2019 INDEPENDENT REPORT SPONSORED BY CNCS, "SENIOR CORPS PROVIDES THE ACCESS, STRUCTURE, AND FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR LOW-INCOME, AT-RISK AMERICANS 55 AND OLDER TO LIVE HAPPIER, HEALTHIER LIVES WHILE MAKING A DIFFERENCE IN THEIR COMMUNITIES" (SENIOR CORPS.GOV/HEALTHY VOLUNTEERS.)
FAMILY & COMMUNITY SERVICES, INC. (F&CS) IS A PRIVATE NON-PROFIT SOCIAL SERVICE AGENCY HEADQUARTERED IN RAVENNA, OHIO IN PORTAGE COUNTY. WITH 71 PROGRAMS IN 21 COUNTIES IN OHIO AND 2 COUNTIES IN MICHIGAN AND THE WORK OF OVER 600 EMPLOYEES, MORE THAN 100,000 CHILDREN AND ADULTS WERE ASSISTED IN 2017. SINCE ITS INCEPTION IN 1941, FAMILY & COMMUNITY SERVICES, INC. HAS SOUGHT TO STRENGTHEN, EMPOWER, AND ENRICH INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES THROUGH A BROAD CONTINUUM OF SERVICES. THE AGENCY IS GUIDED BY A COMMITMENT TO INDIVIDUAL DIGNITY, SERVICE EXCELLENCE, ACCOUNTABILITY, VOLUNTEERISM, AND BELIEF IN THE SOLIDARITY OF THE HUMAN FAMILY. 
FAMILY & COMMUNITY SERVICES, INC. PROPOSES TO CONTINUE TO PROVIDE SENIOR CORPS OPPORTUNITIES IN OHIO COMMUNITIES BY REQUESTING CONTINUATION OF THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM GRANT FOR THE OHIO COUNTIES OF STARK, MONTGOMERY, CLARK, GREENE, TRUMBULL, MAHONING, GEAUGA, AND PORTAGE IN OHIO.  THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM CURRENTLY HAS 80 VOLUNTEERS SERVING AN AVERAGE OF 30 HOURS PER WEEK, WITH RECRUITMENT INCREASING THROUGH CONTINUOUS COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT. IN 2019-2020 THE EXPECTATION IS THAT THERE WILL BE UP TO 100 UNDUPLICATED VOLUNTEERS IN TRAINING OR ACTIVELY SERVING. THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES EDUCATION ISSUE AREA, SPECIFICALLY WITH FOCUS ON THE FOLLOWING PERFORMANCE MEASURES: SCHOOL READINESS ED1A OUTPUT & ED23A OUTCOME; AND ED1A & ED4A: K-12 SUCCESS. 
IN PARTNERSHIP WITH LOCAL SCHOOL DISTRICTS, HEAD START LOCATIONS, SUMMER AND AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMMING AS WELL AS THE LOCAL CHAPTERS OF UNITED WAY, AREA AGENCY ON AGING AND SENIOR CENTERS, THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS SERVING IN STARK, MONTGOMERY, CLARK, GREENE, TRUMBULL, MAHONING, GEAUGA, AND PORTAGE COUNTIES IN OHIO WILL PROVIDE THE INDIVIDUALIZED ATTENTION AND SUPPORT THAT SOME CHILDREN NEED TO DEVELOP GOOD STUDY HABITS AND CLASSROOM BEHAVIOR AND TO REACH THEIR ACADEMIC GOALS. THE EXPECTED RESULTS ARE THAT 100 SENIOR VOLUNTEERS WILL BE ENGAGED IN AND CONTRIBUTE TO THEIR COMMUNITY THROUGH ONE-ON-ONE INTERACTION BETWEEN FOSTER GRANDPARENTS AND 500+ STUDENTS DEEMED AT-RISK.  THIS INTERACTION WILL CONTRIBUTE TOWARD INCREASING THE INDIVIDUAL CHILD'S SELF-ESTEEM AND DECREASING BEHAVIORAL PROBLEMS, ULTIMATELY RESULTING IN ACADEMIC PROGRESS AND SUCCESS.  
FOR THIS GRANT YEAR, F&CS IS REQUESTING 100 VSY, 93 WITH CNCS FUNDS, FOR AN EIGHT-COUNTY AREA: CLARK, GEAUGA, GREENE, MAHONING, MONTGOMERY, PORTAGE, STARK AND TRUMBULL.

THE PIONEER FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS SPONSORED BY BLUE VALLEY COMMUNITY ACTION PARTNERSHIP (BVCA). THE PIONEER FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM WAS THE FIRST FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IN THE STATE OF NEBRASKA STARTING IN 1972 WITH BVCA SPONSORING SINCE 1991. BLUE VALLEY COMMUNITY ACTION PARTNERSHIP (BVCA) WAS OFFICIALLY INCORPORATED ON JANUARY 19, 1966. BVCA IS A PRIVATE, NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION. BVCA PARTNERSHIP OPERATES 30 PROGRAMS THAT INTERACT AND COMPLEMENT EACH OTHER. THEIR PROGRAMS ARE AS DIVERSE AS THE COMMUNITIES AND FAMILIES THEY SERVE. BVCA'S PRIMARY SERVICE AREA INCLUDES BUTLER, FILLMORE, GAGE, JEFFERSON, POLK, SALINE, SEWARD, THAYER AND YORK COUNTIES WITH LIMITED SERVICES PROVIDED IN PAWNEE, NEMAHA, JOHNSON AND RICHARDSON COUNTIES IN NEBRASKA. THE OTHER FGP COUNTIES SERVED ARE IN THE SENCA (SOUTHEAST COMMUNITY ACTION PARTNERSHIP) SERVICE AREA, PAWNEE, NEMAHA, JOHNSON AND RICHARDSON COUNTIES.  SENCA ALSO SERVES CASS COUNTY IN NEBRASKA. BVCA'S PIONEER FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS REQUESTING 50 VOLUNTEER SERVICE YEARS (VSY'S) AND A TOTAL DOLLAR AMOUNT OF $320,908. 
SCHOOLS AND HEAD START PROGRAMS ARE THE PRIMARY STATIONS FGP VOLUNTEERS ARE PLACED IN.  THE PERFORMANCE MEASURES WE ARE USING ARE:
1.1 ASSISTING IN CLASSROOM, HEAD START WITH THE OBJECTIVE OF SCHOOL READINESS.  WE ARE TRACKING THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN WHO COMPLETED EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION PROGRAMS AND THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN DEMONSTRATING GAINS IN SOCIAL AND/OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT.  
2.1 TUTORING- PUBLIC SCHOOL WITH THE OBJECTIVE K-12 SUCCESS. WE ARE TRACKING THE NUMBER OF STUDENTS COMPLETING A CNCS SUPPORTED EDUCATION PROGRAM AND THE NUMBER OF STUDENTS IN MENTORING/TUTORING PROGRAMS WITH IMPROVED ACADEMICS.

AN ESTIMATED 10 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL SERVE WITHIN COMMUNITY ACTION'S EARLY HEAD START AND HEAD START CENTERS. OF THIS NUMBER, 10 (100%) WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL ASSIST IN CLASSROOMS, INCLUDING AIDING WITH SMALL GROUP ACTIVITIES, PROVIDING EMOTIONAL SUPPORT TO CHILDREN, TEACHING AND REINFORCING SOCIAL SKILLS IN THE MOMENT, AND FACILITATING MEALTIME DISCUSSIONS WITH CHILDREN. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS SCHOOL READINESS. AT THE END OF THE FIRST YEAR OF THE GRANT PERIOD, 87% OF CHILDREN WILL DEMONSTRATE DEVELOPMENTAL GAINS. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $67,654 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $6,667 IN NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES.

THE EASTERN NEBRASKA OFFICE ON AGING (ENOA) IS COMMITTED TO HELP OLDER NEBRASKANS LIVE INDEPENDENTLY AND PROVIDES VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES FOR INDIVIDUALS FOR ALL AGES. IN THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM, AN ESTIMATED 70 OLDER ADULTS WILL VOLUNTEER AND SERVE THEIR COMMUNITY. OF THIS NUMBER, 55 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME-BASED ASSIGNMENTS. SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE LISTENING TO CHILDREN READ, HELPING WITH A DAILY ROUTINE, HELPING CHILDREN STAY ON TASK, SETTING GOALS, ENCOURAGING POSITIVE SOCIAL SKILLS, AND PROVIDING SUPPORT AND ENCOURAGEMENT. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION. BY MEASURING PROGRESS ON THE VOLUNTEER ASSIGNMENT PLANS IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT AT LEAST 65% OF THE CHILDREN WILL DEMONSTRATE IMPROVEMENT IN ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT OR SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR SCHOOL READINESS. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $336,342 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY LOCAL SUPPORT OF $64,660 AND AN EXCESS AMOUNT OF $5,729.

THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM OF EASTERN NORTH DAKOTA (FGP OF E. ND) SPONSORED BY TRI-VALLEY OPPORTUNITY COUNCIL, INC. (AKA TRI-VALLEY)  WOULD BE DEDICATED TO OPERATING A PROGRAM THAT HELPS MEET THE NEEDS OF CHILDREN BIRTH TO 21, WHILE ALSO PROVIDING MEANINGFUL VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES FOR ADULTS 55 AND OLDER.

TRI-VALLEY HAS SUCCESSFULLY BEEN A GRANTEE SPONSOR OF THE FGP OF NW MN SINCE 1997, WITH A SERVICE AREA OF 11 COUNTIES (POLK, NORMAN, RED LAKE, LAKE OF THE WOODS, ROSEAU, PENNINGTON, MARSHALL, KITTSON, MAHNOMEN, BECKER AND CLAY). THIS LONGEVITY IS A RESULT OF NURTURING COMMUNITY PARTNERS AND FUNCTIONAL WORKING RELATIONSHIP TO ASSESS THE NEEDS OF OUR EDUCATIONAL COMMUNITIES AND POPULATIONS SERVED. IT IS BECAUSE OF TRI-VALLEY?S MANY YEARS OF EXPERIENCE THAT WOULD MAKE THE EXPANSION OF THE PROGRAM INTO THE EASTERN PARTS OF NORTH DAKOTA AN EASY GROWTH, AS WE COULD ADAPT CURRENT PROCESS, PRACTICES AND POLICIES TO TACKLE A LARGER AND BORDERING AREA. OUR AGENCY ALSO PRACTICED AND HAS LEARNED A GREAT DEAL OVER THE YEARS OF WHAT IT TAKES TO GARNISH RELATIONSHIPS WITH VOLUNTEER, COMMUNITY PARTNERS AND FUTURE SITES TO CREATE A PROGRAM THAT WILL MEET THE NEEDS OF THE SITES AND DEFINED PERFORMANCE MEASURES.

THE PROPOSAL FOCUSES ON TWO COMMUNITY NEEDS IN THE COUNTIES OF EASTERN NORTH DAKOTA: K-12 SUCCESS AND SCHOOL READINESS. THE WORK PLANS ADDRESS EDUCATIONAL SUCCESS FOR K-12 THROUGH CONSISTENT ASSISTANCE WITH ACADEMIC MENTORING AND TUTORING IN CLASSROOMS. THESE WORK PLANS WILL ADDRESS SUCCESS IN DEMONSTRATING GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS AND IMPROVED ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE IN HEAD START CENTERS AND EDUCATIONAL SUCCESS IN PRIVATE AND PUBLIC SCHOOLS THROUGHOUT THE SERVICE AREA. THE VOLUNTEERS WILL BE ASSIGNED A SITE AND WILL VOLUNTEER WITH STUDENTS IN SMALL GROUPS AND 1:1; BUILDING A CONSISTENT, NURTURING, NON-JUDGMENTAL, INTER-GENERATIONAL, CARING RELATIONSHIP WITH THE STUDENTS.

THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM OF EASTERN NORTH DAKOTA IS REQUESTING $285,523.00 TO RECRUIT, SUSTAIN AND RETAIN 48 UNDUPLICATED VOLUNTEER SERVICE YEARS (VSYS) VOLUNTEERS AFTER THE COMPLETION OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT. THE 48 VSYS VOLUNTEERS WILL 1) WILL PROVIDE STUDENTS ASSISTANCE/ CLASSROOM SUPPORT AND TUTORING TO 375 CHILDREN IN PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SCHOOLS WITH EXCEPTIONAL OR SPECIAL NEEDS IN A SMALL GROUP OR 1 ON 1 SETTING, 2) WILL HELP 50 CHILDREN ENROLLED IN HEAD START PROGRAMS GAIN SCHOOL READINESS THROUGH DEMONSTRATION AND SUPPORT.

THE SENIOR VOLUNTEERS OF THE CENTRAL MN FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM(FGP) PROVIDE MEANINGFUL SUPPORTIVE RELATIONSHIPS FOR CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL NEEDS THAT ENRICH THE LIVES OF ALL INVOLVED. AN ESTIMATED 210 FOSTER GRANDPARENT(FG) VOLUNTEERS SERVE. THEY TUTOR AND MENTOR CHILDREN THROUGH A NETWORK OF 100+ VOLUNTEER STATIONS SUCH AS HEAD STARTS, PRE-SCHOOLS, AND K-12 CLASSROOMS. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION. ANNUALLY, THE THREE-YEAR GRANT WILL SUPPORT A MINIMUM OF 231 PRE-SCHOOL AGE CHILDREN IN DEMONSTRATING GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS, 1204 SCHOOL AGE CHILDREN IN DEMONSTRATING IMPROVED ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE IN ACADEMICS, AND AN ADDITIONAL 84 MENTORED CHILDREN WILL DEMONSTRATE IMPROVED ACADEMICS. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $745,927 TO FUND 125 VOLUNTEER SERVICE YEARS (VSYS) WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $184,662 NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES.

LUTHERAN SOCIAL SERVICE OF MINNESOTA (LSS OF MN) IS HONORED TO SERVE AS ONE OF FOUR PROVIDERS OF THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IN MINNESOTA. WE REMAIN COMMITTED TO OUR LONG STANDING PARTNERS ACROSS MINNESOTA AND CONTINUE TO EXPAND OUR WORK TO FOCUS ON EARLY CHILDHOOD IN SETTINGS WHERE VOLUNTEERS CAN MAKE AN INTEGRAL IMPACT BY PREPARING CHILDREN FOR SCHOOL. WE WILL ALSO RESPOND TO THE NEED FOR FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS IN SCHOOLS WITH HIGHER PERCENTAGES OF FREE AND REDUCED LUNCH STUDENTS. THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY WILL ALLOW LSS OF MN TO POSITIVELY SUPPORT AND IMPACT THE LIVES OF CHILDREN IN FIVE NEW RURAL COUNTIES WHERE ACCESS TO SERVICES ARE OFTEN LIMITED.  MINNESOTA CHILDREN IN POVERTY AND AFRICAN-AMERICAN STUDENTS AT ALL GRADE LEVELS ARE MORE THAN TWO GRADE LEVELS BEHIND THEIR PEERS. 13.8% OF ALL CHILDREN IN MINNESOTA LIVE AT OR BELOW THE POVERTY LEVEL AND THAT PERCENTAGE INCREASES TO 16% FOR CHILDREN UNDER THE AGE OF SIX. 35,000 MINNESOTA CHILDREN UNDER THE AGE OF FIVE DO NOT HAVE ACCESS TO HIGH QUALITY EARLY CHILDHOOD DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS. CHILDREN WHO DO NOT RECEIVE EARLY CHILDHOOD AND ELEMENTARY EDUCATION INTERVENTION MAY NOT ACHIEVE THEIR FULL POTENTIAL WHICH COULD RESULT IN COMMUNITIES WITH A LESS SKILLED WORKFORCE, INCREASED CRIME RATES, AND MORE CITIZENS ON PUBLIC ASSISTANCE. AS TEACHERS SEE MORE CHILDREN WITH HIGH NEEDS IN THEIR CLASSROOMS, A GREATER AMOUNT OF STAFF TIME IS REQUIRED TO MEET THE NEEDS OF THESE STUDENTS. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS, WHO SPEND ONE-TO-ONE TIME TUTORING AND MENTORING STUDENTS, WILL INCREASE STUDENT ENGAGEMENT AND SUCCESS. WITH A STRATEGIC FOCUS ON HIGH IMPACT SITES AND POPULATIONS, OUR VOLUNTEERS CAN IMPROVE THESE OUTCOMES AND CREATE A SUCCESSFUL ENVIRONMENT FOR THESE YOUTH. OUR CURRENT PROGRAMMING INCLUDES AN ESTIMATED 300 FGP VOLUNTEERS WHO WILL SERVE IN THE 2019-2020 BUDGET YEAR. ALL OF THESE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS. THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE TUTORING, MENTORING, AND SUPPORT OF SOCIAL EMOTIONAL GROWTH IN THE CHILDREN THEY SERVE. IN PARTICULAR, WE WILL FOCUS ON EARLY K-12 SUCCESS AND SCHOOL READINESS, WITH NEW FOCUS BEING PLACED ADDITIONALLY ON SCHOOLS SUPPORTING STEM PROGRAMMING, HOMELESSNESS, AND ADDRESSING THE EMERGING CHALLENGES OF DRUG AND OPIOID ABUSE. AT THE END OF THE GRANT, WE WILL DEMONSTRATE GROWTH IN ACADEMIC PROGRESS AND SOCIAL/EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT IN THE CHILDREN WE SERVE.  LSS OF MN HAS A LONG HISTORY OF STRONG PERFORMANCE IN DELIVERING FOSTER GRANDPARENT SERVICES TO DIVERSE COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE STATE.  IN THE 2018-2019 SCHOOL YEAR, 96% OF CHILDREN (2217 OUT OF 2305 RETURNED ASSIGNMENT PLANS) MET THEIR GOALS.  WE ARE CONTINUALLY LOOKING FOR WAYS TO IMPROVE SERVICE DELIVERY AND EXPECT THESE PERFORMANCE OUTCOMES TO CONTINUE. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $470,091 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY LSS OF MN FUNDS OF $64,898.
