THE NAME OF THE LEGAL APPLICANT OF THIS GRANT IS NEW HANOVER COUNTY SENIOR RESOURCE CENTER. NEW HANOVER COUNTY SENIOR RESOURCE CENTER IS PART OF NEW HANOVER COUNTY GOVERNMENT. THE SENIOR RESOURCE CENTER PROVIDES RESOURCES AND ACTIVITIES FOR SENIOR ADULTS IN NEW HANOVER COUNTY. THE RESOURCES AND ACTIVITIES PROVIDED BY THE CENTER ARE AIMED AT PROMOTING WELLNESS, ENCOURAGING INDEPENDENCE AND IMPROVING QUALITY OF LIFE. THE PROGRAMS OFFERED AT THE CENTER INCLUDE PHYSICAL FITNESS CLASSES, SUPPORT GROUPS, VOLUNTEER ENGAGEMENT, CONGREGATE MEALS, SOCIAL OPPORTUNITIES, EDUCATION, SOCIAL ACTIVITIES, AND CRAFT CLASSES. THE NEW HANOVER COUNTY SENIOR RESOURCE CENTER ALSO SPONSORS THE SENIOR CORPS FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM, THE RETIRED AND SENIOR VOLUNTEER PROGRAM, SENIOR HEALTH INSURANCE INFORMATION (MEDICARE COUNSELING), INDEPENDENT LIFE SERVICES, CONGREGATE LUNCH NUTRITION PROGRAM AND THE HOME DELIVERED MEAL PROGRAM, VOLUNTEER INCOME TAX ASSISTANCE PROGRAM, AND SENIOR TRANSPORTATION.  THE WORK PLANS FOR THIS GRANT APPLICATION WILL INCLUDE 32 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS. AS STATED IN THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE "INVITATION TO APPLY FOR 2019 QUARTER 4 (YEAR 1 OF A SINGLE OR MULTIYEAR GRANT", WE ARE REQUESTING $160,328. THE NEW HANOVER COUNTY FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM GRANT WILL ADDRESS FOUR PERFORMANCE MEASUREMENTS:
 1. MENTORING IN AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAMS:  10 FGP  VOLUNTEERS WILL MENTOR 15 K-12 STUDENTS IN THREE AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAMS. THE OUTCOME TARGET IS THAT 75% OF THE STUDENTS THAT PARTICIPATE IN THE MENTORING PROGRAM WILL DEMONSTRATE IMPROVED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT AND IMPROVE SOCIAL SKILLS. 
 2. SCHOOL READINESS: 15 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL TUTOR 50 STUDENTS K-6 RESULTING IN IMPROVED ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE IN LITERACY AND OR MATH. THE GOAL IS TO HAVE 75% OF THE CHILDREN PROMOTED TO THE NEXT GRADE LEVEL. 
3. CARING FOR INFANTS: 4 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL NURTURE 3 TO 4 MOTHERS AND THEIR INFANTS WHO ARE RESIDENTS OF THE KELLY HOUSE RESIDENTIAL TREATMENT FACILITY. THIS FACILITY IS A DRUG TREATMENT FACILITY FOCUSING ON SUBSTANCE ABUSE TREATMENT SERVICES.  NEW HANOVER COUNTY IS RANKED AS ONE OF THE TOP CITIES IN THE US FOR OPIOID USE.  THE KELLY HOUSE IS CRITICAL IN PROVIDING SUBSTANCE ABUSE TREATMENT AND SERVING AS A HALFWAY HOUSE OR SOBER LIVING HOME WITH OUTPATIENT CARE TO HELP SUPPORT PREGNANT WOMEN AND POSTPARTUM WOMEN.   THIS FACILITY PROVIDES A PLACE FOR THE MOTHERS AND THEIR VULNERABLE AT-RISK BABIES TO GET REHAB, HEALING, DEVELOPMENT, AND TO REJOIN SOCIETY IN A HEALTHY MANNER.   THE FGP VOLUNTEERS ARE CRITICAL IN HELPING WITH THE PROGRAM BY SUPPORTING THE MOTHERS WITH THE CHILDREN WHILE THEY ARE IN REQUIRED TRAINING AND JOB SEARCHING. MOST BABIES HAVE SPECIAL NEEDS AND REQUIRE SUPPORT TO DEVELOP FINE AND GROSS MOTOR SKILLS DURING THEIR EARLY STAGE OF LIFE.  THE FGP VOLUNTEERS ARE PLACED IN THIS SETTING TO HELP THE MOTHERS WHO MAY NOT BE ABLE TO GIVE THE CHILD THE SUPPORT NEEDED TO DEVELOP AT A NORMAL RATE, BUT MORE IMPORTANTLY THEY ASSIST THE BABIES WITH NURTURE AND WORK ON THEIR MOTOR SKILLS THAT HELPS THEM ACHIEVE THEIR AGE DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES.   WITHOUT THE ATTENTION AND CARING OF THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS THESE CHILDREN MAY NOT REACH THE 75% GOAL OF BEING AT THE NORMAL RATE FOR FINE AND GROSS MOTOR SKILLS. 
4. SCHOOL READINESS: 3 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL ASSIST 5 CHILDREN IN PRESCHOOLS IN GAINING THE SKILLS NEEDED FOR SCHOOL READINESS IN TERMS OF ACADEMIC, SOCIAL, AND/OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT.

FOR THE PAST 52 YEARS MOUNTAIN PROJECTS, INC. CONTINUES TO PROVIDE UNINTERRUPTED SERVICE AS A COMMUNITY BASED NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION. AS A RESULT OF PRESIDENT JOHNSON?S WAR ON POVERTY, MPI WAS FOUNDED IN 1965 PROGRAMS HAVE THAT PROVIDE VITAL SERVICES TO CHILDREN BOTH PRE-SCHOOL AND ELEMENTARY, ACADEMICALLY CHALLENGED, SOCIALLY DELAYED, THE ELDERLY, PHYSICALLY AND MENTALLY DISADVANTAGED AND GENERAL PUBLIC IN WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA.  BY DEMONSTRATING CONSISTENT COMMUNITY SERVICE THAT CHANGES PEOPLE?S LIVES, MOUNTAIN PROJECTS INC., EMBODIES THE SPIRIT OF HOPE, IMPROVES COMMUNITIES, AND MAKES CHEROKEE, CLAY, GRAHAM, HAYWOOD, JACKSON, MACON, AND SWAIN COUNTIES, AS WELL AS THE QUALLA BOUNDARY A BETTER PLACE TO LIVE.  
PARTNERING WITH SEVERAL OTHER NON-PROFIT AGENCIES IN THE COMMUNITY CONTINUES TO BE A MAJOR EMPHASIS OF MOUNTAIN PROJECTS. AS A SPONSORING AGENCY OF FGP, MOUNTAIN PROJECTS CONTINUES TO MATCH VOLUNTEERS WITH MEANINGFUL PLACEMENTS THROUGH THESE COLLABORATIONS WITH VOLUNTEER STATIONS IN THE SEVEN WESTERN COUNTIES OF NC. THE AGENCY SERVES THOUSANDS OF CLIENTS EACH MONTH THROUGH THE 32 GRANTS AND 21 PROGRAMS THAT PROVIDES YEAR-ROUND SERVICES.  THE FIRST GRANT WAS FROM THE OFFICE OF ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY IN THE AMOUNT OF $52,021. CURRENT REVENUES ARE OVER $14,600,000.  VIA A MULTIPLICITY OF PROGRAMS MORE THAN 1800 VOLUNTEERS ARE UTILIZED ON AN ANNUAL BASIS.  
FGP VOLUNTEERS ARE UTILIZED IN CURRENT PROJECT ACTIVITIES WHICH INCLUDE WORKING WITH CHILDREN IN THE HEAD START CLASSROOMS, EARLY CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTERS, ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS, AND OTHER EDUCATION CENTERS.  THESE VOLUNTEERS ASSIST CHILDREN IN AN INTERGENERATIONAL, ONE-ON-ONE ENVIRONMENT BY DEVELOPING METHODOLOGIES THAT HELP CHILDREN GET BACK ON TRACK IN THEIR CLASSROOMS.   VOLUNTEER STATIONS COVER A SEVEN-COUNTY REGION AND GIVE THE VOLUNTEERS MEANINGFUL SERVICE WHILE PROVIDING A POSITIVE IMPACT TO THE AREA.

THE OXFORD-LAFAYETTE COUNTY CHAMBER OF COMMERCE IS A NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION OF BUSINESSES AND INDIVIDUALS DEDICATED TO PRESERVING AND PROMOTING ECONOMIC COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT. THEIR MISSION IS TO UNDERTAKE THOSE PROGRAMS AND PROJECTS WHICH IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR THE OXFORD-LAFAYETTE COUNTY AREA. WE ARE REQUESTING FUNDING FROM CNCS IN THE AMOUT OF $403,402 WITH A TOTAL OF 82 VSY'S.  NON-FEDERAL CONTRIBUTIONS IN THE AMOUNT OF $73,974 WILL BE USED TO MATCH THE GRANT.  THIS GRANT WILL ADDRESS COMMUNITY NEEDS IN THE FOCUS AREA OF EDUCATION. THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING COMMUNITY NEEDS: SERVE AS TUTORS AND MENTORS AT THE TEN (10) ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS WHERE THEY SERVE; IN EACH SCHOOL SYSTEM, MANY STUDENTS ARE READING BELOW GRADE LEVEL AND THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS ARE HELPING TO REALLY MAKE A DIFFERENCE IN THE STUDENTS GAINING THE SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE THEY NEED TO READ AT APPROPRIATE LEVELS; ASSIST HEAD START (2 STATIONS) CHILDREN WITH PRE-READING SKILLS; HELP INDIVIDUALS WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES MAINTAIN OR IMPROVE THEIR SKILL LEVEL. WE RELY ON THE SCHOOLS TESTING METHODS TO PROVIDE THE RESULTS TO THE PROGRAM OF IMPACTS THAT ARE MADE AS WE ADDRESS THE NEEDS OF THE VOLUNTEER STATIONS. THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES ARE: THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL HELP INDIVIDUALS MAINTAIN AND/OR IMPROVE THEIR SKILL LEVEL ON THEIR ISP/IEP ASSESSMENTS; STUDENTS WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN READING READINESS; HEAD START CHILDREN SERVED WILL OBTAIN THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO ACHIEVE THE APPROPRIATE PRE-LITERACY SKILLS NECESSARY FOR SCHOOL AND FEEL NURTURED AND COMFORTED BY THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS.

58 UNDUPLICATED FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS. THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE TUTORING ELEMENTARY SCHOOL AGE STUDENTS IN LITERACY ACTIVITIES IN SAVE THE CHILDREN?S LITERACY PROGRAM, INCLUDING EMERGENT READER MODULES FOR STUDENTS IN K AND 1ST GRADE AND GUIDED INDEPENDENT READING PRACTICE FOR DEVELOPING READERS IN 2ND GRADE AND HIGHER. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, 75% OF THE ESTIMATED 348 STUDENTS WILL MEET THE GOALS SET BY THE NATIONAL EDUCATION TEAM OF SAVE THE CHILDREN THAT INDICATE SIGNIFICANT IMPROVEMENT IN READING. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $348,541 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $34,854 IN NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES.

THE SENIOR CITIZENS COUNCIL OF GREATER AUGUSTA AND THE CSRA, GEORGIA, INC., (THE SCC) IS A PRIVATE NOT-PROFIT, COMMUNITY-BASED, 501 (C) (3) ORGANIZATION SERVING THE 13-COUNTY CENTRAL SAVANNAH RIVER AREA (CSRA), IN GEORGIA. THE MISSION OF THE SCC IS TWO-FOLD?TO PROVIDE A DIVERSITY OF SERVICES TO SENIOR ADULTS AND TO ENABLE THEM TO APPLY THEIR EXPERIENCE AS A RESOURCE FOR MEETING IDENTIFIABLE COMMUNITY NEEDS. THE SCC HAS BEEN A LEADING PROVIDER OF AGING SERVICES SINCE 1968 AND HAS SPONSORED FGP SINCE 1985.
THE SCC IS REQUESTING $333,938 FROM CNCS TO MOBILIZE AN ESTIMATED 97 UNDUPLICATED FGP VOLUNTEERS. WE HAVE APPLIED FOR APPROXIMATELY $94,000 IN NON-FEDERAL FUNDS FROM AUGUSTA-RICHMOND COUNTY AND THE UNITED WAY OF THE CSRA TO AUGMENT CNCS FUNDING. ALTHOUGH CNCS REQUIRED THAT A MINIMUM OF 56 UNDUPLICATED FGP VOLUNTEERS SERVE IN OUTCOME BASED ASSIGNMENTS, WE ANTICIPATE AT LEAST 90 WILL SERVE IN THE STRATEGIC FOCUS AREA OF EDUCATION IN SCHOOL READINESS AND K-12 SUCCESS IN BURKE, COLUMBIA, JEFFERSON, AND RICHMOND COUNTIES. AS THESE ASSIGNMENTS ARE TYPICALLY 9-MONTHS, OVER-ENROLLING TO MEET THE GOAL WILL BE NECESSARY. ADDITIONAL NON-DUPLICATED VOLUNTEERS WILL BE PLACED AT THE FAMILY Y CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTER AND AT HOPE HOUSE. DUPLICATED VOLUNTEERS PLACED IN OTHER COMMUNITY PRIORITIES UNDER SC1 OUTPUTS ONLY, WILL SERVE DURING SCHOOL BREAKS AT MACH ACADEMY, THE CSRA COMMUNITY INITIATIVE, AND THE FAMILY Y ? NORTH JEFFERSON. 
BASED ON TEST SCORES AT THE BEGINNING OF THE ASSIGNMENT AND TEACHER OBSERVATION, STUDENTS WHO ARE IDENTIFIED AS LACKING AGE-APPROPRIATE SOCIAL SKILLS AND THE MATURITY TO ENABLE THEM TO BECOME SUCCESSFUL LEARNERS, STUDENTS THAT ARE AT RISK OF RETENTION BECAUSE THEY LAG BEHIND THEIR PEERS IN GRADE LEVEL SKILLS, NON-TRADITIONAL HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS WORKING TOWARD A GED OR A HIGH SCHOOL DIPLOMA, AND SPECIAL EDUCATION STUDENTS WILL BENEFIT FROM PERSON TO PERSON SUPPORTIVE ASSISTANCE THROUGHOUT THE SCHOOL YEAR. SERVICE ACTIVITIES DESIGNED TO MEET THE ED23A, ED5A, AND H15A OUTCOMES WILL FOCUS ON MEETING ACADEMIC AND SOCIAL NEEDS OF THE ASSIGNED STUDENTS AND MAY INCLUDE ASSISTANCE WITH VOCABULARY AND ORAL AND WRITTEN LANGUAGE EXPRESSION, READING COMPREHENSION, MATHEMATICS, AND MODELING POSITIVE BEHAVIOR.
WORKING WITH THE BOARDS OF EDUCATION IN COLUMBIA, JEFFERSON, AND RICHMOND COUNTIES, COMMUNITIES IN SCHOOLS ? BURKE COUNTY, YOUTH CHALLENGE ACADEMY, AND THE CSRA HEAD START PROGRAM, THIS PROJECT WILL DOCUMENT THE TOTAL NUMBER OF STUDENTS SERVED BY FGP VOLUNTEERS DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR AND REPORT STATION-PROVIDED POST-TEST OUTCOMES ON STUDENT PROGRESS AT THE END OF THE REPORTING PERIOD AS REQUIRED BY CNCS.

THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) COLLABORATES WITH TITLE ONE SCHOOLS, NONPROFIT CHILDCARE CENTERS AND PRESCHOOLS THROUGHOUT THE COUNTY. THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS SCHOOL READINESS AND EDUCATION. AN ESTIMATED FORTY-ONE 
VOLUNTEERS INCLUDING FULL AND PART-TIME FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE CHILDREN THAT ARE UNDERPRIVILEGED, AT RISK FOR ACADEMIC FAILURE AND SOCIALLY CHALLENGED. THE FGP WILL SERVE A MINIMUM OF 15 HOURS IN THE ROLE OF FRIENDSHIP, MENTORING/TUTORING, AND AS A ROLE MODEL WHILE ENCOURAGING SOCIAL/EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT. FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL PROVIDE DIRECT SERVICES TO THE CHILD(REN)'S SPECIFIC NEEDS BY PROVIDING A MINIMUM OF 15 HOURS WEEKLY. FGP WILL WORK ONE ON ONE WITH CHILDREN IN READING, MATH, LANGUAGE ARTS, SHARING MEALS AND ACTIVITIES WHILE CREATING PRODUCTIVE AND POSITIVE CONVERSATIONS.  FGP WILL ALSO HELP WITH MOTOR SKILLS TO INCLUDE, BUT NOT LIMITED TO WALKING, TALKING, AND WRITING. FGP WILL PERFORM THESE DUTIES BY WAY OF ASSISTANCE, ENCOURAGEMENT AND BY DEMONSTRATING AN EXAMPLE OF THE INTENDED GOALS.
THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY A 10% MINIMUM GRANTEE SHARE.

AN ESTIMATED 47 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE.  OF THIS NUMBER ALL OF THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS.  SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE HELPING WITH SCHOOL WORK, POSITIVE ENCOURAGEMENT AND REDIRECTION, MODELING PROPER SOCIAL SKILLS AND ASSISTING WITH COGNITIVE ACTIVITIES.  THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION.  AT THE END OF A THREE-YEAR GRANT OUR GRANDPARENTS WILL HAVE SERVED AT LEAST 150 AT-RISK CHILDREN WITHIN THE SCHOOL SYSTEM.  THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $209,157.00 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED WITH $38,590.00.

OVERVIEW, INC IS THE COMMUNITY ACTION AGENCY FOR A SEVEN COUNTY AREA.  THE MISSION OF OVERVIEW, INC IS TO IDENTIFY PROBLEMS, PROVIDE SERVICES AND OPERATE PROGRAMS IN AN EFFORT TO ENABLE ELDERLY AND ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED CITIZENS TO ACHIEVE SELF-SUFFICIENCY.  THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM CURRENTLY SERVES IN THREE OF THE POVERTY BASED COUNTIES.  BALDWIN, HANCOCK AND PUTNAM COUNTIES ARE THE THREE COUNTIES CURRENTLY BEING SERVED BY THE BENEFICIAL FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM.  WITH THIS NEW GRANT OUR FOCUS AREA WILL BE ENTIRELY ON EDUCATION.  WE WILL PLACE AN ESTIMATED 47 VOLUNTEERS IN AN OUTCOME BASED ASSIGNMENT.  THE VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE AT AN ESTIMATED SEVEN LOCATIONS WITHIN THE THREE COUNTIES WHERE WE HAVE VOLUNTEERS.   WE WILL BE WORKING WITH THE BOARD OF EDUCATION, TEACHERS, MENTORS AND AT-RISK CHILDREN TO ENHANCE K-12 SUCCESS AND PROMOTE GOOD LEARNING SKILLS.  THE HEAD START CENTERS WILL BE USED AS PARTNERS IN THIS VENTURE.  THE OUTCOMES OF EACH CHILD-GRANDPARENT CONNECTION WILL BE MEASURED BY USING DATA IMPACTS AND EVALUATIONS. SOME OF THE DAILY ACTIVITIES THAT THE VOLUNTEERS WILL ENGAGE ARE:  HELPING WITH SCHOOL WORK, POSITIVE ENCOURAGEMENT AND REDIRECTION, MODELING PROPER SOCIAL SKILLS, ASSIST WITH COGNITIVE ACTIVITIES, ETC.  BY THE END OF THE THREE YEAR GRANT PERIOD OUR GRANDPARENTS WILL HAVE SERVED AT LEAST 150 AT-RISK CHILDREN WITHIN THE SCHOOL SYSTEM AND WILL HAVE HELPED THEM SUCCEED AND MOVE ON TO THE NEXT GRADE LEVEL.  IT IS EXPECTED THAT THIS EARLY INTERVENTION WILL CONTINUE TO PROMOTE INCREASES IN THE PERCENT OF CHILDREN DEMONSTRATING GAINS IN K-12 SUCCESS AND EMOTIONAL AND SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT.  THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $209,157.00 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $38,590.00.

AN ESTIMATED 33 FEDERAL UNDUPLICATED FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE. OF THIS NUMBER 33 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS. VOLUNTEERS WILL ASSIST WITH EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES AT EIGHT (8) VOLUNTEER STATIONS SUCH AS SCHOOLS, NON-PROFIT DAYCARES AND OTHER NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS IN CHATHAM COUNTY.  GRANDPARENTS WILL ASSIST WITH COGNITIVE DEVELOPMENT BY TALKING TO CHILDREN ON A LEVEL THEY CAN UNDERSTAND, MODEL AND REINFORCE APPROPRIATE BEHAVIORS AND HELP CHILDREN IDENTIFY OBJECTS, NUMBERS, COLORS AND LETTERS.  FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL HELP CHILDREN IMPROVE THEIR INDIVIDUAL SKILL DEVELOPMENT AND EDUCATIONAL GOALS. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION.  AT THE END OF THE 3 YEAR PERFORMANCE PERIOD IT IS ESTIMATED THE FOLLOWING OUTCOMES WILL BE ACHIEVED: CHILDREN WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS IN TERMS OF SOCIAL AND/OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $191,571 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $41, 255 OF NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES.

MIAMI-DADE COUNTY (MDC), FLORIDA'S ESTIMATED POPULATION IS OVER 2.7 MILLION WITH A GROWTH RATE OF 0.56% IN THE PAST YEAR (ON-LINE HTTP://WORLDPOPULATIONREVIEW.COM/FLORIDA-COUNTIES/MIAMI-DADE-COUNTY/2017). MDC IS THE LARGEST COUNTY IN FLORIDA  THE ETHNIC COMPOSITION OF THE POPULATION OF MDC IS  1.84 MILLION HISPANIC RESIDENTS (67.7%), 437,181 BLACK RESIDENTS (16.1%), 368,048 WHITE RESIDENTS (13.6%), 42,015 ASIAN RESIDENTS (1.55%) AND TWO + RESIDENTS 16,368 (0.6%). WHEN COMPARED TO OTHER PLACES MDC HAS THE LARGEST CONCENTRATION OF THE FOLLOWING LANGUAGES FRENCH CREOLE (112,030 SPEAKERS), SPANISH (1.59 MILLION SPEAKERS) AND HEBREWS (6,122 SPEAKERS) OF THE STATE OF FLORIDA. THE FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF ELDER AFFAIRS (DOEA) 2017 PROFILE FOR OLDER FLORIDIANS IDENTIFIED MDC AS ONE OF THE LARGEST CONCENTRATIONS OF LOW-INCOME MINORITY OLDER ADULTS; OF THIS AMOUNT, 113,483 ELDERS ARE LIVING ALONE AND BELOW THE 125 PERCENTILE POVERTY GUIDELINES. COMMUNITY ACTION AND HUMAN SERVICES DEPARTMENT (CAHSD) IS ONE OF MDC  TWENTY-FIVE DEPARTMENTS, WHICH CURRENTLY SPONSORS THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE (CNCS) SENIOR COMPANION, FOSTER GRANDPARENT, AND RETIRED AND SENIOR VOLUNTEER PROGRAMS THROUGH ELDERLY & DISABILITY SERVICES. THE DEPARTMENT'S MISSION IS TO EMPOWER ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED INDIVIDUALS, FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES THROUGH ADVOCACY, EDUCATION, RESOURCE MOBILIZATION, AND SERVICE DELIVERY. THE DEPARTMENT EXEMPLIFIES ITS MISSION TO THE RESIDENTS OF MDC THROUGH EXCELLENT SERVICE PROVISION AND PUBLIC ASSISTANCE.    THE FGP IS PROPOSING A MANAGEMENT CAPACITY OF SIXTY-ONE VSYS. THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE INVESTMENT OF FEDERAL DOLLARS IN THE AMOUNT OF $282,734 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $208,690 OF MIAMI-DADE COUNTY GENERAL FUND LOCAL DOLLARS TOTALING $491,424 TO PROVIDE COMMUNITY SERVICE AT THIRTY SEVEN (37), PARTNERING ORGANIZATIONS. FGP'S COMMUNITY PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS ARE THE FOLLOWING- SCHOOL BOARD OF MIAMI-DADE COUNTY (PUBLIC SCHOOLS), YWCA,  THE FLORIDA CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION OF AMERICA ,  CENTRO MATER CATHOLIC CHARITIES AND THE HAITIAN YOUTH AND COMMUNITY CENTER OF FLORIDA THE  COLLABORATING PUBLIC OR NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS FOR THIS PROJECT.   THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM WILL ENGAGE 70 VOLUNTEERS IN THE FOLLOWING FOCUS AREA:  EDUCATION AS THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON SCHOOL READINESS AND K-12 SUCCESS.  VOLUNTEERING OPPORTUNITIES IN THESE FOCUS AREAS TARGET OUR COMMUNITY NEEDS TO PROVIDE THE CHILDREN WITH AN OPPORTUNITY TO ESTABLISH AND DEVELOP A MEANINGFUL RELATIONSHIP WITH A FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEER. THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEER IS ABLE TO PROVIDE THE CHILD WITH MORE ONE ON ONE TIME, HENCE ENHANCING THE CHILD'S LEARNING SKILLS IN A NON-THREATENING ENVIRONMENT.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

SPONSOR: THE SOUTH FLORIDA INSTITUTE ON AGING (FORMERLY IMPACT BROWARD)
VISION: A WORLD WHERE EVERYONE THRIVES AS THEY AGE. 

MISSION: "TO IMPROVE SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC INSIGHTS AND SERVICES TO EMPOWER PEOPLE AS THEY AGE."

IN ORDER TO EXPAND OUR SERVICES TO MORE CITIZENS, THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS UNANIMOUSLY VOTED TO CHANGE OUR ORGANIZATION NAME AT THE BOARD MEETING ON NOVEMBER 16, 2017. ON FEBRUARY 2, THE AGENCY REBRANDED AS THE SOUTH FLORIDA INSTITUTE ON AGING OR SOFIA. SOFIA BUILDS ON IMPACT BROWARD AND THE ORGANIZATION WILL EVOLVE INTO A NEW "THINK & ACT TANK" FOCUSING ON ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL RESEARCH, POLICY AND PROGRAMS TO SUPPORT SOUTH FLORIDA'S AGING COMMUNITY. OUR AGENCY WILL FOCUS ON WILL TACKLE THE TOUGHEST SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC ISSUES AND LAUNCH RESEARCH TO DEVELOP POLICY AND RECOMMEND PROGRAMMING. ALSO,DELIVERING FORWARD LOOKING PROGRAMMING TAILORED TO MEET THE NEEDS OF THE AGING COMMUNITY AND COMMITTED TO ENHANCING THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR OLDER PEOPLE.  

THE SOUTH FLORIDA INSTITUTE ON AGING (SOFIA), IS THE PREMIER NON-PROFIT 501(C) (3) ORGANIZATION IN BROWARD COUNTY FOR OLDER ADULTS WHO WANT TO REMAIN ACTIVE, HEALTHY, AND INVOLVED IN THEIR COMMUNITIES BY CONTRIBUTING TIME TO IMPROVE THE LIVES OF OTHERS AND TO MEET THE CRITICAL NEEDS OF THE COMMUNITY. IMPACT BROWARD WAS AWARDED ONE OF THE FIRST FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAMS IN THE COUNTRY IN 1965 AND IS THE PROUD SPONSOR OF THREE SENIOR CORPS PROGRAMS IN BROWARD COUNTY; RETIRED AND SENIOR VOLUNTEER PROGRAM (RSVP), SENIOR COMPANION PROGRAM (SCP) AND THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS PROGRAM (FGP). 
AN ESTIMATED 168 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE A TOTAL OF 672 CHILDREN. SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE READING FOR 30 MINUTES 2-3X'S A WEEK. THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION, K-12 SUCCESS AND ASSISTING IN CLASSROOM-HEAD START. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, STUDENTS WILL HAVE IMPROVED PERFORMANCE IN LITERACY AND OR MATH, AND CHILDREN WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SOCIAL AND/ OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $556,761.00 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY, THE SCHOOL BOARD OF BROWARD COUNTY $170,000, UNITED WAY OF BROWARD $107,050.00, CITY OF HOLLYWOOD CDBG $10,600, AND IN KIND REVENUE AND INTEREST INCOME $2,300. THE PROGRAM HAS ALSO BEEN SUPPLEMENTED BY A.D. HENDERSON FOUNDATION $26,656 BROWARD COUNTY LIBRARIES $34,419.00, THE BATCHELOR FOUNDATION $10,000.00, CORAL SPRINGS COMMUNITY CHEST $1,300.00 IN PREVIOUS YEARS. THE AGENCY IS MONITORED BY UNITED WAY AND OTHER FUNDERS  ANNUALLY AND CONSISTENTLY RECEIVES EXCELLENT EVALUATIONS.  THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT WILL PROVIDE NURTURING ONE -ON -ONE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN THEMSELVES AND THE CHILDREN THEY SERVE, IN TITLE ONE BROWARD COUNTY PUBLIC SCHOOLS (TITLE ONE SCHOOLS ARE ELIGIBLE TO HAVE STUDENTS RECEIVE ADDITIONAL ASSISTANCE IF MORE THAN 50% OF THE STUDENTS AT A PARTICULAR SCHOOL RECEIVE FREE OR SUBSIDIZED MEALS), HEAD START PROGRAMS, VPK PROGRAMS, AND NON -PROFIT EARLY CHILD CARE CENTERS FOR A MINIMUM OF 15 TO A MAXIMUM OF 40 HOURS PER WEEK. 
THIS INTERGENERATIONAL RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT AND THE CHILD PROVIDES A POSITIVE RELATIONSHIP ENABLING ALL CHILDREN TO GROW ACADEMICALLY AND EMOTIONALLY.

THE DR. PIPER CENTER FOR SOCIAL SERVICES, INC. IS A NOT FOR PROFIT 501 [C] (3) SOCIAL SERVICE AGENCY. IT WAS ORIGINALLY FOUNDED AS A NEIGHBORHOOD CENTER CARRYING ON THE IDEALS OF COMMUNITY SERVICE EXEMPLIFIED BY DR. ELLA PIPER, A DISTINGUISHED PHYSICIAN AND COMMUNITY LEADER IN FORT MYERS DURING THE FIRST HALF OF THE TWENTIETH CENTURY.  THE CENTER HAS EXPANDED FROM A NEIGHBORHOOD CENTER TO A MAJOR FIVE COUNTYWIDE PROVIDER OF SERVICES WHILE MAINTAINING ITS NEIGHBORHOOD BASE. A BOARD OF DIRECTORS FROM THE COMMUNITY IS RESPONSIBLE FOR POLICIES AND OVER-ALL SUPERVISION OF THE CENTER. OUR MISSION IS TO ENHANCE THE SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC WELL BEING OF THOSE 55 AND OLDER AND MAKE A POSITIVE IMPACT IN THE LIVES OF CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL NEEDS AND FRAIL ELDERLY CLIENTS. 
THE DR. PIPER CENTER FOR SOCIAL SERVICES HAS BEEN THE LOCAL SPONSOR OF THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM SINCE 1993 AND OUR GOAL IS TO CONTINUE TO ADDRESS THE NEEDS OF LOW-INCOME SENIORS AS WELL AS CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL NEEDS IN LEE, COLLIER, HENDRY, SARASOTA AND CHARLOTTE COUNTIES.  THE PROGRAM PROVIDES A GRATIFYING VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES TO LOW INCOME SENIORS TO MENTOR AND TUTOR CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL NEEDS WHILE AT THE SAME TIME STRENGTHENING THEIR CAPACITY TO REMAIN ACTIVE AND SELF-SUFFICIENT.  THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS THE MOST COST EFFECTIVE PROGRAM TO HELP CHILDREN DEVELOP SKILLS, CONFIDENCE, AND STRENGTH OF CHARACTER TO SUCCEED IN LIFE; AND THEY MAKE THEIR NEIGHBORHOOD STRONGER BY HELPING CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL NEEDS ACHIEVE THEIR GOALS.

THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM SW FLORIDA WILL ADDRESS EDUCATION AS OUR FOCUS AREA. FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL BE ASSIGNED IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS AND AFTER SCHOOL PROGRAMS. ACCORDING TO CITY-DATA.COM, APPROXIMATELY 379,448 CHILDREN UNDER THE AGE OF 18 LIVE IN SW FLORIDA.  15.9% OF HOUSEHOLDS WITH CHILDREN ARE BELOW POVERTY LEVEL. BASED ON THE COMMUNITY DISADVANTAGE INDEX OR CDI, ZIP CODE 33916 WAS IDENTIFIED AS THE MOST DISADVANTAGE IN THE COUNTRY WITH A SCORE OF 10 FOLLOWED BY ZIP CODES 33905 AND 33901 BOTH WITH A SCORE OF 5. WORKING POOR HAVE A RELATIVELY GREATER RISK OF CHILDREN SLIPPING INTO CRIME. FOR FISCAL YEAR 2013-2014 THERE WERE 4,490 YOUTHS REFERRED FOR FELONIES, MISDEMEANORS AND OTHER OFFENSES IN CIRCUIT 20, ACCORDING TO THE FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF JUVENILE JUSTICE. AS PART OF A COMMUNITY ALTERNATIVE TO INSTITUTIONAL CARE, FOSTER GRANDPARENTS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A VERY COST EFFECTIVE COMPONENT IN THE SERVICE PLANS TO ADDRESS THE CHALLENGE OF IMPACTING THE LIVES OF OUR CHILDREN AND YOUTH. AN ESTIMATED 100 UNDUPLICATED VOLUNTEERS WILL WORK IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS PROVIDING ONE ON ONE MENTORING AND TUTORING TO AT LEAST 300 ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED CHILDREN IN 34 ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS IN READING, MATH, WRITING, GRAMMAR, AND COMPREHENSION SKILLS.  ANOTHER TWENTY (20) UNDUPLICATED FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL WORK WITH 100 ECONOMICALLY CHALLENGED CHILDREN THROUGH CURRICULUM BASED AFTER SCHOOL PROGRAMS AND PLANNED ACTIVITIES IN SUMMER PROGRAMS TO PROVIDE A STEADY, CARING, AND HELPFUL PRESENCE AT VARIOUS LOCATIONS, GIVING THESE YOUTH THE EXTRA HOMEWORK HELP THEY NEED.  ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE MODELING AND REINFORCING APPROPRIATE BEHAVIOR; READING AND TELLING STORIES TO CHILDREN; HELPING CHILDREN IDENTIFY OBJECTS, NUMBERS, COLORS, AND LETTERS; ENCOURAGING SELF-HELP SKILLS; AND TALKING WITH AND LISTENING TO CHILDREN THROUGH A NETWORK OF 20 AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS. AT THE END OF THE 12-MONTH PERFORMANCE PERIOD, THE IMPACT WILL SHOW AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF STUDENTS IN MENTORING/TUTORING PROGRAMS WITH IMPROVED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $393,070 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $95,753 OF FUNDING FROM THE COUNTY AND CITY GOVERNMENT, COMMUNITY FOUNDATIONS, UNITED WAY OF LEE COUNTY AND PROCEEDS FROM FUNDRAISING EVENTS.

THE AREA AGENCY ON AGING PALM BEACH/TREASURE COAST, INC. IS A NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION WHICH PROVIDES SERVICES TO SENIORS, ADULTS WITH DISABILITIES AND THOSE WHO CARE FOR THEM IN A FIVE COUNTY AREA. THE AGENCY ADMINISTERS THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM WHICH IS FOCUSED ON SUPPORTING LOW-INCOME POPULATIONS (BOTH SENIOR AND YOUNG) WITHIN GEOGRAPHIC LOCATIONS IN WHICH THERE IS A PRESSING NEED AND PROVIDING SERVICES WITHIN A BEST PRACTICES FRAMEWORK THAT ARE COLLABORATIVE AND INTEGRATED INTO THE FABRIC OF COMMUNITY EFFORTS. THE PROGRAM, WHICH IS A MEMBER IN GOOD STANDING OF THE PALM BEACH COUNTY MENTOR CENTER NETWORK AND SUBSCRIBES TO THE ELEMENTS OF EFFECTIVE PRACTICE FOR MENTORING, PROVIDES OPPORTUNITIES FOR LOW INCOME SENIORS TO IMPROVE EDUCATIONAL OUTCOMES FOR CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL NEEDS THROUGH ONE-ON-ONE MENTORING AND TUTORING.  THIS GRANT REQUEST COVERS THE PERIOD FROM APRIL 1, 2019 THROUGH MARCH 31, 2022. THE PROPOSAL SEEKS FUNDING FOR 160 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS TO SERVE APPROXIMATELY 600 DISADVANTAGED CHILDREN IN FOUR FLORIDA COUNTIES: MARTIN, OKEECHOBEE, PALM BEACH AND ST. LUCIE FOR 20-30 HOURS PER WEEK.  ALL OF THE 160 VOLUNTEERS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME-BASED ASSIGNMENTS WITH THE PRIMARY FOCUS ON EDUCATION. VOLUNTEERS WILL PROVIDE SERVICES IN APPROXIMATELY 50 PRE-KINDERGARTEN CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTERS, HEAD STARTS AND ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS TO CONTRIBUTE TO SCHOOL READINESS FOR THE ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED CHILDREN AND PROVIDE SUPPORT THAT IMPROVES SCHOOL SUCCESS IN ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE AND ENGAGEMENT OUTCOMES FOR KINDERGARTEN THROUGH GRADE 3.  THE ONE-TO-ONE MENTORING AND TUTORING WILL HAVE AN EMPHASIS ON DEVELOPING SOCIAL SKILLS, BEHAVIOR MODIFICATION AND LITERACY.  BASED ON PREVIOUS OUTCOMES, WE ANTICIPATE THAT BY THE END OF THE SCHOOL YEAR, A MINIMUM OF 75% OF CHILDREN WILL DEMONSTRATE IMPROVEMENT IN IDENTIFIED NEEDS - ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT, LITERACY AND/OR MATH WITH IMPROVED BEHAVIORAL AND/OR SOCIAL SKILLS.  THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $554,175 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY A 29% MATCH OF NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES.

THE ALACHUA COUNTY BOARD OF COUNTY COMMISSIONERS (BOCC) HAS SUCCESSFULLY SPONSORED THE ALACHUA COUNTY FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) FOR 45 YEARS. BOCC IS THE GOVERNING BODY FOR ALACHUA COUNTY GOVERNMENT AND IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ESTABLISHING POLICIES, ENACTING LAWS, AND SETTING THE COUNTY'S BUDGET. BOCC CONTINUES TO SET THE NEEDS OF CHILDREN AND SENIORS AS A FUNDING PRIORITY. THE PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF FUNDING DERIVED FROM CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $393,351.00 AND NON-FEDERAL SHARE OF $113, 833.00 DERIVED FROM THE SPONSOR (BOCC) AND IN-KIND CONTRIBUTIONS. 

EDUCATION IS THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THE FGP WITH SERVICE ACTIVITIES TARGETED TO ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED AND/OR SPECIAL OR EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS CHILDREN IN PRE-SCHOOLS, ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS, HEAD START, EARLY CHILDHOOD CENTERS, AND AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAMS. SIXTY-SIX (66) UNDUPLICATED VOLUNTEERS WILL PROVIDE TUTORING AND INSTRUCTIONAL ACTIVITIES FOCUSED ON IMPROVING LITERACY AND MATH SKILLS, ASSIST CHILDREN WITH CLASS AND HOMEWORK COMPLETION, AND INTERACT WITH STUDENTS HELPING THEM IN THE AREAS OF SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT. VOLUNTEERS ASSISTING CHILDREN IN SCHOOL READINESS PROGRAMS WILL HELP STUDENTS REACH THEIR DEVELOPMENTAL GOALS BY FOCUSING ON ACTIVITIES SUCH AS COUNTING, NUMBER AND LETTER RECOGNITION, HAND AND EYE COORDINATION (TRACING), COLORING, CUTTING EXERCISES, AND REINFORCING PERSONAL HYGIENE PRACTICES. VOLUNTEERS WILL ENGAGE CHILDREN THROUGH INTERACTIVE PLAY, SINGING, READING ALOUD AND BUILDING COMMUNICATION SKILLS BY SOUND RECOGNITION. VOLUNTEERS SERVING IN AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAMS AS MENTORS AND POSITIVE ROLE MODELS WILL ASSIST STUDENTS WITH HOMEWORK COMPLETION WHILE ENCOURAGING A POSITIVE ATTITUDE TOWARD LEARNING. VOLUNTEERS WILL HELP CHILDREN ESTABLISH HEALTHY RELATIONSHIPS AND POSITIVE ENGAGEMENT IN EDUCATIONAL, SOCIAL AND RECREATIONAL ACTIVITIES, AND ASSIST WITH SCHOOLWORK, ARTS AND CRAFTS, AND TECHNOLOGY.

AT THE END OF THE 36 MONTH PERFORMANCE PERIOD, ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES WILL INCLUDE: ELEMENTARY STUDENTS WILL DEMONSTRATE A MARKED IMPROVEMENT IN LITERACY AND/OR MATH; CHILDREN SERVED IN HEAD START AND EARLY CHILDHOOD CENTERS WILL SHOW IMPROVEMENT IN LITERACY SKILLS PREPARING THEM FOR ENTRY INTO KINDERGARTEN OR ADVANCEMENT TO THE NEXT LEVEL; AND AFTERSCHOOL PARTICIPANTS WILL DEMONSTRATE IMPROVED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT AND PERFORMANCE. 

FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL PROVIDE THESE ACTIVITIES THROUGH AN EXTENSIVE AND GROWING NETWORK OF 35 VOLUNTEER STATIONS DEVELOPED THROUGH COLLABORATION WITH ALACHUA COUNTY PUBLIC SCHOOLS, THE EARLY LEARNING COALITION, AND OTHER EDUCATIONAL PROVIDERS.

ELDER CARE SERVICES' FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM ANTICIPATES AT LEAST 107 VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE THROUGHOUT OUR 15-COUNTY SERVICE AREA OF FLORIDA (BAY, CALHOUN, FRANKLIN, GADSDEN, GULF, HOLMES, JACKSON, JEFFERSON, LEON, LIBERTY, MADISON, TAYLOR, WALTON, WAKULLA, AND WASHINGTON COUNTIES). OF THIS NUMBER, 100 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS. THESE VOLUNTEERS WILL BE SERVING IN SUPPORT OF THE SENIOR CORPS SCHOOL READINESS AND K-12 SUCCESS PERFORMANCE MEASURE OBJECTIVES. FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEER ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ASSISTING IN CLASSROOMS AND TUTORING PUBLIC SCHOOL CHILDREN WHO ARE ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED WITH SPECIAL OR EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, WE ANTICIPATE ASSISTING AT LEAST 200 ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED CHILDREN AND/OR CHILDREN WHO HAVE SPECIAL OR EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $523,923.75 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $$58,456.80 IN NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES.

AS A NATIONAL SERVICE PROGRAM FOR AMERICANS 55 YEARS AND OLDER, THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) MISSION IS SIMPLE AND DIRECT; TO EMPOWER LOW TO MODERATE-INCOME INDIVIDUALS THE OPPORTUNITY TO TUTOR AND MENTOR CHILDREN AND YOUTH WITH SPECIAL OR EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS. ESTABLISHED IN 1980, THE FGP HELPS ENHANCE THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR CITIZENS OF MOBILE COUNTY. EVEN NOW, THE MOBILE COUNTY COMMISSION IS A LEADING CATALYST FOR FGP. VOLUNTEERS SERVE AN AVERAGE OF 5-40 HOURS PER WEEK IN SCHOOLS, HEAD START, HOSPITALS, AND CHILD CARE CENTERS.  THEY REVIEW SCHOOLWORK, REINFORCE VALUES, TEACH PARENTING SKILLS, HELP THOSE WITH LIMITED ENGLISH AND CARE FOR CHILDREN WITH PHYSICAL CHALLENGES.

ACCORDING TO ALABAMA POPULATION CENSUS 2019, MOBILE COUNTY'S ESTIMATED POPULATION IS 413,955. WHEN COMPARED TO THE REST OF THE STATE, MOBILE IS THE THIRD MOST POPULOUS IN ALABAMA. THE CITY IS MOST KNOWN FOR BEING THE ONLY SALTWATER PORT IN THE STATE. THE PORT OF MOBILE HAS CONTRIBUTED SIGNIFICANTLY TO THE CITY'S ECONOMY THROUGHOUT ITS HISTORY. MOBILE'S POPULATION IS PREDOMINANTLY BLACK, WITH THIS RACE MAKING UP 50.6% OF THE TOTAL POPULATION. FORTY-FIVE PERCENT OF THE POPULATION IS WHITE, 1.8% IS ASIAN, 1.4% IS MIXED, AND 2.4% ARE OF HISPANIC OR LATINO ORIGIN. NATIVE AMERICANS AND OTHER RACES EACH MAKE UP LESS THAN 1% OF THE TOTAL POPULATION.  15.5% OF THE POPULATION IS OVER THE AGE OF 65 YEARS, AND JUST 22% OF THE POPULATION IS 18 YEARS OR UNDER.

ALABAMA'S STATE DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION "2020 STRATEGIC PLAN" ENVISIONS EVERY CHILD A GRADUATE AND EVERY GRADUATE PREPARED. THE COUNTY'S PUBLIC SCHOOL SYSTEM IS THE LARGEST SCHOOL DISTRICT IN THE STATE WITH 57,910 STUDENTS ENROLLED. IN THE 2017-2018 ACADEMIC YEAR, THE GRADUATION RATE IN MOBILE COUNTY WAS 86%. DURING THE SAME YEAR, THE STATE DEPARTMENT FOUND TWELVE FAILING SCHOOLS IN MOBILE COUNTY.  OF THE TWELVE FAILING SCHOOLS THE FGP ARE PARTNERS TO FIVE. HEAD START'S PRESCHOOL PROGRAM ENROLLS 1,223 CHILDREN.  FGP ARE PARTNERS TO FOUR HEAD START CENTERS.  FOSTER GRANDPARENTS REAP THE BENEFITS OF FEELING A PERSONAL SENSE OF ACCOMPLISHMENT WHILE SUPPORTING STUDENTS AND CHILDREN AS THEY PREPARE TO ACHIEVE SCHOOL READINESS AND K-12 SUCCESS.

AN AUGMENTATION OF $133,740 IN LOCAL AND STATE-MATCHED FUNDS WILL SUPPORT THE CNCS INVESTMENT OF $361,978, TO PAIR EIGHTY ADULTS TO CHILDREN AND STUDENTS IN NEED OF ACADEMIC SUPPORT. THROUGH EXCEPTIONAL PROGRAM MANAGEMENT, DEDICATION AND HARD WORK THE FGP OF MOBILE COUNTY REMAINS COMMITTED TO IMPROVING LIVES, STRENGTHENING COMMUNITIES, AND FOSTERING CIVIC ENGAGEMENT THROUGH SERVICE AND VOLUNTEERING.

AN ESTIMATED, 72 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE. OF THIS NUMBER, 61 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS. SOME OF THE ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE: ASSISTING WITH COGNITIVE ACTIVITIES, SOCIAL SKILLS, COMMUNICATION SKILLS, READING SKILLS, ASSISTING WITH SCHOOL WORK, AND OFFERING POSITIVE ENCOURAGEMENT. THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, THE EXPECTED OUTCOME FOR CHILDREN SERVED WILL SHOW AN INCREASE IN COGNITIVE SKILLS (LEARNING AND THINKING), LANGUAGE AND SPEECH, SOCIAL SKILLS (FRIENDSHIP, TEAMWORK, AND RESPECT), READING SKILLS, SELF-HELP, AND CONFLICT RESOLUTION. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $364,875 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY SOUTHEAST ALABAMA COMMUNITY ACTION PARTNERSHIP (SEACAP) IN THE AMOUNT OF $79,012.

COMMUNITY ACTION PARTNERSHIP OF NORTH ALABAMA (THE PARTNERSHIP) HAS SPONSORED THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM FOR NEARLY 30 YEARS. THE PARTNERSHIP HAS BUILT A CORE OF PARTNERSHIPS WITH AGENCIES LIKE AREA AGENCY ON AGING, LOCAL COUNTY AND CITY SCHOOL DISTRICTS, HOSPITALS, AND SENIOR CENTERS. AN ESTIMATED 66 VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE IN MORGAN, CULLMAN, AND LAWRENCE, ALL OF WHICH ARE CONSIDERED RURAL COUNTIES WITH GROWING AGING AND DISABLED POPULATIONS.

BASED ON COMMUNITY NEEDS, THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM LOOKS FOR PARTNERSHIPS AND OPPORTUNITIES WITH MEASURABLE OUTCOMES IN THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF EDUCATION. IDENTIFYING COMMUNITY NEEDS ALLOW OLDER ADULT VOLUNTEERS TO GIVE BACK TO THEIR COMMUNITIES; PROVIDING ACTIVE OLDER ADULTS A WAY TO COMBAT UNMET NEEDS AND TO HELP BUILD THE CAPACITY OF PARTNERS IN PROVIDING EDUCATION TO LOCAL STUDENTS.

AN ESTIMATED 66 FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE EACH YEAR IN THE PROGRAM. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL PROVIDE THROUGH A NETWORK OF 9 VOLUNTEER STATIONS: ONE-ON-ONE TUTORING ASSISTANCE IN LITERACY AND OR MATH SKILLS AND SCHOOL READINESS. PARTNERING VOLUNTEER STATIONS INCLUDE PUBLIC SCHOOLS, FAITH-BASED SCHOOLS AND ALTERNATIVE SCHOOLS IN MORGAN, LAWRENCE, AND CULLMAN COUNTIES. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS K-12 SUCCESS AND SCHOOL READINESS. 
AT THE END OF THE 12-MONTH PERFORMANCE PERIOD, IT IS PROJECTED THAT 100 CHILDREN WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN LITERACY SKILLS. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $287,929 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY ADDITIONAL FUNDING FOR A TOTAL OF $302, 325.

EAST ALABAMA SERVICES FOR THE ELDERLY, INC. HAS SERVED AS THE SPONSOR AGENCY FOR THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) SINCE 1981 AND IS APPLYING FOR RENEWAL OF APPLICATION OF SPONSORSHIP FOR FGP. THE MISSION THE EASE-FOSTER GRANDPARENTS PROGRAM IS TO PROVIDE VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES FOR INDIVIDUALS AGES 55 AND OLDER REGARDLESS OF EDUCATIONAL AND/OR SOCIAL BACKGROUND TO SERVE CHILDREN WHO HAVE SPECIAL OR EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS, OR WHO WOULD BENEFIT FROM THE ONE-TO-ONE ATTENTION PROVIDED, ESPECIALLY CHILDREN OF MILITARY FAMILIES OR VETERANS, FOSTER GRANDPARENT'S PRIMARY FOCUS AREA WILL BE EDUCATION WITH EMPHASIS IN SCHOOL READINESS AND K-12 SUCCESS.

AN ESTIMATED 60 UNDUPLICATED FGP VOLUNTEER WILL SERVE WITHIN THE GEOGRAPHICAL LOCATION OF LEE & RUSSELL COUNITES: AUBURN, OPELIKA, SMITHS LOCATED IN LEE COUNTY; HURTSBORO, FORT MITCHELL, SEALE, PHENIX CITY LOCATED IN RUSSELL COUNTY. FORTY-EIGHT VOLUNTEERS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS. VOLUNTEERS WILL ENGAGE APPROXIMATELY 250 CHILDREN IN ONE-TO-ONE OR GROUP DIRECTION/INSTRUCTION AND MENTORING ACTIVITIES TO HELP THE CHILDREN DEVELOP EMOTIONALLY, SOCIALLY AND ACADEMICALLY IN THE CLASSROOM SETTINGS. AT THE END OF THE 3-YEAR GRANT CYCLE 86% OF THE IDENTIFIED CHILDREN RECEIVING SERVICES OF THE FGS WILL COMPLETE THE PROGRAM OF STUDY WITH IMPROVED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT. VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE IN 3 DAY CARES/EARLY LEARNING, 3 PRE-K SCHOOLS, 3 HEAD STARTS, 8 ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS, 1 MIDDLE SCHOOL AND 2 RECREATIONAL CENTERS FOR A TOTAL OF 20 STATIONS RECEIVING TUTORING/MENTORING SERVICES IN THE AREAS OF SOCIAL, EMOTIONAL, DEVELOPMENT, LITERACY AND MATH.

CNCS INVESTMENT OF $285,755.00 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $32,306 IN MATCHING FUNDS.

IN JUNE OF 1974, THE CITY OF RUSSELLVILLE WAS FUNDED BY THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE FOR THIS FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP), WHICH COVERS FIVE COUNTIES IN ALABAMA:  COLBERT, FRANKLIN, LAUDERDALE, MARION, AND WINSTON.  

OUR FUNDING SOURCES INCLUDE $331,213 FROM THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE, $12,711.28 FROM THE STATE OF ALABAMA, $22,349 FROM CITY AND COUNTY MULTIPLICITIES, $28,993.00 FROM IN-KIND CONTRIBUTIONS, AND $3,128.00 FROM FUND RAISING EVENTS/DONATIONS/GRANTS.  

WE CURRENTLY HAVE 62 FGP SENIOR CITIZENS VOLUNTEERS WHO MENTOR AND TUTOR IN ONE-ON-ONE SITUATIONS WITH SPECIAL AND EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS CHILDREN DURING A 12-MONTH PERIOD.  THEY DO VOLUNTEER WORK IN 14 SCHOOLS, 2 HEAD START PROGRAMS, 1 COURT ORDERED SCHOOL FOR JUVENILE DELINQUENTS, 4 DAYCARE CENTERS, 2 PRE-K CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTERS, 3 AFTER SCHOOL TUTORING PROGRAMS, 1 REHABILITATION CENTER, AND 1 PARK AND RECREATION CENTERS. 

THE CITY OF RUSSELLVILLE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS AN IMPORTANT PART OF THE COMMUNITIES WE SERVE.  ITS AIM IS TO SERVE SENIOR CITIZENS 55 AND OLDER AND SPECIAL AND EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS CHILDREN IN OUR AREA WITH A PRIMARY FOCUS IN EDUCATION (SCHOOL READINESS AND K-12 SUCCESS).  FGP VOLUNTEERS GAIN A SENSE OF PRIDE AND ACCOMPLISHMENT, STAY ACTIVE IN THE COMMUNITY, EXTEND THEIR LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES, AND GAIN SELF-WORTH WHILE MENTORING AND TUTORING THESE CHILDREN.  AT THE SAME TIME, THE CHILDREN GAIN CONFIDENCE IN SOCIAL AND/OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT, LITERACY AND/OR MATH SKILLS, ENHANCED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT, AND THE FEELING OF BEING LOVED AND ACCEPTED BY THE FGP VOLUNTEER

POSITIVE MATURITY, INC. (PM), IS A 501 (C )3 ORGANIZATION WHOSE MISSION HAS BEEN TO ENHANCE THE LIVES OF MATURE ADULTS THROUGH CIVIC ENGAGEMENT AND SOCIAL SERVICES SINCE 1972. POSITIVE MATURITY, INC. OFFERS 6 PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO KEEP SENIORS IN JEFFERSON, SHELBY, WALKER AND BLOUNT COUNTIES ACTIVELY ENGAGED AND INDEPENDENT FOR AS LONG AS POSSIBLE. AS A CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE SPONSOR, POSITIVE MATURITY, INC. HOUSES THE 3 SENIOR CORPS PROGRAMS, RSVP, SENIOR COMPANION PROGRAM, FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM, AND ONE VISTA PROGRAM. POSITIVE MATURITY IS RESPECTFULLY REQUESTING $290,067 FROM CNCS. IN ADDITION TO THE CNCS FUNDING, POSITIVE MATURITY, INC. WILL SECURE SUPPLEMENTAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $44,117 FROM UNITED WAY OF CENTRAL ALABAMA, OTHER LOCAL, COUNTY AND STATE (NON-FEDERAL) RESOURCES AND THROUGH GENEROUS DONATIONS MADE BY THE COMMUNITY AT LARGE. THROUGH THIS GENEROUS FUNDING, PM WILL BE ABLE TO SUPPORT AN ANTICIPATED 66 FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) VOLUNTEERS OVER THE NEXT YEAR. OUR FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL ADDRESS COMMUNITY NEEDS THROUGH "IMPACT VOLUNTEERING" WITH A PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF EDUCATION. VOLUNTEERS WILL ADDRESS THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA BY PROVIDING 1:1 TUTORING, MENTORING, DAILY LIFE SKILLS AND COMPANIONSHIP AT A VARIETY OF DAYCARE, HEAD START PROGRAMS, SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITY PROGRAMS THAT SERVE "AT-RISK" YOUTH.
FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM VOLUNTEERS IN HEAD START AND DAYCARE PROGRAMS WILL ASSIST CHILDREN BY PROVIDING 1:1 INSTRUCTION ON DAILY LIFE SKILLS (WASHING HANDS, TYING SHOES, BUTTONING, ETC) AS WELL AS SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT SKILLS (TAKING TURNS, GREETINGS, ASKING PERMISSION, GETTING ALONG WITH OTHERS, ETC). THESE SKILLS HELP TO PROVIDE A FOUNDATION FOR IMPROVED ACADEMIC SUCCESS.  THEY WILL ALSO PREPARE CHILDREN FOR THEIR UPCOMING ACADEMICS BY WORKING 1:1 WITH THEM ON NUMBERS, LETTERS, AND COLORS. 
FGP VOLUNTEERS IN THE ELEMENTARY SCHOOL SYSTEMS WILL WORK WITH CHILDREN WHO HAVE ENTERED SCHOOL BEHIND ACADEMICALLY OR ARE FAILING TO KEEP UP WITH THE CLASSROOM ASSIGNMENTS BY PROVIDING 1:1 TUTORING IN AREAS SUCH AS MATH AND READING.  THEY WILL ALSO WORK WITH CHILDREN WHO ARE DEFINED AS "AT-RISK" DUE TO ENGLISH BEING A SECOND LANGUAGE BY PROVIDING 1:1 TIME WORKING ON LANGUAGE SKILLS. 
FGP VOLUNTEERS ASSIGNED TO JACKSON OLIN HIGH SCHOOL WILL HELP STUDENTS ENROLLED IN THE YOUNG MOTHER'S PROGRAM REACH THEIR ACADEMIC SUCCESS BY PROVIDING SUPERVISION AND CARE OF THEIR INFANTS WHILE THEY ATTEND SCHOOL.  FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL ALSO WORK WITH HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS WHO ARE CURRENTLY INCARCERATED AT THE LOCAL JUVENILE DETENTION CENTER PROVIDING MENTORING AND TUTORING AS THEY SERVE OUT THEIR SENTENCE.
THROUGHOUT THE NEXT THREE YEARS, POSITIVE MATURITY, INC AND THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM WILL STRIVE TO WORK WITH SENIORS WHO ARE VETERANS AND MILITARY FAMILIES THROUGH THEIR VOLUNTEER RECRUITMENT. BY MATCHING YOUTH WITH THOSE WHO HAVE SERVED OUR COUNTRY, WE CAN ASSIST IN INTER-GENERATIONAL LEARNING AND APPRECIATION OF OUR HEROES.   
THROUGHOUT THE NEXT THREE YEARS, POSITIVE MATURITY AND THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM ANTICIPATES 198 VOLUNTEERS SERVING OVER 200 CHILDREN TO ENSURE THEY HAVE THE TOOLS AND ATTENTION NEEDED FOR THEIR ACADEMIC SUCCESS.

THE AGING, DISABILITY AND VETERANS SERVICES DIVISION OF MULTNOMAH COUNTY PROMOTES INDEPENDENCE, DIGNITY AND CHOICE IN THE LIVES OF OLDER ADULTS, PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES AND VETERANS. SPONSORING THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) HAS BEEN A SOURCE OF PRIDE FOR OUR DIVISION AND IS A PROGRAM THAT CLEARLY EXEMPLIFIES OUR VALUES. AN ESTIMATED 45 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE ACROSS CLACKAMAS, WASHINGTON AND MULTNOMAH COUNTIES. OF THIS NUMBER 45 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS. SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ASSISTING IN K-12 CLASSROOMS, ASSISTING IN HEAD START CLASSROOMS, TUTORING IN K-12 CLASSROOMS AND TUTORING IN COMMUNITY-BASED SETTINGS SUCH AS BOYS & GIRLS CLUB AND SUN AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS, AND COMMUNITY-BASED MENTORING. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION WITH OBJECTIVES IN BOTH SCHOOL READINESS AND K-12 SUCCESS. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, WE WILL BE ABLE TO DEMONSTRATE THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN DEMONSTRATING GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS IN TERMS OF SOCIAL AND/OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND THE NUMBER OF STUDENTS IN GRADES K-12 THAT PARTICIPATED IN THE MENTORING OR TUTORING OR OTHER EDUCATION PROGRAM, INCLUDING CNCS-SUPPORTED SERVICE LEARNING, WHO DEMONSTRATED IMPROVED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT. EACH FGP VOLUNTEER WILL BE MATCHED WITH A MINIMUM OF FOUR CHILDREN TO SERVE A TOTAL OF 180 CHILDREN. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $243,653 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $24,365.

IN THE THIRD YEAR OF THIS GRANT, AN ESTIMATED 62 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE 310 YOUTH THROUGH A VARIETY OF ACTIVITIES; ALL SERVICE WILL OCCUR IN THE FOCUS AREA OF EDUCATION. THE VOLUNTEERS' ACTIVITIES WILL BE MEASURED WITH THE EXPECTATION THAT THE YOUTH WILL SHOW IMPROVED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT OR SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL SKILLS, OR GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS. THE YOUTH OF JACKSON, JOSEPHINE AND KLAMATH COUNTIES WILL BE SERVED BY FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS AT APPROXIMATELY 43 LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS, AMONG THOSE INCLUDE LOCAL ELEMENTARY AND CHARTER SCHOOLS, HEAD START CENTERS, AND EARLY LEARNING CENTERS. ADDITIONALLY LOCAL BRANCHES OF THE LIBRARY SYSTEMS, THE YMCA, THE FAMILY NURTURING CENTER, HEARTS WITH A MISSION HOMELESS SHELTER AND ONTRACK'S HOME PROGRAM, WILL BE SERVED BY FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $333,165 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $96,614 IN CASH AND IN-KIND SUPPORT.

THE SPONSOR FOR THE EASTERN AND CENTRAL OREGON FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (EO-CO FGP) IS COMMUNITY COUNSELING SOLUTIONS (CCS), A 501(C)(3) CORPORATION PROVIDING MENTAL HEALTH AND RELATED SERVICES. CCS HAS 150 EMPLOYEES AND ITS MISSION IS TO PROVIDE DYNAMIC, PROGRESSIVE, AND DIVERSE SUPPORTS TO IMPROVE THE WELL-BEING OF OUR COMMUNITIES. CCS IS REQUESTING $319,354.35 IN FEDERAL FUNDING FOR THE EO-CO FGP PROGRAM AND PROPOSES TO SUPPLEMENT THESE FEDERAL FUNDS WITH AN ADDITIONAL $35,510 IN NON-FEDERAL CASH AND IN-KIND SUPPORT.

JOHN BRENNE, LONG-TIME FGP AND SCP PROJECT DIRECTOR FROM 1975 TO 2018, PASSED AWAY SUDDENLY ON JANUARY 22, 2018.  HE HAS SINCE BEEN REPLACED BY TERESA E. O?HALLORAN, WHO BRINGS NEW PERSPECTIVE AND ORGANIZATION TO THE PROGRAM.  ROBERT BURDETT REMAINS THE PROJECT ASSISTANT AND A VITAL PART OF THE PROGRAM PROVIDING ORIENTATION TO THE NEW PROJECT DIRECTOR.

IN THE UPCOMING PROGRAM YEAR, WE PROPOSE A REDUCTION IN VSYS DUE TO THESE UNEXPECTED CHANGES. BY REDUCING OUR VSYS TO 53 IT WILL ALLOW THE FLEXIBILITY NEEDED TO REORGANIZE AND SOLIDIFY THE PROGRAM UNDER NEW PROJECT LEADERSHIP.  WE ANTICIPATE THE EO-CO FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE APPROXIMATELY 55,332 HOURS DURING THE 2019-20 PROGRAM YEAR.  CCS CURRENTLY HAS OVER 30 EO-CO FGP VOLUNTEER STATIONS IN BAKER, MALHEUR, MORROW, UNION, HARNEY, UMATILLA, CROOK, DESCHUTES, JEFFERSON, AND WASCO COUNTIES. VOLUNTEER STATION TYPES INCLUDE BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SCHOOLS AS WELL AS HEAD START AND A VARIETY OF AFTERSCHOOL OR SUMMER PROGRAMS.  THE EO-CO FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL PROVIDE SERVICE TO 560 STUDENTS WITH AN ESTIMATED 55 VOLUNTEERS (53 VSYS).

THE EO-CO FGP PROGRAM OF CCS IS WELL ESTABLISHED IN THE AREA IT SERVES. WE CONTINUE TO REACH OUT TO ESTABLISH MORE MEMORANDUMS OF UNDERSTANDING WITH SCHOOLS IN OUR SERVICE AREA WHILE AT THE SAME TIME STRENGTHENING EXISTING ONES.  WE EXPECT TO RECRUIT MORE FGP VOLUNTEERS IN THE EASTERN AND CENTRAL OREGON AREAS IN ORDER TO STABILIZE AND ACHIEVE OUR VSY GOAL.

THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA FOR THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION WITH THE OBJECTIVES OF SCHOOL READINESS AND K-12 SUCCESS.  THE SERVICE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE TUTORING / SUMMER LEARNING.

OREGON DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION (ODE) TESTING RECORDS FOR THE SCHOOL YEAR 2017-18 SHOW THERE ARE 580,684 REGISTERED STUDENTS IN THE STATE.  OF THESE STUDENTS, 261,637 ARE IN ELEMENTARY SCHOOL.  53% OF ALL STUDENTS IN GRADE 3 DO NOT MEET OR EXCEED GRADE LEVEL FOR ENGLISH, AND 54% OF ALL STUDENTS IN GRADE 3 FALL SHORT OF THE LEVEL FOR MATHEMATICS.  48.6 % OF STUDENTS IN GRADES 3-5 DO NOT MEET STATE GRADE-LEVEL EXPECTATIONS FOR ENGLISH LANGUAGE ARTS.  FOR STUDENTS IN GRADES 6-8, THE NUMBER IS 44.8% WHO DO NOT MEET THE STANDARD FOR LITERACY.  THE NUMBERS FOR MATHEMATICS ARE ALSO WORRISOME - 56.4% OF STUDENTS IN GRADES 3-5 DO NOT MEET STATE GRADE-LEVEL EXPECTATIONS FOR MATHEMATICS.  FOR STUDENTS IN GRADES 6-8, 59% FAIL TO MEET STANDARD IN MATHEMATICS.  (SOURCE: OREGON DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION WEBSITE)

SEVERAL FACTORS CONTRIBUTE TO POOR READING LEVELS, INCLUDING LACK OF PARENTAL INVOLVEMENT, LACK OF ONE-TO-ONE ASSISTANCE, CLASS SIZE, AND POVERTY.  53% OF ALL OREGON ELEMENTARY SCHOOL STUDENTS ARE ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE FREE AND REDUCED-PRICE LUNCH.  2015 FIGURES FROM THE ODE SHOW FREE/REDUCED ELIGIBILITY PERCENTAGES OF 50.3% FOR SCHOOLS IN DESCHUTES COUNTY (12,652 STUDENTS); 54.1% FOR CROOK COUNTY (1,751 STUDENTS); 60.7% FOR JEFFERSON COUNTY (2,241); AND 64.8% FOR WASCO COUNTY SCHOOLS (2,333 STUDENTS).  EASTERN OREGON STUDENTS HAVE EQUALLY HIGH NUMBERS.

VOLUNTEER SERVICE ACTIVITIES ARE ALL SCHOOL-BASED, AND INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING ELEMENTS:
1.	ONE-TO-ONE TUTORING WITH SPECIAL NEEDS SCHOOL CHILDREN WHO HAVE BEEN DESIGNATED BY A TEACHING PROFESSIONAL AS NEEDING EXTRA HELP TO BE A SUCCESSFUL STUDENT.  THE EO-CO FGP VOLUNTEER NURTURES THE STUDENT, ACTS AS A ROLE MODEL, AND PROVIDES SPECIFIC HELP WITH READING, MATH AND BY DEFAULT BECOME THEIR SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL SUPPORT.  45 OF OUR 55 VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE IN ELEMEN

AN ESTIMATED 38 UNDUPLICATED FG VOLUNTEERS, 37 FEDERAL AND ONE SPONSOR FUNDED,  WILL SERVE IN K-12 AND SCHOOL READINESS OUTCOME-BASED ASSIGNMENTS TO ADDRESS THESE NEEDS THROUGH TUTORING, MENTORING, CLASSROOM SUPPORT, AND SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL SUPPORT.  AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, 240 YOUTH WILL HAVE IMPROVED TARGETED LEVELS. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $224,950 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $24,995 OF NON-FEDERAL SPONSOR MATCH THAT INCLUDES A SPONSOR FUNDED VSY.  
FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE AS TUTORS/MENTORS IN SCHOOLS, NON-PROFIT DAY CARE CENTERS, HEAD START CENTERS AND EXTENDED TIME PROGRAMS THAT SERVE AT-RISK YOUTH THROUGH AFTER SCHOOL/SUMMER PROGRAMS. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE HELPING WITH CLASSROOM ASSIGNMENTS, READING WITH CHILDREN, AND PROVIDING ENCOURAGEMENT AND SUPPORT. THE PRIMARY FOCUS IS TO IMPROVE SCHOOL READINESS AND K-12 SUCCESS FOR STUDENTS WHO ARE TESTING BELOW GRADE LEVEL OR WHO ARE IDENTIFIED BY SITE STAFF AS BEING AT RISK. ACCORDING TO KRISTA HERTZ, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR OF THE EDUCATION FOUNDATION FOR BILLINGS PUBLIC SCHOOLS, ?FG VOLUNTEERS ARE A VALUABLE COMMUNITY RESOURCE TO THE CLASSROOMS. PROVIDING MUCH NEEDED ASSISTANCE TO STRUGGLING STUDENTS, FGS BECOME PART OF AN INTERVENTION PLAN FOR STRUGGLING STUDENTS, HELPING TO FILL IN THE EDUCATION GAPS. WITHOUT THAT EXTRA HELP, STUDENTS ARE AT RISK OF FALLING EVEN FURTHER BEHIND AS THEY GO TO THE NEXT GRADE LEVEL. COMMUNITY PARTNERS, SUCH AS FGP, ARE CRITICAL TO THE SUCCESS OF OUR STUDENTS.? 
ST. VINCENT HEALTHCARE WAS FOUNDED IN 1898 WITH A MISSION OF SERVING OTHERS, ESPECIALLY THOSE WHO ARE POOR OR VULNERABLE.  CELEBRATING 48 YEARS OF SERVICE IN MT, THE ST. VINCENT HEALTHCARE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) SUPPORTS THIS MISSION, TARGETING AT-RISK YOUTH WHO HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS BEING BELOW IN SOCIAL, DEVELOPMENTAL, OR ACADEMIC LEVELS.

ALU LIKE, INC. IS A NON-PROFIT AGENCY WHOSE MISSION IS TO HELP NATIVE HAWAIIANS WHO ARE COMMITTED TO ACHIEVING THEIR POTENTIAL FOR THEMSELVES, THEIR FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES.  NATIVE HAWAIIAN CHILDREN ARE MORE LIKELY TO EXPERIENCE NEGLECT OR ABUSE THAN OTHER ETHNIC GROUPS.  NATIVE HAWAIIAN CHILDREN IN ELEMENTARY SCHOOL LAG BEHIND CHILDREN FROM OTHER ETHNIC GROUPS IN READING PROFICIENCY AND MATHEMATICS.  TRADITIONALLY, NATIVE HAWAIIAN KUPUNA (OLDER ADULTS OR GRANDPARENTS) PLAY A LARGE ROLE IN PROVIDING SUPPORT AND GUIDANCE WITHIN THE FAMILY AND COMMUNITY.   AN ESTIMATED 62 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL PROVIDE ONE-ON-ONE ATTENTION IN PRESCHOOL AND CLASSROOMS K-12.  SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE PROVIDING EMOTIONAL SUPPORT AND CULTURAL REINFORCEMENT, AS WELL AS LITERACY DEVELOPMENT, MATHEMATICS AND TUTORING.  THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION WITHIN A NATIVE HAWAIIAN CULTURAL CONTEXT.  AT THE END OF THE THREE YEAR GRANT PERIOD, 20 PRESCHOOL CHILDREN WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS IN LITERACY, MATHEMATICS OR SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL SKILLS AND 150 STUDENTS IN GRADES K-12 WILL DEMONSTRATE IMPROVEMENT IN READING PROFICIENCY AND MATHEMATICS AND SOCIAL EMOTIONAL SKILLS.  THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $373,134 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $76,853.

THE STATE OF HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN SERVICES (DHS) IS SUBMITTING A GRANT PROPOSAL FOR THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) INITIATED BY THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE (CNCS).  DHS HAS SERVED AS THE GRANTEE FOR THIS PROGRAM SINCE ITS INCEPTION IN HAWAII 54 YEARS AGO.  THE TERM FOR THIS CURRENT GRANT IS THREE YEARS STARTING IN JULY 2019 AND ENDING IN JUNE 2022.  THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA FOR DHS IS EDUCATION, WITH TARGETS ON HELPING PRESCHOOL AGE CHILDREN DEMONSTRATING GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS (ED1A) AND ASSISTING SCHOOL AGE CHILDREN WITH K-12 SUCCESS (ED1A).  AN ESTIMATED 85 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE.  OF THIS NUMBER 85 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS.  IT IS THE GOAL OF THE HAWAII FGP TO PROVIDE ENCOURAGEMENT AND SUPPORT TO EVERY CHILD SERVED TO ALLOW THEM TO REACH THEIR HIGHEST POTENTIAL.  VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES WILL BE PROVIDED IN PRIVATE, NON-PROFIT PRESCHOOL PROGRAMS, HEAD START PROGRAMS, AFTER SCHOOL PROGRAMS, TUTORING PROGRAMS AND PUBLIC SCHOOLS.

PROGRAM OBJECTIVE ED1A -- SCHOOL READINESS
DHS WILL STRIVE TO ENGAGE THIRTY-THREE (33) FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS TO SERVE ONE HUNDRED-FIVE (105) STUDENTS IN TWENTY (20) HEAD START AND PRIVATE, NON-PROFIT EARLY EDUCATION CENTERS.  THE PROGRAM HAS SET A TARGET OUTCOME OF NINETY-TWO (92) OR EIGHTY-EIGHT PERCENT (88%) OF THE CHILDREN SERVED DEMONSTRATING IMPROVEMENT IN SCHOOL READINESS.  

PROGRAM OBJECTIVE ED1A -- K-12 SUCCESS
DHS WILL STRIVE TO ENGAGE FIFTY-TWO (52) FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS TO SERVE TWO HUNDRED-FIFTY (250) STUDENTS IN THIRTY-THREE (33) HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION (DOE) PUBLIC SCHOOLS.  THE PROGRAM HAS SET A TARGET OUTCOME OF TWO HUNDRED TWENTY (220) OR EIGHTY-EIGHT PERCENT (88%) OF THE STUDENTS SERVED HAVING IMPROVEMENT ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT OR SOCIAL EMOTIONAL SKILLS.

THE PROPOSED FUNDING LEVEL OF $456,781 IS BEING REQUESTED BY DHS.  
DHS IS COMMITTED TO PROVIDE $350,219 IN FUNDS TO ASSIST IN THE IMPLEMENTATION OF PROGRAM SERVICES.  THE PROGRAM HAS SET A GOAL OF 76 VOLUNTEER SERVICE YEARS (VSY).

THE DEPARTMENT OF DEVELOPMENTAL SERVICES (DDS) IS THE AGENCY THROUGH WHICH THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA PROVIDES SERVICES AND SUPPORTS TO INDIVIDUALS WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES (CONSUMERS.)
 
THE DDS ADMINISTERS A ROBUST FOSTER GRANPARENT PROGRAM (FGP), AND BEGINS THIS NEW GRANT PERIOD WITH 255 VOLUNTEERS FOR 494 CONSUMERS UNDER THE AGE OF 22.  WHILE ONLY REQUIRED TO FULFILL 205 VSYS, THE DSS CONTINUES TO DELIVER 265 VSYS IN THIS NEW GRANT PERIOD.
 
THE FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE THROUGHOUT CALIFORNIA WITH SUPERVISION AND ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT FROM SEVEN REGIONAL CENTERS. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE EDUCATION.  ALL OF THE FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL BE PLACED IN WORK PLAN ASSIGNMENTS, WHICH WILL PROMOTE SELF-DETERMINATION, INDEPENDENCE, PRODUCTIVITY, INTEGRATION AND INCLUSION IN COMMUNITY-BASED SETTINGS.  OUR CONSUMERS WILL BENEFIT BY RECEIVING THE FOLLOWING VOLUNTEER SERVICES: (1) ASSISTANCE IN THE CLASSROOM, (2) COMPANIONSHIP, (3) COMFORTING, (4) MENTORING, (5) SUPPORTING INTEGRATION, AND (6) OTHER INDIVIDUALIZED SUPPORTS AS IDENTIFIED IN THE CONSUMER'S IPP* OR IEP*.  IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THESE SUPPORTS WILL ENABLE CONSUMERS TO MORE FULLY PARTICIPATE IN VARIOUS INTEGRATED SETTINGS SUCH AS HEAD START, PUBLIC SCHOOL SITES, EMPLOYMENT TRAINING CENTERS FOR STUDENT INTERNS, AND OTHER ALTERNATIVE EDUCATIONAL SETTINGS. APPROXIMATELY 265 UNDUPLICATED VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE IN OUTCOME- BASED WORK PLAN OBJECTIVES, WITH AN ADDITIONAL 29 UNDUPLICATED VOLUNTEERS SERVING IN THE H15 OUTPUT-ONLY WORK PLAN OBJECTIVE.

THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE'S FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $1,233,036 MILLION WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY APPROXIMATELY $615,043 OF NON-FEDERAL FUNDS.

* THE INDIVIDUAL PROGRAM PLAN OR IPP IS THE RECORD OF THE NEEDS, SERVICES, AND SUPPORTS, IDENTIFIED FOR THE CONSUMER UNDER CALIFORNIA'S SYSTEM OF SERVICES.

*THE INDIVIDUALIZED EDUCATIONAL PLAN IS A PLAN OR PROGRAM DEVELOPED TO ENSURE THAT A CHILD WHO HAS A DISABILITY IDENTIFIED UNDER THE LAW AND IS ATTENDING AN ELEMENTARY OR SECONDARY EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION RECEIVES SPECIALIZED INSTRUCTION AND RELATED SERVICES.

AN ESTIMATED 74 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE. OF THIS NUMBER, 74 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS. SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE IMPLEMENTING TWICE-WEEKLY "JUMPSTART SESSIONS" OVER THE COURSE OF THE SCHOOL YEAR ON TEAMS IN PARTNER CLASSROOMS AND PROVIDING INDIVIDUAL CLASSROOM SERVICE HOURS. BOTH ACTIVITIES WILL INCREASE THE KINDERGARTEN READINESS OF 249 PRESCHOOL-AGED CHILDREN ANNUALLY FROM LOW-INCOME COMMUNITIES IN LOS ANGELES COUNTY USING JUMPSTART'S CURRICULUM DESIGNED TO IMPROVE KEY LANGUAGE, LITERACY, AND SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL SKILLS. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, 249 CHILDREN WILL HAVE BEEN SERVED BY THE PROGRAM EACH YEAR AND 137 PARTICIPATING CHILDREN WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS SKILLS ANNUALLY. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $385,999 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $149,018.

           AN ESTIMATED 70 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS (ALSO KNOWN AS ELDER MENTORS IN ALASKA) WILL SERVE.  OF THIS NUMBER, 70 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS.  THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL SUPPORT THE IMPROVEMENT OF ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT IN K-12 STUDENTS AND SCHOOL READINESS IN PRE-K CHILDREN THROUGH IN-SCHOOL MENTORING AND SHARING OF CULTURAL VALUES.
          THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION.
