HSOR'S STRONG LOCAL PRESENCE IN ROCKLAND COUNTY, CLOSE COLLABORATION WITH THE COMMUNITY ADVISORY COUNCIL AND VOLUNTEER STATIONS, 50 YEARS OF EXPERIENCE AND COMMUNITY COLLABORATION, AND HSOR'S AND THE CORPORATION'S ALIGNED GOALS OF SCHOOL READINESS AND K-12 SUCCESS PUT HSOR IN A POSITION TO EFFECTIVELY AND EFFICIENTLY SUPPORT THE FGP IN ROCKLAND COUNTY.

LEGAL APPLICANT: THE NEW YORK CITY DEPARTMENT FOR THE AGING 

DESCRIPTION OF ORGANIZATION AND MISSION: THE NEW YORK CITY DEPARTMENT FOR THE AGING (DFTA) WAS ESTABLISHED AS A MAYORAL DEPARTMENT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK IN L975 AND AS A FEDERAL AREA AGENCY ON AGING IN 1973.  IT IS THE LARGEST AREA AGENCY ON AGING IN THE UNITED STATES, WITH FUNDING FROM FEDERAL, STATE, AND CITY SOURCES AS WELL AS FOUNDATIONS.  THE DEPARTMENT'S MISSION IS "TO WORK FOR THE EMPOWERMENT, INDEPENDENCE, DIGNITY AND QUALITY OF LIFE OF NEW YORK CITY'S DIVERSE OLDER ADULTS, AND FOR THE SUPPORT OF THEIR FAMILIES THROUGH ADVOCACY, EDUCATION, AND THE COORDINATION AND DELIVERY OF SERVICES." DFTA HAS DEFINED A SET OF STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES TO DIRECT MISSION ACCOMPLISHMENT.  KEY AMONG THESE IS THE FOLLOWING: "TO FOSTER INDEPENDENCE AND INDIVIDUAL CHOICES; CONFRONT AGEISM; AND PROMOTE OPPORTUNITIES FOR OLDER PEOPLE TO SHARE THEIR LEADERSHIP, KNOWLEDGE, AND SKILLS."  SPONSORSHIP OF THE FGP IS CLEARLY CENTRAL TO THE DFTA'S MISSION, AND WILL HELP DFTA PROMOTE A POSITIVE VIEW OF AGING AND THE POTENTIAL OF OLDER PERSONS TO CONTRIBUTE MEANINGFULLY TO THEIR COMMUNITIES.

SECTION A.  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
GATEWAY COMMUNITY ACTION PARTNERSHIP IS ACTIVELY INVOLVED IN THE LIVES AND WELFARE OF THE COMMUNITIES IN SOUTHERN NEW JERSEY.  IN GLOUCESTER, SALEM AND CAMDEN COUNTIES, GATEWAY PROVIDES SERVICES TO CHILDREN AND FAMILIES THROUGH PROGRAMS SUCH AS OUR EARLY HEAD START AND HEAD START PROGRAMS AS WELL AS THE WOMEN, INFANTS, AND CHILDREN'S (WIC) NUTRITION PROGRAM.  GATEWAY HAS BEEN ACTIVELY SUPPORTING THE WORK OF THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM THROUGHOUT ITS HEAD START CENTERS IN SOUTHERN NEW JERSEY, INCLUDING CELEBRATING THEIR WORK AT THE ANNUAL HEAD START VOLUNTEER LUNCHEON. GATEWAY RECOGNIZES THE IMPORTANT ROLE THAT SENIOR ADULTS CAN PLAY IN THE LIVES OF YOUNG CHILDREN. GATEWAY IS COMMITTED TO ENSURING THAT CHILDREN BENEFIT FROM THE LOVE AND ATTENTION OF A FOSTER GRANDPARENT, AND THAT FOSTER GRANDPARENTS BENEFIT FROM THE OPPORTUNITY TO SHARE THEIR TIME AND TALENTS WITH THE CHILDREN.  
GATEWAY COMMUNITY ACTION PARTNERSHIP WILL WORK WITH AN ESTIMATED 58 FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM VOLUNTEERS TO SERVE IN THE COMMUNITIES OF CAMDEN, GLOUCESTER, SALEM AND BURLINGTON. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS, IN CHILD CARE AND HEAD START, HELPING CHILDREN WITH SCHOOL READINESS. SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE SUPPORTING SCHOOL READINESS IN THE CLASSROOM: HEAD START, CHILD CARE, AND SCHOOL DISTRICT PRESCHOOL PROGRAMS. OTHER ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE COMFORTING CHILDREN IN THE CLASSROOM AND ASSISTING WITH CARING FOR INFANTS IN THE EARLY HEAD START CLASSROOMS.  THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION, SPECIFICALLY EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, IT IS EXPECTED THAT CHILDREN WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS, SOCIAL AND/OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT, LITERACY SKILLS, AND NUMERACY. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $349,894 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $38,877.

-	COGNITIVE TABLE GAMES
-	ART AND CRAFTS
-	RECREATIONAL EXERCISE  

THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION. TO ACCOMPLISH THESE GOALS, THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $226,365 PER YEAR WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED IN THE ANTICIPATED LEVEL OF $64,620 IN NON FEDERAL RESOURCES.

THE JEFFERSON PARK MINISTRIES UNION COUNTY FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS THE LIFE LINE FOR MANY SENIORS IN THE UNION COUNTY AREA. THIS PROGRAM HAS REJUVENATED MANY OF THE SENIORS AND WE CAN SEE THIS CHANGE IN THEIR LIVE, AND THEIR ATTITUDE TOWARDS THE CHILDREN THEY ARE SERVING. SENIORS WHO WERE ONCE ANTI-SOCIAL ARE NOW BUILD SELF-CONFIDENCE WHILE WORKING WITH THE CHILDREN; THUS, ALLOWING THEM TO BECOME MORE INVOLVED IN THEIR COMMUNITY.

AN ESTIMATED 38 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL SERVE. OF THIS NUMBER, AN ESTIMATED 38 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS. THE PRINCE GEORGE'S COUNTY DEPARTMENT OF FAMILY SERVICES IS THE LEGAL APPLICANT FOR THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP). THE MISSION OF THE DEPARTMENT OF FAMILY SERVICES IS TO ENSURE THE PROVISION OF COMPREHENSIVE AND RESPONSIVE COMMUNITY-BASED SERVICES THAT ENHANCE THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES THAT STRENGTHEN THE PRINCE GEORGE'S COUNTY COMMUNITY. THE PRINCE GEORGE'S COUNTY FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM HAS BEEN IN EXISTENCE FOR FORTY-SIX YEARS AND IS HOUSED IN THE DEPARTMENT OF FAMILY SERVICES AGING AND DISABILITIES SERVICES DIVISION WHICH ALSO SERVES AS THE LOCAL AREA AGENCY ON AGING.   THE MISSION OF THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS TO CONNECT ADULTS 55 AND OVER WITH MEANINGFUL VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES WITH CHILDREN IN CHILD CARE CENTERS, SCHOOLS AND OTHER NON-PROFIT AGENCIES.
THROUGH THIS GRANT, AN ESTIMATED 60 VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE THE PRINCE GEORGE?S COUNTY COMMUNITY THROUGH APPROXIMATELY 16 HOST SITES.  OF THIS NUMBER 40 VOLUNTEERS WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS.  THE PRINCE GEORGE'S COUNTY FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM'S PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF SERVICE IS SCHOOL READINESS AND EDUCATION. THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS PROVIDE ACTIVITIES SUCH AS SCHOOL AND COMMUNITY-BASED MENTORING, ASSISTING IN CLASSROOMS, COMFORTING CHILDREN, CARING FOR INFANTS AND ASSISTING YOUNG MOTHERS.  AT THE END OF THE THREE YEAR GRANT PERIOD 60 VOLUNTEERS WILL ASSIST APPROXIMATELY 425 CHILDREN IMPROVE IN THE ACADEMIC AREAS OF LITERACY AND MATH. THE TOTAL AMOUNT OF THE PROPOSED FY19 BUDGET IS $321,905 OF WHICH $241,038 IS THE REQUESTED CNCS SHARE AND $80,867 IS THE GRANTEE SHARE.   OUR PRIMARY GOALS ARE TO MAKE A DIFFERENCE IN THE LIFE OF A CHILD WHILE AT THE SAME TIME ENRICHING THE LIFE OF THE VOLUNTEER AS WELL AS PROVIDE MENTORING OPPORTUNITIES FOR AT-RISK YOUTH IN PRINCE GEORGE'S COUNTY.

THE MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF JUVENILE SERVICES IS THE CENTRAL CABINET --LEVEL AGENCY RESPONSIBLE FOR PROVIDING INDIVIDUALIZED CARE AND TREATMENT OF YOUTH OFFENDERS BETWEEN THE AGES OF SEVEN AND TWENTY-ONE. THE DEPARTMENT'S MISSION SEEKS TO ENSURE THE PUBLIC SAFETY AND PROTECTION OF THE COMMUNITY, TO HOLD YOUTH OFFENDERS ACCOUNTABLE TO VICTIMS AND COMMUNITIES, AND TO DEVELOP YOUTH COMPETENCY AND CHARACTER TO ASSIST THEM IN BECOMING RESPONSIBLE AND PRODUCTIVE MEMBERS OF SOCIETY. IN CARRYING OUT ITS MISSION, DJS EMBRACES A BALANCED AND RESTORATIVE JUSTICE PHILOSOPHY INCORPORATING EVIDENCE-BASED BEST PRACTICES. AN ESTIMATED 59 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE AS POSITIVE ROLE MODELS, AS TUTORS, AND AS MENTORS. THEY WILL PROVIDE INDIVIDUALIZE TUTORING AND MENTORING TO YOUTH IDENTIFIED AS NEEDING ASSISTANCE THROUGH A NETWORK OF TWENTY-FIVE STATIONS SUCH AS; ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS, JUVENILE DETENTION FACILITIES, DAY/EVENING REPORTING CENTERS, ALTERNATIVE EDUCATION PROGRAMS, AFTER SCHOOL PROGRAMS, AND A 3RD GRADE READING PROGRAM. SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE: INDIVIDUALIZED AND SMALL GROUP READING FOCUSING ON READING COMPREHENSION AND WORD RECOGNITION; ENCOURAGING YOUTH TO PARTICIPATE IN CLASSROOM DISCUSSIONS, PRACTICING PROPER CLASSROOM BEHAVIOR, AND TO COMPLETE CLASSROOM AND HOMEWORK ASSIGNMENTS. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THE PROJECT IS EDUCATION. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT,  THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES FOR THIS PROGRAM ARE;  IMPROVED ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE IN LITERACY AND OR MATH, AND IMPROVED OVERALL ACADEMICS.  THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $306,665 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $141,612 NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES.

THE UNITED PLANNING ORGANIZATION (UPO) IS REQUESTING FUNDING TO CONTINUE THE ADMINISTRATION OF THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL COMMUNITY SERVICES (CNCS), SENIOR CORPS, AND FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM FOR THE DC GRANT AWARD FROM JULY 1, 2018 THROUGH JUNE 30, 2021 IN THE AMOUNT OF $751,177.  THE UPO FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) WILL PROVIDE VOLUNTEER SERVICE OPPORTUNITIES FOR APPROXIMATELY 250 VOLUNTEERS AGED 55 AND OLDER EACH YEAR OVER THE THREE-YEAR PERIOD. OF THE 250 SENIOR VOLUNTEERS NINETY PERCENT OF VOLUNTEERS WILL BE PLACED IN IMPACT-BASED ASSIGNMENTS AND SUPPORTED WITH OUTCOME WORK/ASSIGNMENT PLANS AND EVALUATIONS.
THE UPO FGP FOCUS AREA IS EDUCATION. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS (FGS) WILL ASSIST IN EARLY EDUCATION, EARLY HEAD START AND HEAD START TO FACILITATE SCHOOL READINESS.  FGS WILL PROVIDE TUTORING / MENTORING IN CNCS SUPPORTED PUBLIC AND PUBLIC CHARTER SCHOOLS TO IMPROVE ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE.   AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT PERIOD, UPO INTENDS TO ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING OUTCOMES: 1) ED23 2,025 CHILDREN DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SOCIAL AND /OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT 2) ED27 1,860 STUDENTS IN MENTORING/TUTORING PROGRAMS WITH IMPROVED ACADEMICS IN MATH AND LITERACY 3) ED2 4,000 STUDENTS WILL COMPLETE CNCS SUPPORTED EDUCATION PROGRAMS.
 	OVER THE LAST TWO YEARS OF THE PROGRAM, THE PROJECT DIRECTOR HAS WORKED WITH UPO OFFICES OF DEVELOPMENT AND RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT TO RAISE IN-KIND FUNDING TO SUPPORT THE FGP. IN FY 2017, DEVELOPMENT EFFORTS RESULTED IN RAISING $29,200 FROM PRIVATE FOUNDATIONS AND FROM INDIVIDUALS.  OVER THE NEXT THREE YEARS, UPO INTENDS TO SUPPLEMENT THE GRANT MATCH REQUIREMENTS OF $78,177 PER YEAR BY RAISING $30,000 PER YEAR IN GRANTS AND $48,177 PROGRAM IN-KIND SUPPORT AND CASH DONATIONS.

CAREER RESOURCES, INC. (CRI) PROPOSES TO LAUNCH THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM OF GREATER BRIDGEPORT, WITH FUNDING FROM THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE.  

AN ESTIMATED 67 FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL SERVE. ALL OF THE VOLUNTEERS IN THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS. VOLUNTEER ACTIVITIES WILL FOCUS ON EDUCATION. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS K-3RD GRADE LITERACY TUTORING. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, THE ANTICIPATED EDUCATIONAL OUTCOME IS THAT 300 CHILDREN WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS, SOCIAL AND/OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT, AND DEMONSTRATE IMPROVEMENT IN LITERACY SKILLS. FOR THIS PROJECT, 67 VOLUNTEERS WILL DEDICATE 3132 HOURS OF SERVICE IN CLASSROOMS THROUGHOUT THE GREATER BRIDGEPORT AREA. THE HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES COMMISSION (HHSC), THROUGH ITS FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP), IS FUNDED TO SUPPORT 448 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS BY CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE (CNCS) PLUS AN ADDITIONAL 8 VOLUNTEERS THROUGH A LEGISLATIVE STATE AWARD. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THE FGP PROJECT IS EDUCATION, COVERING THE OBJECTIVES OF SCHOOL READINESS, K-12 SUCCESS AND THREE AREAS UNDER THE OBJECTIVE OF COMFORTING CHILDREN (JUVENILE DELINQUENCY, STATE SUPPORTED LIVING CENTERS (SSLCS), AND AFTER SCHOOL AND SUMMER PROGRAMS). SERVICE ACTIVITIES ALIGNING WITH NATIONAL PERFORMANCE MEASURES INCLUDE: ASSISTING IN CLASSROOMS; ASSISTING IN HEAD START CLASSROOMS; MENTORING YOUNG MOTHERS WITHIN PUBLIC SCHOOLS; AND TUTORING, MENTORING, AND COMFORTING CHILDREN. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT CYCLE, IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT AT LEAST 5,739 CHILDREN WILL BE MENTORED IN EDUCATION OUTCOME AREAS BY THE FGP VOLUNTEERS IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS, HEAD START CENTERS, CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTERS, SSLCS, AND JUVENILE CORRECTION FACILITIES. ADDITIONAL CHILDREN IN TRANSIENT POPULATIONS WILL BE SERVED IN OUTPUT AREAS SUCH AS HOMELESS SHELTERS, AFTER SCHOOL AND SUMMER PROGRAMS. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $1,917,775 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $263,049 IN STATE GENERAL REVENUE AND LEGISLATIVE STATE AWARD. THE FGP SERVICE AREAS HAVE OFFICES IN ABILENE, AUSTIN, CORPUS CHRISTI, DENTON, LUFKIN, LUBBOCK, MEXIA AND ROSENBERG AND PROVIDE SERVICES TO SURROUNDING AREAS CONSISTING OF 29 TEXAS COUNTIES.

WE ARE THE SOUTH EAST TEXAS FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM.  OUR SPONSORING AGENCY IS THE SOUTH EAST TEXAS REGIONAL PLANNING COMMISSION (SETRPC).  SETRPC WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1971 FOR THE PURPOSE OF SOLVING REGION-WIDE PROBLEMS BY PROMOTING INTERGOVERNMENTAL COOPERATION AND COORDINATION, CONDUCTING COMPREHENSIVE REGIONAL PLANNING, AND PROVIDING A FORUM FOR THE DISCUSSION AND STUDY OF AREA ISSUES.  SETRPC HAS BEEN OUR SPONSORING AGENCY FOR OVER 28 YEARS.   
WE HAVE RECRUITED AND TRAINED AN ESTIMATED 90 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WHO WILL SERVE IN HARDIN, JEFFERSON AND ORANGE COUNTIES, ALSO KNOWN AS THE ?GOLDEN TRIANGLE?. OUR VOLUNTEER ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PROVIDING MENTORS AND TUTORS TO ENCOURAGE "AT RISK" CHILDREN WHILE HELPING ENHANCE THEIR SOCIAL, EMOTIONAL, AND COGNITIVE DEVELOPMENT AND ACADEMIC SKILLS.    THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION.  
BECAUSE OF OUR FOSTER GRANDPARENT'S INVOLVEMENT WITH THEIR ASSIGNED CHILDREN, WE ARE ANTICIPATING THAT 85% OF THE CHILDREN SERVED WILL BE SUCCESSFUL IN REACHING THEIR ACADEMIC GOALS.  THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $393,446 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY LOCAL INVESTMENT OF $144,441. WITH THESE INVESTMENTS, WE WILL BE ABLE TO PROVIDE 88 VOLUNTEER SERVICE HOURS (VSYS) TO OUR COMMUNITY.

SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE: ASSISTING IN THE CLASSROOM, ASSISTING IN HEAD START CLASSROOMS, COMFORTING CHILDREN, CARING FOR INFANTS, AND TUTORING. SUNBEAM FAMILY SERVICES, INC., IS A VOLUNTEER-LEAD AND SUPPORTED NONPROFIT AGENCY WITH A 110 YEAR TRADITION OF SERVICE TO THE COMMUNITY'S MOST VULNERABLE CITIZENS RESIDING IN THE OKLAHOMA CITY METRO AREA.  OUR HISTORY DATES BACK TO 1907 WHEN THE AGENCY OPERATED A CHILDREN'S HOME FOR DEPENDENT AND NEGLECTED CHILDREN.  OUR COUNSELING CLINIC HAS BEEN IN OPERATION SINCE THE LATE 1930S AND WAS THE FIRST COMMUNITY-BASED MENTAL HEALTH SERVICE IN OKLAHOMA.   IN THE LATE 1960S, SUNBEAM OPENED THE CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTER, WHICH HAS NOW MERGED WITH OKC EDUCARE.  IN THE 1970S, SUNBEAM BEGAN PROVIDING SERVICES TO THE ELDERLY AND THEIR FAMILIES, NOW KNOWN AS THE SENIOR COMPANION PROGRAM.  IN 2001, SUNBEAM OPENED THE FIRST EMERGENCY SHELTER FOR SENIOR CITIZENS IN OKLAHOMA.  IN 2003, WE ADDED THE CAREGIVER FUNDAMENTALS PROGRAM AND BEGAN OFFERING TRAINING AND SUPPORT TO INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES CARING FOR AN AGING FAMILY MEMBER. SUNBEAM HAS A STRONG TRADITION OF BEING ON THE CUTTING EDGE OF SENIOR SERVICES AND IS PROUD TO BE A PART OF THE SENIOR CORPS PROGRAM.  SUNBEAM IS DEDICATED TO PROVIDING THE HIGHEST QUALITY OF CARE FOR SENIORS IN OUR COMMUNITY.  ALL OF OUR SERVICES ARE NATIONALLY ACCREDITED BY THE COUNCIL ON ACCREDITATION.  OUR MISSION IS TO PROVIDE PEOPLE OF ALL AGES WITH HELP, HOPE, AND THE OPPORTUNITY TO SUCCEED. 
SUNBEAM'S FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS CURRENTLY APPLYING FOR THIRD YEAR OF A MULTI-YEAR GRANT AWARD FROM THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE, SENIOR CORPS; WE RESPECTFULLY REQUEST $273,617.  THIS AWARD AMOUNT WILL ALLOW US TO DELIVER THE EXCELLENT SERVICES THAT WE PROVIDE TO SENIORS IN OKLAHOMA AS A PART OF SUNBEAM'S SENIOR SERVICES PROGRAMMING. .   
IT IS ALSO INTERESTING TO NOTE THAT, ACCORDING TO AARP, THE PERCENTAGE OF OKLAHOMANS AGES 50 TO 64 THAT LIVE AT 133% TO 400% OF THE POVERTY LEVEL IS 45% COMPARED TO THE NATIONAL AVERAGE OF 39%.  ALL OF OUR FOSTER GRANDPARENTS CURRENTLY PROVIDING VOLUNTEER SERVICE FALL AT OR BELOW 200% OF POVERTY.  
SUNBEAM FAMILY SERVICES IS DEDICATED TO PROVIDING QUALITY, OUTCOME-BASED SERVICES THROUGHOUT ALL PROGRAMS OF SERVICE.  THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM INCORPORATES MANY MECHANISMS FOR FEEDBACK TO ENSURE EFFICIENT AND EFFECTIVE SERVICES TO SENIORS.  THE PROGRAM HAS AN EXTENSIVE PERFORMANCE QUALITY IMPROVEMENT (PQI) COMPONENT THAT INCLUDES QUARTERLY PEER REVIEW OF ALL PROGRAM FILES.  THE SUNBEAM SENIOR SERVICES PQI TEAM EVALUATES THE PROGRAM ANNUALLY AND PROVIDES FEEDBACK TO THE SENIOR SERVICES ADVISORY COUNCIL.  ADDITIONALLY, THE PQI TEAM CONDUCTS INTERVIEWS WITH A RANDOMLY CHOSEN GROUP OF FOSTER GRANDPARENTS TO EVALUATE THE IMPACT OF THE PROGRAM.  THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT SUPERVISOR(S) CONDUCT QUARTERLY REVIEWS OF OUTCOMES OF THE PROGRAM THAT ARE PREDETERMINED BY THE BOARD-APPROVED AGENCY STRATEGIC PLAN. 
SUNBEAM FAMILY SERVICES IS AS VITAL TO THE COMMUNITY NOW AS IT WAS IN 1907, WORKING HARD EACH AND EVERY DAY TO FULFILL ITS MISSION BY PROVIDING AFFORDABLE, QUALITY SOCIAL SERVICES THAT RESULT IN IMPROVED INDIVIDUAL AND FAMILY FUNCTIONING.  THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS AN INTEGRAL PART OF SUNBEAM FAMILY SERVICE'S PROGRAMMING AND PLAYS A CRUCIAL ROLE IN THE CONTINUUM OF CARE AVAILABLE TO SENIORS IN OKLAHOMA.  SUNBEAM IS MISSION-DRIVEN, NATIONALLY ACCREDITED AND PROVIDES SERVICES THAT ARE EVIDENCED-BASE AND OUTCOME MEASURED.  WE ARE PROUD OF ALL WE HAVE ACCOMPLISHED IN THE PAST YEARS, AND WE ARE EXCITED AND PREPARED TO FACE FUTURE OPPORTUNITIES AND CHALLENGES OF THIS NEW(ER) PROGRAM THAT COMPLEMENTS OUR SENIOR COMPANION PROGRAM.

THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS A SUPPORT AND PREVENTION PROGRAM, BOTH IN ITS ACTIONS AND ITS PHILOSOPHY AND BENEFITS EVERYONE INVOLVED WITH IT.  THE PROGRAM SPONSOR BELIEVES THAT THE GREATER THE INDEPENDENCE AND SELF-SUFFICIENCY OF AN INDIVIDUAL, THE GREATER THE QUALITY OF LIFE IS FOR THAT PERSON. DELTA COMMUNITY ACTION FOUNDATION, INC. IS A PRIVATE, NON-PROFIT CORPORATION ORGANIZED FOR THE PURPOSE OF PLANNING, COORDINATING, AND EXECUTING PROGRAMS AUTHORIZED BY FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL ENTITIES TO ALLEVIATE AND ATTEMPT TO ERADICATE POVERTY IN SOUTHERN OKLAHOMA.  THE MISSION OF DELTA COMMUNITY ACTION AGENCY IS TO PROMOTE THE SELF-SUFFICIENCY AMONG OUR CITIZENS TO SECURE THE OPPORTUNITIES TO WORK, TO LIVE IN DECENCY, AND WITH DIGNITY.
WE ARE REQUESTING FUNDING FOR THE DELTA FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IN THE AMOUNT OF $461,931 TO BE USED FOR 77 VOLUNTEER SERVICE YEARS (VSYS) TO PERFORM VOLUNTEER WORK IN 11 COUNTIES LOCATED IN SOUTHERN AND CENTRAL OKLAHOMA: CADDO, CARTER, CLEVELAND, COMANCHE, GARVIN, GRADY, MCCLAIN, MURRAY, POTTAWATOMIE, SEMINOLE, AND STEPHENS.  THE 77 VSYS WILL SERVE APPROXIMATELY 80,000 HOURS ASSISTING AT RISK CHILDREN IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS, HEAD START, AND EARLY HEAD START CLASSROOMS.
THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THE DELTA FGP IS EDUCATION.  OUR VOLUNTEERS SEEK TO IMPROVE EDUCATIONAL OUTCOMES FOR DISADVANTAGED/AT-RISK CHILDREN.  DELTA FGP VOLUNTEERS ENGAGE IN A VARIETY OF SERVICE ACTIVITIES TO ENSURE THE SUCCESS OF THESE OUTCOMES.  SOME OF THE SERVICE ACTIVITIES WILL FOCUS ON HELPING STUDENTS FURTHER DEVELOP READING, MATH, WRITING, SPELLING, AND COMPREHENSION SKILLS TO IMPROVE ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT.  OTHER SERVICE ACTIVITIES WILL HAVE VOLUNTEERS HELPING CHILDREN COMPLETE LITERACY OBJECTIVES THAT ARE ALIGNED WITH HEAD START EARLY LEARNING OUTCOMES FRAMEWORK.  THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOME AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT WILL BE THAT ASSIGNED STUDENTS DEMONSTRATE IMPROVEMENTS IN DEVELOPMENTAL AREAS IN WHICH THEY NEED ASSISTANCE.  
THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $461,931 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY SPONSORSHIPS AND IN-KIND DONATIONS TOTALING $53,431.  DELTA COMMUNITY ACTION FOUNDATION, INC. WILL BE FOCUSING ON LOCATING ADDITIONAL FUNDING RESOURCES THROUGHOUT THE YEAR.

KI BOIS COMMUNITY ACTION FOUNDATION, INC. (KI BOIS CAF) IS A MULTI-PURPOSE COMMUNITY ACTION AGENCY.  ITS MISSION IS TO REMAIN DEDICATED TO ELIMINATING THE CAUSES OF POVERTY AND BETTERING THE ECONOMIC, MENTAL, PHYSICAL AND SOCIAL WELL-BEING OF ALL PEOPLE, MOST IMPORTANTLY THE DISADVANTAGED, BY UTILIZING EFFECTIVE COORDINATION AND ADMINISTRATION OF AVAILABLE RESOURCES.
KI BOIS CAF IS REQUESTING $557,898 IN BUDGET SUPPORT FROM THE CORPORATION AND WILL SUPPLEMENT THE FEDERAL BUDGET WITH $70,158.  AN ESTIMATED 121 VOLUNTEERS WILL PARTICIPATE IN THE PROGRAM.  THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA IS EDUCATION, THE NATIONAL PERFORMANCE MEASURES ARE K-12 SUCCESS AND SCHOOL READINESS.  THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS COMMUNITY NEEDS SURROUNDING CHILDREN AND THEIR FAMILIES THAT ARE EXPERIENCING LOW-INCOME AND OTHER DIFFICULTIES.  ACCORDING TO THE CHILD TRENDS DATA BANK, CHILDREN WHO ARE POOR ARE DISPROPORTIONATELY EXPOSED TO RISK FACTORS THAT MAY IMPAIR BRAIN DEVELOPMENT AND AFFECT SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT.  THIS CAN AFFECT THEIR ABILITY TO LEARN AND PROGRESS IN SCHOOL WHICH ULTIMATELY AFFECTS THEIR POTENTIAL TO EARN A LIVING WAGE AND BECOME A PRODUCTIVE MEMBER OF THE COMMUNITY.
VOLUNTEERS WILL GREATLY INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF PUBLIC SCHOOLS AND HEAD START CENTERS BY PROVIDING ONE-ON-ONE ATTENTION, TUTORING AND MENTORING WHICH WOULD NOT BE AVAILABLE OTHERWISE FOR CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL AND EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS.  THESE VOLUNTEERS WILL ASSIST THE EDUCATIONAL FACILITY IN BETTER PREPARING CHILDREN FOR THE NEXT STEP IN THEIR EDUCATIONAL CAREER.
THE PROJECT'S ANTICIPATED END OUTCOMES ARE 350 ELEMENTARY SCHOOL CHILDREN WILL SHOW AT LEAST 10% IMPROVEMENT IN THEIR IDENTIFIED PRIORITY AREA SUCH AS MATH OR LITERACY SKILLS, AND 15 HEAD START CHILDREN WILL SHOW AT LEAST 10% PROGRESS IN THEIR IDENTIFIED PRIORITY AREAS SUCH AS LETTER, NUMBER AND COLOR RECOGNITION AND SOCIAL/LANGUAGE SKILLS.

THE COUNTIES OF EDDY AND LEA, LOCATED IN THE SOUTHEASTERN SECTION OF THE STATE OF NEW MEXICO, ARE KNOWN FOR THEIR NATURAL WONDERS, SUCH AS CARLSBAD CAVERNS AND THE LINCOLN NATIONAL FOREST.  EDDY COUNTY HAS A POPULATION OF 57,578; AND LEA COUNTY HAS A POPULATION OF 71,180.  IN 2015, TWENTY-SIX(26) PERCENT OF THE POPULATION IN EDDY COUNTY, AND THIRTY (30) PERCENT IN LEA COUNTY, WERE CHILDREN UNDER THE AGE OF 18.  OF THESE, 12% IN EDDY COUNTY AND 28% IN LEA COUNTY LIVED BELOW THE POVERTY LEVEL.  THE POPULATION IS STEADILY INCREASING DUE TO THE EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES SPURRED BY THE BOOMING INDUSTRIES OIL AND GAS. THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM, SPONSORED BY THE SOUTHEAST NEW MEXICO COMMUNITY ACTION CORPORATION HAS SERVED THE COMMUNITIES FOR 52 YEARS.  
 	THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA FOR THE GRANT RENEWAL APPLICATION IS EDUCATION. THE OBJECTIVES ARE SCHOOL READINESS AND K-12 SUCCESS.  TWENTY-SEVEN FOSTER GRANDPARENTS (INPUTS) WILL TUTOR 135 CHILDREN IN THREE HEAD START PROGRAMS AND  SIXTEEN K-12 SCHOOLS IN EDDY AND LEA COUNTIES (TARGETS).  FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL ASSIST CHILDREN ONE-ON-ONE AND IN SMALL GROUPS, TO IMPROVE/ DEVELOP THEIR LANGUAGE/LITERACY AND SOCIAL SKILLS (SERVICE ACTIVITIES). THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES WILL BE THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN DEMONSTRATING GAINS IN - SCHOOL READINESS IN TERMS OF SOCIAL AND/OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT, SCHOOL READINESS IN TERMS OF LITERACY SKILLS, AND THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN WITH IMPROVED ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE IN LITERACY AND/OR MATH.

CITIZENS FOR THE DEVELOPMENTALLY DISABLED, INC. (CDD) PROVIDES DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH CONTRACT SERVICES THROUGH THE FAMILY, INFANT & TODDLER PROGRAM FOR CHILDREN BIRTH -- THREE YEARS OF AGE, A DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES WAIVER PROGRAM FOR HANDICAPPED ADULTS FROM THE AGE OF 21 THROUGH ADULTHOOD, AND SPONSORS THE COLFAX COUNTY FOSTER GRANDPARENT AND SENIOR COMPANION PROGRAMS. CDD IS APPLYING FOR NINE VOLUNTEER SERVICE YEARS AND $74,000 IN STATE FUNDING TO SUPPORT THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM. 

THE SERVICE CATEGORIES THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS ARE PRE-ELEMENTARY, ELEMENTARY EDUCATION, TUTORING & CHILD LITERACY (MID-SCHOOL) AND BENEFITS TO VOLUNTEERS.  THE ELEMENTARY EDUCATION WORK PLAN INCLUDES PERFORMANCE MEASURES. THE PROGRAM WILL COLLECT MID-YEAR AND END-YEAR EVALUATION FORMS FROM VOLUNTEER STATION REPRESENTATIVES TO MEASURE PERFORMANCE. ANOTHER MEASUREMENT TOOL USED IS VOLUNTEER SATISFACTION SURVEYS. THE PROJECT'S ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES ARE:

* PRE-ELEMENTARY CHILDREN RECEIVING SERVICES WILL BE ABLE TO ADAPT TO THEIR SCHOOL SCHEDULE AND SEPARATION FROM PARENTS AND/OR BE ABLE TO ENTER KINDERGARTEN.
* INTERMEDIATE OUTCOME IS; EIGHTY PERCENT OF ELEMENTARY STUDENTS WILL IMPROVE THEIR ACADEMIC, ORGANIZATIONAL AND BEHAVIORAL SKILLS BECAUSE OF THE HELP OF A FOSTER GRANDPARENT.  
* END OUTCOME IS; NINETY PERCENT OF ELEMENTARY STUDENTS WILL ADVANCE TO THE NEXT GRADE LEVEL.
* MENTORED STUDENTS (MID-SCHOOL) WILL IMPROVE IN ACADEMIC, ORGANIZATIONAL AND BEHAVIORAL SKILLS BECAUSE OF THE HELP OF A FOSTER GRANDPARENT THEY WILL ADAPT TO THE CHANGE OF MID- SCHOOL SCHEDULES. 
* VOLUNTEERS WILL BENEFIT BY HAVING SOMETHING MEANINGFUL TO DO, SUPPLEMENTAL INCOME FOR LOW INCOME VOLUNTEERS AND ALL VOLUNTEERS WILL HAVE IMPROVED QUALITY OF LIFE. 

THE ELEMENTARY EDUCATION WORK PLAN ADDRESSES COMMUNITY NEEDS AND THE CORPORATION'S STRATEGIC PLAN; EDUCATION, BY IMPROVING EDUCATIONAL AND BEHAVIORAL OUTCOMES OF STUDENTS IN LOW-ACHIEVING PRE-ELEMENTARY, ELEMENTARY AND MIDDLE SCHOOL. 

THE BENEFITS TO VOLUNTEERS WORK PLAN ADDRESS CNCS GOAL 2 (STRENGTHEN NATIONAL SERVICE SO THAT PARTICIPANTS ENGAGED IN CNCS-SUPPORTED PROGRAMS CONSISTENTLY FIND SATISFACTION, MEANING AND OPPORTUNITY.) BY SUPPORTING PARTICIPANTS TO FIND MEANING IN THEIR SERVICE EXPERIENCE AND REMAIN HIGHLY ENGAGED IN THEIR COMMUNITIES.

THE CITY OF SANTA FE, NEW MEXICO, DIVISION OF SENIOR SERVICES MISSION IS TO OFFER PROGRAMS AND SERVICES DESIGNED TO ALLOW OLDER ADULTS TO REMAIN LIVING IN THEIR OWN HOMES AS COMFORTABLY AND AS INDEPENDENTLY AS POSSIBLE, AND TO HOPEFULLY AVOID INSTITUTIONALIZATION. ONE WAY OF ACCOMPLISHING THIS IS THROUGH VOLUNTEERING IN OUR SANTA FE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM WHERE THEY HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO REMAIN ACTIVE AND SOCIALLY ENGAGED. THE 2004 STUDY CONDUCTED BY DR. LINDA FRIED (DIRECTOR OF CENTER ON AGING AND HEALTH, JOHN HOPKINS MEDICAL INSTITUTIONS) EVALUATING THE IMPACTS OF OLDER VOLUNTEERS IN PUBLIC ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS IN ROLES DESIGNED TO MEET SCHOOLS? NEEDS AND INCREASE THE SOCIAL, PHYSICAL, AND COGNITIVE ACTIVITY OF THE VOLUNTEERS REVEALED THAT OLDER ADULTS WHO REGULARLY VOLUNTEER WITH CHILDREN BURN 20% MORE CALORIES PER WEEK, EXPERIENCED FEWER FALLS, WERE LESS RELIANT ON CANES, AND PERFORMED BETTER ON A MEMORY TEST THAN THEIR PEERS. 
THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM, THE FIRST NATIONAL INTERGENERATIONAL PROGRAM, WAS CREATED IN 1963 AS A COMPONENT OF THE ?WAR ON POVERTY.? ITS PRIMARY PURPOSE IS TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR LOW-INCOME SENIORS (AGED 60 AND OVER) TO ENGAGE WITH CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL OR EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS WHILE REDUCING ISOLATION AND POVERTY AMONG THE ELDERLY. IN THIS CONTEXT, THE SANTA FE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM PROPOSES SERVING A PROJECTED 27 LOW-INCOME SENIOR VOLUNTEERS; ALL OF WHICH WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS.  THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THE PROJECT IS EDUCATION WITH PRIMARY OBJECTIVES OF INCREASING SCHOOL READINESS AND K-12 SUCCESS. SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ASSISTING THE IDENTIFIED CHILDREN IN CLASSROOMS, COMFORTING THEM AND PROVIDING MENTORING/TUTORING.  AT THE END OF THE ONE YEAR GRANT CYCLE, APPROXIMATELY 89 CHILDREN WILL HAVE EITHER SUCCESSFULLY BEEN PROMOTED TO THE NEXT GRADE LEVEL WITH THEIR PEERS, INCREASE TEST SCORES, AND INCREASE SOCIAL SKILLS AS WELL AS BOOSTING THE CHILD?S MORALE, CONFIDENCE AND SELF-ESTEEM. THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $24,833 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $98,539 IN NEW MEXICO STATE FUNDS AND $112,252 IN LOCAL CITY FUNDS.

THE SPONSOR ORGANIZATION IS THE DEMING LUNA COUNTY COMMISSION ON AGING, INC. (COA).  THE COA IS A NON-PROFIT 501(C)(3) CORPORATION OPERATING AS A SERVICE ORGANIZATION IN LUNA COUNTY, NEW MEXICO SINCE 1976.  THE COA HAS BEEN THE LEADER IN IMPLEMENTING SERVICES AND PROGRAMS IN LUNA COUNTY WITH A STRONG MISSION OF PROMOTING INDEPENDENCE, PRESERVING DIGNITY, AND ENHANCING THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR A DIVERSE POPULATION OF OLDER ADULTS AND PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES IN OUR COUNTY.  OUR ORGANIZATION ADVOCATES AND PROVIDES SUPPORTIVE PERSON-TO-PERSON SERVICES TO OLDER, LOW-INCOME ADULTS WHO HAVE HEALTH AND FUNCTIONAL LIMITATIONS, ENABLING THEM TO LIVE INDEPENDENTLY FOR AS LONG AS POSSIBLE IN A DIGNIFIED MANNER WITHIN OUR COMMUNITY.  THE COA CURRENTLY OFFERS OPPORTUNITIES FOR OLDER ADULTS THROUGH PROGRAMS LIKE THE SENIOR EMPLOYMENT PROGRAM, THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT, SENIOR COMPANION AND RETIRED SENIOR VOLUNTEER PROGRAMS.

FOR OUR FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) PROJECT, AN ESTIMATED TWELVE (12) VOLUNTEERS WILL PROVIDE SERVICE WITHIN THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF EDUCATION THROUGH THE DEMING PUBLIC SCHOOL DISTRICT AND HEAD START PROGRAMS LOCATED IN THE COMMUNITY.  FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL PROVIDE DEVELOPMENTAL, SOCIAL AND INTERPERSONAL SKILLS TO IDENTIFIED CHILDREN PRE-K THROUGH SIXTH GRADE THROUGH A NETWORK OF ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS AND HEAD START PROGRAMS. 
AT THE END OF A TWELVE MONTH PERFORMANCE PERIOD, THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES FOR FOUR STATIONS WILL BE CHILDREN WHO HAVE DEVELOPED SKILLS THAT WILL ASSIST WITH THEIR ADVANCEMENT TO THE NEXT GRADE LEVEL.  THESE SKILLS WILL HAVE ASSISTED THEM IN AREAS SUCH AS READING, MATH AND LANGUAGE ARTS AS WELL AS DEVELOPING SOCIAL SKILLS FOR RELATIONSHIP DEVELOPMENT.

THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT TO OUR FGP PROJECT IS ZERO DOLLARS.  THE PROJECT WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED WITH STATE, LOCAL AND IN-KIND FUNDS IN THE AMOUNT OF $76,543 (NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES).

NEW MEXICO (NM) IS A MINORITY-MAJORITY STATE WITH MORE THAN 59% HISPANIC CHILDREN, ACCORDING TO THE U.S. CENSUS BUREAU-2015. ACCORDING TO THE 2016 KIDS COUNT IN NM, NM RANKS VERY LOW, 49TH AMONG THE STATES ON OVERALL CHILD WELL-BEING, WITH A PROPORTION OF ITS CHILDREN-20% OF FAMILIES LIVE AT OR BELOW THE POVERTY LEVEL. IN WHICH THE HOUSEHOLD HEAD LACKS A HIGH SCHOOL DIPLOMA. IN ADDITION, 36% OF THE STATE?S FAMILIES THAT LIVE IN POVERTY ARE HEADED BY A NON-HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATE. READING PROFICIENCY IS A CRUCIAL ELEMENT OF SCHOLASTIC SUCCESS, BUT IN NM, 77% OF THE CHILDREN ARE NOT PROFICIENT IN READING BY THE 4TH GRADE. NM CHILDREN LIVE IN FAMILIES WHERE THE HEAD OF THE HOUSEHOLD LACKED A HIGH SCHOOL DIPLOMA. THESE NUMBERS RANK NM 47TH IN THE NATION ON THIS INDICATOR. THEREFORE, CHILDREN?S CHANCES OF BEING HEALTHY, DOING WELL IN SCHOOL, AND GROWING UP TO BE PRODUCTIVE AND CONTRIBUTING MEMBERS OF SOCIETY ARE TIED TO THEIR EXPERIENCES IN THE EARLY YEARS. EVIDENCE SUGGESTS THAT POVERTY AND LOW SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS ARE LINKED TO POOR HEALTH AND EDUCATIONAL OUTCOMES AND MAY HAVE PARTICULARLY LONG-LASTING AND POWERFUL EFFECTS ON CHILDREN. IN NM, CHILDREN OF COLOR FACE SERIOUS CHALLENGES AT MUCH GREATER RATES THAN DO MANY OF THEIR PEERS. CHILDREN TEND TO HAVE WORSE OUTCOMES IN ECONOMIC WELL-BEING, EDUCATION, AND HEALTH, AND IN FACT, RACIAL AND ETHNIC DISPARITIES EXIST IN NEARLY EVERY INDICATOR OF CHILD WELL-BEING. CHILDREN OF COLOR ARE MORE LIKELY TO LIVE IN POVERTY AND IN HIGH-POVERTY AREAS AND A LESS LIKELY TO HAVE ACCESS TO HEALTH INSURANCE AND HIGH-QUALITY EARLY EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. RACIAL AND ETHNIC DISPARITIES ARE OF A PARTICULAR CONCERN IN NM BECAUSE 75% CHILDREN ARE CHILDREN OF COLOR. IN ORDER TO GIVE NM AND KIDS MORE OPPORTUNITIES TO SUCCEED, WE MUST BRING TOGETHER PROGRAMS FOR CHILDREN AND ADULTS AND TAKE A DELIBERATE AND COORDINATED TWO-GENERATIONAL APPROACH. THIS IS AN AREA THAT THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM WILL ASSIST IN IMPROVING EDUCATIONAL OUTCOMES.

THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) OF CURRY COUNTY WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1965 TO PROVIDE OLDER ADULTS WITH A USEFUL WAY TO SERVE THEIR COMMUNITIES IN THEIR RETIREMENT YEARS, GIVING THEM THE SATISFACTION THAT COMES FROM BEING NEEDED AND SERVING OTHERS. CURRY COUNTY HAS BEEN AN ACTIVE PARTICIPANT OF FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM SINCE 1986, AFFECTING THE LIVES OF MANY SENIOR FOSTER GRANDPARENTS AND STUDENTS THEY HAVE HELPED. 
AN ESTIMATED EIGHT (8) VSY WILL SERVE IN THE CURRY COUNTY FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM. OF THIS NUMBER EIGHT (8) VSY WILL BE PLACED IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THE PROJECT IS EDUCATION, OBJECTIVES: K-12 SUCCESS. ACTIVITIES WILL BE CONDUCTED IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS AND WILL INCLUDE TUTORING STUDENTS WITH SPECIAL NEEDS AND/OR DISADVANTAGED YOUTH IN THE AREAS OF READING, ENGLISH AS A SECOND LANGUAGE, AND MENTORING IN BEHAVIOR AND SOCIAL SKILLS. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT WE ANTICIPATE THAT THE STUDENTS RECEIVING SERVICES WILL HAVE IMPROVED ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE IN LITERACY, LANGUAGE SKILLS, BEHAVIOR AND SOCIAL SKILLS.  
THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $50,864 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY OVER $30,000 FROM NON-FEDERAL RESOURCES.

THE LEGAL APPLICANT IS THE CITY OF ALBUQUERQUE (COA) DEPARTMENT OF SENIOR AFFAIRS (DSA).  DSA OFFERS SENIORS AGE 50 AND BETTER A CONTINUUM OF SERVICES AND PROGRAMS FOR ACTIVE TO FRAIL ADULTS.  PROGRAMS PROMOTE BOTH HEALTHY AGING AND INDEPENDENT LIVING THAT MEET THE INDIVIDUAL NEEDS OF SENIORS IN THE ALBUQUERQUE/BERNALILLO COUNTY AREA.  DSA OPERATES SENIOR CENTERS, MULTIGENERATIONAL CENTERS, SPORTS/FITNESS CENTERS, MEAL SITES, HOME SERVICES, CARE COORDINATION, INFORMATION & ASSISTANCE SERVICES, SENIOR TRANSPORTATION, AND A CENTRAL KITCHEN. THE MISSION OF DSA IS TO BE A COMMUNITY LEADER, WHO IN PARTNERSHIP WITH OTHERS, INVOLVES SENIORS AND PEOPLE OF ALL AGES IN CREATING A COMMUNITY THAT ENHANCES EVERYONE'S QUALITY OF LIFE BY PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES TO ACHIEVE THEIR POTENTIAL, SHARE THEIR WISDOM, MAINTAIN THEIR INDEPENDENCE, AND LIVE WITH DIGNITY.  
AN ESTIMATED 71 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE IN APPROXIMATELY 48 VOLUNTEER STATIONS INCLUDING ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS, MIDDLE SCHOOLS AND/OR HIGH SCHOOLS, HEAD START PROGRAMS, PRE-ELEMENTARY DAYCARE CENTERS, AND HEALTH AND WELFARE PROGRAMS. TWELVE VOLUNTEER STATIONS ARE YEARLONG ASSIGNMENTS.  VOLUNTEER ACTIVITIES IN ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS WILL INCLUDE TUTORING CHILDREN AND PROVIDING READING SUPPORT.  VOLUNTEERS IN MIDDLE SCHOOLS AND/OR HIGH SCHOOLS WILL MENTOR DISADVANTAGED YOUTH.  VOLUNTEER ACTIVITIES IN HEAD START PROGRAMS WILL INCLUDE ASSISTING IN CLASSROOMS AND MODELING PROPER SOCIAL SKILLS.  VOLUNTEER ACTIVITIES IN PRE-ELEMENTARY DAYCARE CENTERS AND HEALTH AND WELFARE PROGRAMS WILL INCLUDE CARING FOR AND COMFORTING INFANTS, TODDLERS, AND HOMELESS CHILDREN.  ALTERNATE AND DUPLICATED VOLUNTEERS WILL PROVIDE SEASONAL SERVICE IN ELEMENTARY SUMMER SCHOOL SESSIONS AND IN COMMUNITY CENTER SUMMER RECREATION PROGRAMS.  
THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THE PROJECT IS EDUCATION WITH OBJECTIVES IN K-12 SUCCESS AND SCHOOL READINESS. AT THE END OF THE THREE YEAR GRANT, FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL HAVE SERVED OVER 600 CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL OR EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS AND DISADVANTAGED YOUTH.
OF THE CHILDREN SERVED IN OUTCOME-BASED WORK PLANS, 90% WILL HAVE IMPROVED ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE IN LITERACY OR MATH, WILL DEMONSTRATE IMPROVED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT, OR WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS IN TERMS OF SOCIAL AND/OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT.  THE CHILDREN SERVED IN PRE-ELEMENTARY DAYCARE CENTERS, HEALTH AND WELFARE PROGRAMS, AND IN SEASONAL ASSIGNMENTS, WILL BE COMFORTED BY FORGING RELATIONSHIPS WITH FOSTER GRANDPARENTS.

THE TAOS COUNTY SENIOR PROGRAM IS A LOCAL GOVERNMENT ENTITY WHICH COMPRISES FOUR SENIOR CENTERS IN TAOS COUNTY WITH ACTIVITIES AND SUPPORT SERVICES THAT CATER TO THE SPECIFIC NEEDS OF SENIORS. THESE CENTERS ADDRESS THE HEALTH, SOCIAL, RECREATIONAL, AND LOGISTICAL NEEDS OF THE ELDERLY POPULATION IN FOUR LOCATIONS. OUR SENIOR CENTERS SERVE APPROXIMATELY 400 OLDER ADULTS EACH DAY THROUGH A WIDE VARIETY OF PROGRAMS. OUR MISSION IS TO HELP SENIORS IMPROVE AND MAINTAIN A HEALTHY AND INDEPENDENT LIFESTYLE AND TO MAXIMIZE THEIR QUALITY OF LIFE. ACCORDING TO THE 2010 CENSUS THERE WERE 4559 SENIORS LIVING IN TAOS COUNTY, AND 536 LIVING FULL TIME IN THE EAGLE NEST / ANGEL FIRE AREA. MANY FAMILIES IN THE RURAL AREAS HAVE LIVED IN THE AREA THEIR WHOLE LIVES, AND WISH TO REMAIN IN THE AREA. ACCORDING TO THE 2012 AMERICAN COMMUNITY SURVEY THERE WERE APPROXIMATELY OVER 622 IDENTIFIED AS GRANDPARENTS WERE PRIMARY CAREGIVERS FOR THEIR GRANDCHILDREN. THERE WERE 8,232 MALE AND FEMALES OVER THE AGE OF 60 IN TAOS COUNTY WITH 3,857 BEING MALE AND 4,375 BEING FEMALE. THERE WERE 5,771 DISABLED PERSONS LIVING IN TAOS COUNTY. ALL AREAS ARE CONSIDERED VERY RURAL, WITH A POPULATION DENSITY OF 13 PERSONS PER SQ. MILE.
THE MAJORITY OF THE AREAS WHERE THE SENIORS LIVE ARE ON UNPAVED AND NON-MAINTAINED ROADS, WHICH CAUSES ISSUES IN THE WINTER AND RAINY MONTHS. OUTSIDE OF THE TOWN OF TAOS AREA, EMERGENCY TEAMS ARE ON VOLUNTEER BASIS, WHICH INCREASES THE TIME OF RESPONSE. THERE IS A HOSPITAL IN THE TOWN OF TAOS WHICH IS OVER AN HOUR DRIVE FROM THE FARTHEST MOST PART OF THE COUNTY, AND A MEDICAL CLINIC IN BOTH QUESTA AND CHAMISAL AREA, BUT IS ONLY OPEN MON-FRI REGULAR HOURS.
WE ARE CONSCIOUS OF THE CHANGING DEMOGRAPHICS IN OUR CENTER'S SERVICE AREA AND ARE COMMITTED TO GROWING AND ADAPTING OUR CENTERS TO MEET THE EMERGING NEEDS.
THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS INTENDED TO ADDRESS THE CATEGORIES IDENTIFIED IN THE ELEMENTARY SCHOOL EDUCATION SYSTEMS. THE CATEGORIES IDENTIFY THE NEED FOR INDIVIDUAL ONE-TO-ONE INTERVENTION TO ASSIST CHILDREN WHO ARE STRUGGLING TO REACH THEIR SCHOOL READINESS AND LITERACY GOALS. STUDENTS HAVE SHOWN IMPROVEMENT IN GOALS SET BY TEACHER THROUGH WORK PLANS TO ACHIEVE SET ACCOMPLISHMENTS TO NEXT GRADE LEVEL OF ACHIEVEMENT PER IDENTIFIED CHILD. TEACHERS PROVIDE PRE/POST TESTS, DI BELS AND THE CTBS BURGANCE SCORES OR TEACHERS SURVEY TO IDENTIFY THE LEVEL OF ACHIEVEMENT PER IDENTIFY CHILD. 
THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS FUNDED FOR 15 CORPORATION VSY'S AND 16 NON-CORPORATION VSY'S FOR A TOTAL OF 31 VSY'S. SOME OF THE ACTIVITIES THAT THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS ENGAGE IN INCLUDE: PARTICIPATING IN GROUP ACTIVITIES, PLAYING GAMES, AND TELLING STORIES. ASSISTING WITH READING, TEACHING MANNERS AND SOCIAL SKILLS. HELPING CHILD TO FOLLOW DIRECTIONS, ACCOMPLISH WORK AND TO STAY FOCUS ON TASK. CLARIFYING AND INTERPRETING GROUP INSTRUCTIONS INTO INDIVIDUAL INSTRUCTIONS. ASSISTING WITH SELF-HELP SKILLS, COMFORTING AND PRAISING CHILD. 
THE PRIMARY FUNCTION OF OUR FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS TO ASSIST OUR SCHOOL CHILDREN WITH LITERACY AND SCHOOL READINESS. 
AT THE END OF THE THREE YEAR GRANT THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOME WILL BE: STUDENTS WILL IMPROVE ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE IN LITERACY AND IN SCHOOL READINESS OF SOCIAL AND OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT.

HELP-NEW MEXICO, INC. (HELP-NM) IN SAN MIGUEL, MORA AND GUADALUPE COUNTIES HAS BEEN OPERATING AND ASSISTING COMMUNITIES STATEWIDE FOR OVER 50 YEARS TO CREATE SELF-SUFFICIENCY AND PROMOTE ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES TO STRENGTHEN FAMILIES THROUGHOUT NM.  ESTABLISHED IN 1965, HELP-NM HAS PROVIDED SERVICES TO COUNTLESS LOW-INCOME AND MIGRANT/SEASONAL WORKER FAMILIES, NEGLECTED AND ABUSED CHILDREN, DISABLED INDIVIDUALS, DISADVANTAGED YOUTH, AND LAST BUT CERTAINLY NOT LEAST SENIOR CITIZENS. HELP-NM PROGRAMS INCLUDE ADULT EDUCATION, LITERACY, JOB TRAINING, WORK EXPERIENCE, FAMILY OR INDIVIDUAL COUNSELING, EARLY CHILDHOOD AND YOUTH DEVELOPMENT, EDUCATION, NUTRITION, AFFORDABLE HOUSING AND SENIOR PROGRAMS. THE HELP-NM FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP), THROUGH ITS EXISTING CAPACITY PROPOSES TO RENEW OUR PROGRAM FOR CONTINUED OPERATION USING 44 VSYS (STATE AND FEDERAL VSY S). THE FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $41,760 WHICH SUPPORTS 9 VSYS IS SUPPLEMENTED BY $183,213 IN STATE AND LOCAL RESOURCES TO SUPPORT 35 VSY S IN THE THREE COUNTIES OF NORTHEAST NEW MEXICO. THE PROGRAM CONTINUES TO PROVIDE SUPPORT SERVICES TO APPROXIMATELY 88 CHILDREN WHO NEED FGP SERVICES IN 15 WORKSITES. PLACEMENT OF FG P VOLUNTEERS ARE BASED ON NEED THROUGH REFERRALS FROM PARTNERS I.E. SCHOOLS, HEAD START CENTERS ETC AND THE CONCEPT OF ?RIGHT FIT?. THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THE PROJECT IS INDIVIDUAL IMPROVEMENT IN LEARNING BY ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED STUDENTS IN SCHOOLS AND HEAD START PROGRAMS.  AT THE END OF THE PROGRAM PERIOD, STUDENTS ARE EXPECTED TO DEMONSTRATE IMPROVEMENTS IN EDUCATION SKILLS, IMPROVED BEHAVIORS AND BE READING AT GRADE LEVEL. WE WILL UTILIZE SURVEYS, ASSESSMENTS, AND PERSONAL VISITS WILL BE USED TO ADDRESS THE NEEDS AND THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES OF THE PROJECT.

CITY OF ALAMOGORDO MISSION:    THE CITY OF ALAMOGORDO IS A MUNICIPAL CORPORATION THAT EXISTS SOLELY FOR THE PURPOSE OF PROVIDING THE BEST POSSIBLE SERVICES TO OUR CUSTOMERS - THE CITIZENS OF ALAMOGORDO.  WE ARE COMMITTED TO PROVIDING THESE SERVICES WITH HONESTY, INTEGRITY, COMPASSION, FAIRNESS AND A COMMITMENT TO EXCELLENCE.  PART OF OUR MISSION IS TO PROVIDE VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES FOR PERSONS 55 AND OVER, WHICH IN TURN HELPS US PROVIDE AN ENVIRONMENT OFFERING SUPPORT EDUCATION, RECREATION, NUTRITION AND ENTERTAINMENT FOR ELDERLY RESIDENTS IN ALAMOGORDO AND THE SURROUNDING AREA.  OUR GOAL IS TO HELP SENIORS ACHIEVE AND MAINTAIN A VITAL, PRODUCTIVE ROLE IN LIFE EITHER THROUGH VOLUNTEERISM OR AS A CLIENT RECEIVING THESE SERVICES.  

FUNDING SOURCES:    WE CURRENTLY DO NOT RECEIVE ANY FEDERAL FUNDING: HOWEVER, WE ARE REQUESTING $67,500 IN NON-FEDERAL FUNDING FOR 13 VSY'S

SERVICE CATEGORIES:    ELEMENTARY EDUCATION

COMMUNITY NEEDS:    OTERO COUNTY AND ALAMOGORDO HAVE A GREAT NEED FOR LITERACY PROGRAMS.  OVER 25% OF ALL SCHOOL AGE CHILDREN SPEAK MORE THAN ONE LANGUAGE, REPORTING THAT ENGLISH IS NOT THEIR FIRST LANGUAGE AND THEY HAVE LIMITED USE OF ENGLISH AT HOME.  

RESEARCH-BASED METHODS:    STUDENTS IDENTIFIED BY TEACHERS AND ASSISTED BY FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL IMPROVE IN THE AREA OF LITERACY AND MATH.  THEIR SOCIAL SKILLS WILL ALSO IMPROVE DUE TO INCREASED CONFIDENCE.  PRE AND POST TESTS WILL BE USED TO MEASURE GAINS IN LITERACY AND MATH.  SOCIAL SKILL DEVELOPMENT WILL ALSO BE MEASURED BY THE TEACHERS REPORTING ON BEHAVIOR SKILLS REFLECTED ON REPORT CARDS THROUGHOUT THE YEAR.

OUTCOMES:  THOSE STUDENTS IDENTIFIED BY TEACHERS WILL HAVE REACHED THE GOAL OF READING AT CURRENT GRADE LEVEL OR ABOVE.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY - FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM
 EXPERTS ESTIMATE THAT NEARLY 40 PERCENT OF U.S. 4TH GRADERS DO NOT ACHIEVE BASIC LEVELS OF READING PROFICIENCY. THE NUMBER IS HIGHER AMONG LOW-INCOME FAMILIES, CERTAIN MINORITY GROUPS, AND ENGLISH LANGUAGE LEARNERS.  AMONG THE 50 STATES IN THE NATION, NEW MEXICO RANKS 50TH-DEAD LAST-IN 4TH GRADE READING PROFICIENCY. ONLY ABOUT 20 PERCENT, JUST TWO OF EVERY TEN NEW MEXICO 4TH GRADERS, CAN READ AT PROFICIENT LEVELS . 
THE TOTAL POPULATION OF CHAVES COUNTY, LOCATED IN THE SOUTHEASTERN QUARTER OF THE STATE OF NEW MEXICO, IS 66,000. TWENTY-EIGHT PERCENT (28%) ARE UNDER THE AGE OF 18.   OF THESE, THIRTY-TWO PERCENT (32%) LIVE BELOW THE POVERTY LEVEL.  
   CHILDREN WITH DELAYS AND/OR DISABILITIES HAVE IMPROVED THEIR LITERACY AND MATH SKILLS AS A RESULT OF THE TUTORING/MENTORING BY THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM, WHICH HAS BEEN SPONSORED BY THE CHAVES COUNTY J.O.Y. CENTERS, INC. FOR APPROXIMATELY 24 YEARS. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA FOR THE GRANT RENEWAL APPLICATION IS EDUCATION. THE OBJECTIVES ARE SCHOOL READINESS AND K-12 SUCCESS. SERVICE ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE: ASSISTANCE (INDIVIDUALLY & IN SMALL GROUPS) WITH READING AND MATH, MODELING SOCIAL SKILLS, AND HELPING STUDENTS IMPROVE THEIR SELF-ESTEEM (OUTPUTS).  THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $49,869 WILL BE SUPPLEMENTED BY $51,200 STATE DOLLARS AND $6,073 LOCAL DOLLARS.

THE MISSION OF THE SIERRA JOINT OFFICE ON AGING IS TO ESTABLISH A CONTINUUM OF SOCIAL SUPPORT AND HEALTH SERVICES TO MEET THE NEEDS OF ELDERLY INDIVIDUALS AND MAXIMIZE THEIR INDEPENDENCE. AN ESTIMATED 7 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE. THEY WILL PROVIDE ONE-ON-ONE ASSISTANCE TO THE YOUTH OF SIERRA COUNTY THROUGH A NETWORK OF PUBLIC SCHOOLS, A FAITH BASED PRIVATE SCHOOL, THE BOYS AND GIRLS CLUB, AND THE PUBLIC LIBRARY. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION. AT THE END OF THE 12 MONTH PERFORMANCE PERIOD, WE ANTICIPATE PROGRESSION IN READING, MATH, WRITING SKILLS AND ENGLISH AS A SECOND LANGUAGE.

THE UNIVERSITY OF LOUISIANA MONROE, COLLEGE OF BUSINESS AND SOCIAL SCIENCES, UNDER THE EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, MS. RITA MASSEY, WILL OVERSEE THE CADDO/BOSSIER FGP PROGRAM.  A FULL TIME DIRECTOR WILL BE HIRED TO ADMINISTER THE FGP PROGRAM FUNDED FOR 55 VSY'S.  FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL TUTOR CHILDREN TO STRENGTHEN EDUCATIONAL ACADEMICS AND SOCIAL SKILLS THROUGH A NETWORK OF NON-PROFIT VOLUNTEER STATIONS SUCH AS HEAD START CENTERS AND PUBLIC SCHOOLS. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THE PROJECT WILL BE EDUCATION AND SCHOOL READINESS FOCUS AREAS (ED2, ED5, ED23, ED24).  AT THE END OF THE GRANT PERIOD THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN THAT COMPLETED PARTICIPATION IN CNCS SUPPORTED EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION PROGRAMS WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS IN TERMS OF SOCIAL AND/OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT.  THE NUMBER OF STUDENTS IN GRADES K-12 THAT PARTICIPATE IN THE MENTORING OR TUTORING OR OTHER EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING, INCLUDING CNCS-SUPPORTED SERVICE-LEARNING WILL DEMONSTRATE IMPROVED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT.  
THE LA DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION (LDE) FOR 2012 INDICATES 46% OF STUDENTS ENTERING KINDERGARTEN ARE NOT ACADEMICALLY AND DEVELOPMENTALLY READY TO SUCCEED.  STUDENTS WHO BEGIN KINDERGARTEN UNPREPARED ARE LIKELY TO EXPERIENCE DIFFICULTY IN THEIR ACADEMIC ENDEAVORS.  LDE DEVELOPED THE SCHOOL READINESS REPORT TO ENGAGE STAKEHOLDERS TO RECOGNIZE THAT CHILDREN COME TO SCHOOL WITH MANY EXPERIENCES IN MULTIPLE SETTINGS AND RESOURCES FOR SCHOOL READINESS.  SCHOOL READINESS DESCRIBES THE CAPABILITIES OF CHILDREN, THEIR FAMILIES, SCHOOL, AND COMMUNITIES TO BEST PROMOTE STUDENT SUCCESS IN KINDERGARTEN AND BEYOND.  EACH COMPONENT PLAYS AN ESSENTIAL ROLE IN DEVELOPMENT OF SCHOOL READINESS.  A READY CHILD IS PREPARED SOCIALLY, PERSONALLY, PHYSICALLY, AND INTELLECTUALLY WITHIN THE COGNITIVE DOMAINS OF LITERACY, MATH, MOTOR DEVELOPMENT AND SOCIAL/EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENTS.  A STUDY PUBLISHED IN THE JOURNAL OF GERIATRICS AND GERONTOLOGICAL EDUCATION, REPORTS THAT 3-4 YEAR OLDS WHO PARTICIPATE IN A 9-MONTH INTERGENERATIONAL PROGRAM WERE MORE WILLING TO SHARE, HELP AND COOPERATE WITH AN OLDER PERSON THAN THOSE WITHOUT EXPERIENCE WITH THE ELDERLY.
THE CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT OF $327,791 IS REQUESTED ANNUALLY, PENDING CONTINUED FUNDING AVAILABILITY.  THE INITIAL BUDGET PERIOD WILL BEGIN ON AUGUST 1, 2017, AND END DECEMBER 31, 2017.  
THE ANNUAL AWARD AMOUNT WILL BE PRORATED ACCORDINGLY.  SUBSEQUENT BUDGET PERIODS WILL BE 12 MONTHS IN DURATION FROM JANUARY 1, 2018 THROUGH DECEMBER 31, 2019.

BIG BROTHERS BIG SISTERS OF SOUTHWEST LOUISIANA'S FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM WILL HAVE AN ESTIMATED 64 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WHO WILL SERVE CHILDREN IN 17 STATIONS IN CALCASIEU AND JEFF DAVIS PARISHES. THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL WORK AT LEAST 30 MINUTES PER DAY, PER DESIGNATED SUBJECT (READING AND MATH), PER ASSIGNED STUDENT. 
THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS K-12 SUCCESS AND SCHOOL READINESS. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOME IS THAT STUDENTS WILL SCORE AT AVERAGE OR ABOVE AVERAGE ON BENCHMARK TESTING IN MATH AND READING. THE FGP PROGRAM WILL FOCUS ON 3 OUTCOME AREAS:
1. ASSIST STUDENTS IN K-12 IN IMPROVING THEIR READING SKILLS AND MATH SKILLS TO HELP THEM REACH GRADE LEVEL BY GRADE THREE, INCREASING LEAP, ILEAP, AND BENCHMARK SCORES TO BASIC OR ABOVE BASIC. 
2. ASSIST STUDENTS WHO ARE IN GRADES K-12 WHO HAVE LITTLE TO NO ASSISTANCE AT HOME WITH HOMEWORK IN IMPROVING THEIR MATH AND READING SKILLS TO HELP THEM REACH GRADE LEVEL IN THESE SUBJECTS BY GRADE THREE, INCREASING LEAP,  ILEAP AND BENCH MARK TEST SCORES TO BASIC OR ABOVE BASIC.
3. ASSIST HEAD START CHILDREN IN COGNITIVE ABILITIES IN EARLY LITERACY AND MATH SKILLS PRIOR TO ENTERING KINDERGARTEN. 
DATA WILL BE COLLECTED FROM THE STATIONS REPORTED BY TEACHERS AND/OR SUPERVISORS TWICE DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR. TEACHERS WILL DOCUMENT CHILD PARTICIPATION IN FGP PROGRAM ACTIVITIES AS SHOWN ON THE CLASSROOM ATTENDANCE LOG. DATA COLLECTION WILL BE INCLUDED ON A SPREAD SHEET SEPARATED BY STATION AND FGP PROGRAM WHICH WILL BE UPDATED IN JANUARY AND AGAIN IN MAY WITH INFORMATION COLLECTED FROM BENCHMARK SCORES AND/OR STANDARDIZED TESTS. DATA WILL THEN BE TOTALED AND REPORTED. EXPECTED RESULTS INCLUDE: REACHING GRADE LEVEL IN READING AND MATH, INCREASED LEAP, ILEAP AND BENCHMARK TEST SCORES AND SCHOOL READINESS FOR HEAD START STUDENTS. THE 
CNCS FEDERAL INVESTMENT WOULD BE $ 279,104.

HELENA, TANGIPAHOA AND WASHINGTON. CATHOLIC CHARITIES OF THE DIOCESE OF BATON ROUGE (CCDBR) HAS PROVIDED LIFE-SUSTAINING SOCIAL SERVICES THROUGHOUT A 12 CIVIL-PARISH REGION SINCE 1964. WE PROVIDE A WIDE ARRAY OF COMMUNITY BASED SERVICES TO LOW AND MODERATE INCOME POPULATIONS. A TOTAL OF 95% OF THOSE RECEIVING SERVICES FROM CCDBR FALL BELOW FEDERAL POVERTY GUIDELINES.  OUR SERVICES INCLUDE MENTAL HEALTH COUNSELING, HOMELESSNESS PREVENTION PROGRAMS, DOMESTIC AND INTERNATIONAL ADOPTION SERVICES, POST-ADOPTION SERVICES, EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION, YOUTH PROGRAMS, EMPLOYMENT SERVICES, DISASTER RECOVERY CASE MANAGEMENT, FOSTER GRANDPARENT SERVICES, HOUSING FOR HOMELESS, PREGNANT WOMEN, IMMIGRATION AND REFUGEE SERVICES, AND TRANSITIONAL HOUSING FOR FAMILIES WITH CHILDREN. OUR SERVICES ARE DESIGNED TO ASSIST THOSE MOST VULNERABLE IN OUR COMMUNITY ACHIEVE A HIGHER LEVEL OF SELF-SUFFICIENCY AND SUCCESS AS FAMILIES, HOUSEHOLDS AND NEIGHBORHOODS. WE SERVE THOSE MOST IN NEED REGARDLESS OF FAITH, DEPLOYING CREATIVE AND EFFECTIVE SERVICES AIMED AT REDUCING THE IMPACT OF POVERTY IN THE COMMUNITIES WE SERVE.  FOR A NUMBER OF YEARS, CATHOLIC CHARITIES OF THE DIOCESE OF BATON ROUGE HAS BEEN THE LEADING REFERRAL AGENCY OF THE BATON ROUGE UNITED WAY'S 211 INFO LINE.
FOSTER GRANDPARENTS PROVIDE A VITAL SERVICE TO THE COMMUNITIES THEY SERVE. THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM RECRUITS NURTURING, CARING AND LOVING SENIOR CITIZEN VOLUNTEERS TO SERVE AS MENTORS FOR AT-RISK YOUTH IN ELEMENTARY EDUCATION, SCHOOL READINESS AND HUMAN NEEDS SERVICES. THE SUCCESS OF THE CHILDREN IS MEASURED BY OUR TEACHER SURVEYS AS WELL AS OUR TUTORING LOGS.  OUR LONG TERM OUTCOMES FOR OUR STUDENTS ARE TO IMPROVE READING SKILLS AND BE PROMOTED TO THE NEXT GRADE LEVEL. OUR FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL REMAIN ACTIVE, RECEIVE FINANCIAL SUPPORT AND WILL ALSO FEEL AN ENHANCED SENSE OF SELF-WORTH AND OVERALL WELL-BEING. 
AN ESTIMATED 63 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE MORE THAN 212 CHILDREN BETWEEN THE AGES OF 4 -10. CHILDREN READING BELOW THEIR GRADE LEVEL WILL RECEIVE ONE HOUR TUTORING SESSIONS, 3 TIMES PER WEEK, FOR A NINE MONTH SCHOOL TERM.  SOME OF THE FGP ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ONE ON ONE AND SMALL GROUP TUTORING, WITH A FOCUS ON DEVELOPMENT OF READING /READING READINESS SKILLS, LANGUAGE AND WRITING SKILLS, VOCABULARY AND SPELLING EXERCISES AND COMPREHENSION ACTIVITIES.  THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THE PROJECT IS EDUCATION, WITH A HEAVY EMPHASIS ON K-12 SUCCESS AND SCHOOL READINESS.  AT THE END OF THE THREE  YEAR GRANT, WE PROJECT THAT 75% OF STUDENTS PARTICIPATING IN THE PROGRAM WILL DEMONSTRATE IMPROVED SCHOOL READINESS, ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE IN LITERACY AND/OR MATH, IMPROVED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT AND IMPROVED ATTENDANCE.

NORTHERN ARIZONA UNIVERSITY (NAU) PROVIDES AN OUTSTANDING UNDERGRADUATE RESIDENTIAL EDUCATION STRENGTHENED BY RESEARCH, GRADUATE AND PROFESSIONAL PROGRAMS, AND SOPHISTICATED METHODS OF DISTANCE DELIVERY AND VALUES EXCELLENCE IN EDUCATION, STUDENT SUCCESS, EDUCATIONAL ACCESS, DIVERSITY, INTEGRITY, AND CIVILITY. NAU ACHIEVES THIS THROUGH TEACHING, COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT, AND INNOVATIVE MANAGEMENT. THE CIVIC SERVICE INSTITUTE, HOUSED IN THE COLLEGE OF SOCIAL AND BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES, PROVIDES AN IMPORTANT LINK TO THE COMMUNITY BY ENGAGING VOLUNTEERS OF ALL AGES TO HELP MEET CRITICAL COMMUNITY NEEDS. THE CIVIC SERVICE INSTITUTE (CSI@NAU), WHICH ENGAGES VOLUNTEERS TO MEET THE NEEDS OF COMMUNITIES AND NEIGHBORHOODS THROUGHOUT ARIZONA, SPONSORS FOUR NATIONAL SERVICE PROGRAMS: AMERICORPS, SENIOR COMPANION PROGRAM, RSVP, AND FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM. 
THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) SERVES THE ENTIRE STATE OF ARIZONA WITH VOLUNTEERS CURRENTLY ACTIVE IN SEVEN COUNTIES -- COCONINO, MARICOPA, MOHAVE, PIMA, PINAL, YAVAPAI, AND YUMA. THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS WITH MORE THAN 100 EDUCATIONAL SITES SUCH AS PRESCHOOLS, HEAD START CLASSROOMS, K-12 CLASSROOMS, AND NONPROFITS SERVING CHILDREN, FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL WORK WITH AND POSITIVELY IMPACT 750 CHILDREN THROUGHOUT ARIZONA. CSI@NAU REQUESTS $752,359 IN FEDERAL FUNDS TO SUPPORT 150 VOLUNTEERS IN MEETING 125 VOLUNTEER SERVICE YEARS. THE CNCS INVESTMENT WILL BE MATCHED WITH $83,595 REQUIRED MATCH AND $211,751 EXCESS FUNDS, FOR A TOTAL BUDGET OF $1,047,705. 
EDUCATION IS THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM AND VOLUNTEERS SERVE IN THREE WORK PLANS IN TWO OBJECTIVE AREAS: EARLY CHILDHOOD AND K-12 SUCCESS. THROUGHOUT ARIZONA, CHILDREN ARE STRUGGLING TO MEET STATE AND NATIONAL STANDARDS IN THEIR AGE GROUP. FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WORK INDIVIDUALLY OR IN SMALL GROUPS WITH CHILDREN WHO ARE EXPERIENCING CHALLENGES BY TUTORING AND MENTORING THEM TO SUCCEED SCHOOL AND LIFE. VOLUNTEERS, THROUGH PRE-SERVICE AND IN-SERVICE MEETINGS, ARE TRAINED TO DELIVER EFFECTIVE, RESEARCH-BASED TECHNIQUES AND TOOLS TO THEIR ASSIGNED STUDENTS TO ASSIST THEM IN LEARNING IMPORTANT SKILLS. WE ANTICIPATE THE FOLLOWING OUTCOMES: 1) 80% OF STUDENTS IN K-12 EDUCATION PROGRAMS WILL SHOW IMPROVED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT; 2) 80% OF STUDENTS MATCHED WITH A FOSTER GRANDPARENT MENTOR WILL SHOW IMPROVED ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENTS; AND 3) 80% OF STUDENTS IN EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION PROGRAMS WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SOCIAL AND/OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT.

THE NAVAJO FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS SERVES AT THE PUBLIC, BOARDING, COMMUNITY SCHOOL, HEAD-START, AND DAY CARE CENTERS THROUGHOUT THE NAVAJO NATION, TO PROVIDE SERVICES TO "SPECIAL NEED" CHILDREN FOR ENHANCING THEIR EDUCATIONAL ENDEAVORS. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS VOLUNTEERS HAVE MADE UNSELFISH AND VALUABLE CONTRIBUTION TO NAVAJO CHILDREN BY TEACHING THEM ABOUT CULTURE, TRADITION, ARTS/CRAFTS, WRITE/SPEAK IN THE NAVAJO LANGUAGE AND ASSIST THE SCHOOL TEACHERS WITH IMPLEMENTATION OF THE ASSIGNED CURRICULUM.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY:
THE PENINSULA FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (PFGP) HAS BEEN IN OPERATION SINCE 1972, SERVING THOUSANDS OF CHILDREN AND SENIOR CITIZENS IN A FIVE-CITY AREA. THE PRIMARY FOCUS FOR THE PROGRAM IS ENGAGING STUDENTS IN COMMUNITIES BY MENTORING AND ACADEMIC ASSISTANCE. THE MISSION OF THE PFGP IS TO ?SHARE TODAY, SHAPE TOMORROW, AND LEAVE A POSITIVE FOOTPRINT FOR THE FUTURE OF CHILDREN AND SENIOR CITIZENS THROUGHOUT THE PENINSULA?. 
FOR SCHOOL YEAR 2017-2018, CHILDREN IN CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTERS, HEAD START, PRE-K, KINDERGARTEN AND TITLE I ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS WILL BE SERVED BY ONE-HUNDRED FIVE (105) SENIOR CITIZEN VOLUNTEERS, COMPLETING A TOTAL OF EIGHTY-TWO (82) VOLUNTEER SERVICE YEARS (VSY) OR 85,608 VOLUNTEER HOURS. THE VALUE OF VOLUNTEER TIME, WHICH IS MADE AVAILABLE BY INDEPENDENT SECTOR AND UPDATED ANNUALLY, IS CURRENTLY AT A RATE OF $23.56 PER HOUR WHEN CONSIDERING THE POTENTIAL COST OF REPLACING A VOLUNTEER WITH PAID STAFF. USING THIS FORMULA TO CONVERT OUR 82 VSYS TO A DOLLAR AMOUNT, THE TOTAL DOLLAR VALUE OF OUR PFGP VOLUNTEERS IS $2,016,924. 
THE PFGP IS REQUESTING $345,222 FROM THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE TO SUPPORT THE VOLUNTEERS AND STAFF.  THE PROGRAM IS SUPPORTED BY DIRECT LOCAL FUNDS OF $69,770 FROM THE CITY OF HAMPTON (PENDING APPLICATION APPROVAL) AND $20,000 FROM THE CITY OF NEWPORT NEWS (RECOMMENDED BY CITY BUDGET OFFICE, AWAITING FINAL APPROVAL BY CITY COUNCIL) TOTALING $89,770. THE PROGRAM SERVES FIVE (5) LOCALITIES (HAMPTON, NEWPORT NEWS, YORK COUNTY, JAMES CITY COUNTY AND WILLIAMSBURG). THE REQUESTED BUDGET WILL SUPPORT VOLUNTEER STIPENDS, INSURANCE, VOLUNTEER RECOGNITION, ORIENTATION FOR NEW VOLUNTEERS, MONTHLY IN-SERVICE TRAINING FOR VOLUNTEERS, UNIFORMS, STAFF SALARIES AND CRIMINAL BACKGROUND CHECKS FOR THE PFPGP.
 THERE ARE 27 VOLUNTEER STATIONS THROUGHOUT THE 5 LOCALITIES. TWO (2) OF THE SITES ARE CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTERS, NINE (9) ARE HEAD START AND PRE-K CLASSES AND SIXTEEN (16) OF THE SITES ARE TITLE 1 ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS (K-12).  THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THE PROJECT IS EDUCATION INCLUDING EARLY LITERACY STRATEGIES AND SOCIAL/EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT. EACH VOLUNTEER IS ASSIGNED 5 CHILDREN TO TRACK FOR IMPROVEMENT BUT USUALLY SERVICE ALL THE CHILDREN IN EACH CLASSROOM. THE MINIMUM NUMBER OF CHILDREN REPRESENTED IN THE SUBSEQUENT NARRATIVES REFLECTS THESE 5 TEACHER IDENTIFIED STUDENTS, HOWEVER, WE KNOW THE IMPACT OF PFGP VOLUNTEERS WOULD BE MUCH HIGHER IF EACH CHILD WAS COUNTED. WITH AN AVERAGE OF 26 STUDENTS PER CLASSROOM, A MORE ACCURATE NUMBER OF STUDENTS IMPACTED BY PFGP VOLUNTEERS WOULD BE MORE IN THE AREA OF 2,730 STUDENTS THROUGHOUT THE FIVE LOCALITIES. HOWEVER, WE WILL TRACK THE PROGRESS OF THE IDENTIFIED 5 CHILDREN PER VOLUNTEER.  A MINIMUM OF 45 CHILDREN IN CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTERS WILL BE SERVED BY 9 VOLUNTEERS AND WILL DEMONSTRATE A GAIN IN SOCIAL/EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT; A MINIMUM OF 165 STUDENTS IN PRE-K AND HEAD START CLASSES WILL BE SERVED BY 33 VOLUNTEERS AND WILL SHOW GAINS IN SOCIAL/EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND EARLY LITERACY SKILLS; AND, A MINIMUM OF 315 CHILDREN IN ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS (GRADES K-3) WILL RECEIVE ASSISTANCE FROM 63 VOLUNTEERS IN LITERACY STRATEGIES AND INTERVENTION TO HELP ACHIEVE ACADEMIC SUCCESS IN READING AND OTHER CONTENT AREAS AS MEASURED BY STANDARDS OF LEARNING (SOL) SCORES. THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOME IS THAT 75% OF THE VOLUNTEER ASSISTED STUDENTS (34 STUDENTS FOR CHILD DEVELOPMENT CENTERS; 124 STUDENTS IN PRE-K AND HEAD START, AND 236 STUDENTS FOR ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS) WILL SHOW IMPROVEMENT IN THEIR SOCIAL/EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND LITERACY SKILLS. 
THE PFGP HAS PARTNERED WITH BOTH NEWPORT NEWS AND HAMPTON CITY SCHOOLS? SUMMER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS AND THE 21ST CENTURY SUMMER ENRICHMENT PROGRAM TO PROVIDE ACADEMIC ASSISTANCE TO STUDENTS WHO FAILED ONE OR MORE SUBJECTS DURING THE REGULAR SCHOOL YEAR. AT THE END OF THE SUMMER TERMS STUDENTS DEMONSTRATED SIGNIFICANT IMPROVEMENT, ACCORDING TO SCHOOL OFFICIALS.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
AN ESTIMATED 61 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE. SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE: SUPPORTING CHILDREN IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF SOCIALIZATION SKILLS, PROBLEM SOLVING SKILLS AND BUILDING SELF-ESTEEM. THROUGH ONE ON ONE MENTORING THE FGP WILL ENHANCE THE EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE AND ENCOURAGE PROGRESS IN SCHOOL READINESS  IN LITERACY SKILLS AND IMPROVE ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE IN READING AND MATH.
THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT IS SCHOOL READINESS FOR THE ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED YOUNG CHILDREN AND THE EDUCATIONAL AND BEHAVIORAL OUTCOMES OF ELEMENTARY, MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS WITH SPECIAL OR EXCEPTIONAL NEEDS.

FIRST TENNESSEE HUMAN RESOURCE AGENCY (FTHRA) IS A PUBLIC NON-PROFIT AGENCY CHARTERED BY THE STATE IN 1974 WITH THE MISSION TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR PEOPLE OF NORTHEAST TENNESSEE THROUGH EFFECTIVE DELIVERY OF SOCIAL SERVICES. FTHRA SERVES THE MOSTLY RURAL APPALACHIAN COUNTIES OF CARTER, GREENE, JOHNSON, HAWKINS, HANCOCK, SULLIVAN, UNICOI AND WASHINGTON PROVIDING A VARIETY OF NEEDS-BASED SERVICES TO LOW INCOME AND AT-RISK PEOPLE LIVING IN OUR SERVICE AREA. FTHRA HAS SUCCESSFULLY ADMINISTERED FGP IN GREENE COUNTY FOR OVER 12 YEARS AND GREENE COUNTY HAS MAINTAINED AN ACTIVE FGP FOR OVER 45 YEARS THROUGH VARIOUS SPONSORING AGENCIES.  FTHRA'S BOARD OF DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, AND FGP STAFF HAVE DETERMINED THAT THE BEST WAY TO UTILIZE FGP RESOURCES IS TO CONTINUE TO CONCENTRATE OUR EFFORTS IN GREENE COUNTY, HOWEVER WE INTEND TO EXPAND THE PROGRAM INTO AN ADDITIONAL DISTRESSED COMMUNITY (HANCOCK COUNTY) THIS YEAR. 
THE MISSION OF THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS TO ADVANCE VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES FOR SENIOR CITIZENS SO THAT THEY MAY SERVE SPECIAL-NEEDS YOUTH THROUGH COLLABORATIONS WITH WORK SITES IN OUR SERVICE AREA.  AN ESTIMATED 75-80 UNDUPLICATED FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE GREENE AND HANCOCK COUNTIES; ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ASSISTING IN CLASSROOMS, ASSISTING IN HEAD START PROGRAMS, CARING FOR INFANTS, TUTORING IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS.  THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION.  WE ANTICIPATE 325 CHILDREN/YOUTH WILL SHOW IMPROVED LITERACY AND MATH SKILLS. WE ALSO ANTICIPATE IMPROVED CLASSROOM ENGAGEMENT AND ATTENDANCE.  VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE AS POSITIVE ROLE MODELS, PROVIDING UNCONDITIONAL ACCEPTANCE, LOVE AND ATTENTION.  IN PRE-K CLASSES, VOLUNTEERS WILL FOCUS ON EARLY LITERACY, SOCIAL/EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT, SCHOOL READINESS; ENCOURAGING POSITIVE SOCIAL INTERACTION AND COMMUNICATION THROUGH READING, GAMES, AND TEACHING SELF-HELP SKILLS.  VOLUNTEERS IN K-8 GRADES WILL FOCUS ON LITERACY SKILLS; HELPING STUDENTS WITH READING, WORD RECOGNITION, AND PHONICS, AS WELL AS IMPROVEMENT IN ACADEMIC ENGAGEMENT AND PERFORMANCE IN LITERACY.  THE 23+ VOLUNTEER WORK SITES BENEFIT CONSIDERABLY FROM HAVING A FGP VOLUNTEER; IT IS COST-EFFECTIVE FOR THE WORK SITES TO UTILIZE VOLUNTEERS THROUGH FGP SINCE WE PROVIDE CRIMINAL BACKGROUND CHECKS (INCLUDING FINGER PRINTING CHECKS), ANNUAL PHYSICAL EXAMS, ORIENTATION/MONTHLY TRAINING, ETC.).  THE 2011 STATE OF THE CHILD IN TENNESSEE REPORT IDENTIFIES THE NEED FOR ONE-ON-ONE INTERACTION AS THE FOUNDATION FOR BRAIN STIMULATION.  GREENE COUNTY AND GREENEVILLE CITY SCHOOL SUPERINTENDENTS, SUPERVISORS AND DAY CARE CENTER DIRECTORS HAVE ECHOED THOSE FINDINGS; A VOLUNTEER PROVIDING ONE-ON-ONE ATTENTION IN EDUCATIONAL SETTINGS IS A MUCH NEEDED COMPONENT OF THE INDIVIDUALIZED INSTRUCTIONAL PLANS OF THE YOUNG CHILDREN. FOR THE CHILDREN WHO ARE FORTUNATE TO HAVE A FOSTER GRANDPARENT, THE NURTURING, SPECIAL TUTORING, GUIDANCE AND INDIVIDUAL ATTENTION CAN MAKE ALL THE DIFFERENCE IN POSITIVE GROWTH AND SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT.  THIS, IN TURN, IMPACTS THE CHILD'S FAMILY IN A BENEFICIAL WAY.  FOSTER GRANDPARENTS GIVE CHILDREN THAT MUCH-NEEDED ATTENTION THAT CAN CHANGE LIVES.  
BY USING TEACHER OBSERVATION FORMS AND LOGS, ASSIGNMENT PLANS AND ASSIGNMENT PLAN EVALUATIONS, SURVEYS, STAFF OBSERVATIONS, AS WELL AS REPORT CARDS, PRE-SCHOOL TESTING, MID-TERM TESTING, AND END-OF-YEAR EVALUATIONS, OUR PROGRAM WILL DETERMINE WHETHER YOUTH HAVE SHOWN INCREASED RESPONSIVENESS, IMPROVED DEVELOPMENT OF SKILLS AS DETERMINED BY THE TEACHERS SUCH AS LANGUAGE, LETTER, COLOR, NUMBER, AND NAME RECOGNITION, ETC.

AN ESTIMATED 72 FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE. SOME OF THEIR ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ASSISTING IN ELEMENTARY CLASSROOMS AND ASSISTING IN CLASSROOMS AT HEAD START. THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS PROJECT IS EDUCATION-SCHOOL READINESS. AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, AN ANTICIPATED 164 HEAD START AND EARLY ELEMENTARY CHILDREN WILL DEMONSTRATE GAINS IN SCHOOL READINESS IN TERMS OF SOCIAL AND/OR EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT.

CHARLESTON AREA SENIOR CITIZENS SERVICES, INC. (CASC) IS A 501(C)3 ORGANIZATION THAT SERVES SENIOR CITIZENS IN SOUTH CAROLINA, SPECIFICALLY BERKELEY, CHARLESTON, AND DORCHESTER COUNTIES. THE MISSION OF THE ORGANIZATION IS TO PROMOTE THE SOCIAL, MENTAL AND ECONOMIC WELL-BEING OF SENIORS IN THE TRI-COUNTY.  CASC IS REQUESTING $235,870 IN FEDERAL FUNDS TO SPONSOR THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM (FGP) IN THIS THREE COUNTY AREA.  THE FGP WILL PROVIDE 51 VSY'S DURING THE CONTRACT YEAR.  THE FGP WILL ADDRESS TWO PERFORMANCE MEASURES: SCHOOL READINESS/HEAD START/EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATION AND K-12 SUCCESS WITH A THIRD COMPLEMENTARY PROGRAM UNDER K-12 SUCCESS.
FORTY-OME FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL BE ASSIGNED TO 175 STUDENTS IN ELEMENTARY AND MIDDLE SCHOOLS TO ASSIST IN CLASSROOM PERFORMANCE AND TO IMPROVE READING SKILLS. THE END OUTCOME WILL BE THAT 90%, OR 158 OF CHILDREN RECEIVING ASSISTANCE WILL ADVANCE TO THE NEXT GRADE LEVEL.
TWENTY-FIVE FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL ASSIST 75 CHILDREN IN HEAD STARTS, EARLY HEAD STARTS AND A SCHOOL READINESS PROGRAM.  A TOTAL OF 20,000 VOLUNTEER HOURS WILL BE PROVIDED IN THE CONTRACT YEAR, 19 VSY'S.  VOLUNTEERS WILL HELP CHILDREN DEVELOP IN THE SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL DOMAIN AND TO BECOME KINDERGARTEN READY.  FGP VOLUNTEERS WILL ASSIST AT RISK CHILDREN IN DEVELOPING NECESSARY COMMUNICATION, SOCIALIZATION AND COGNITIVE SKILLS TO PROGRESS TO THE NEXT CLASS LEVEL.  THE END OUTCOME WILL BE THAT 90% OR 68 OF CHILDREN RECEIVING ASSISTANCE GRADUATE TO THE NEXT LEVEL APPROPRIATE TO THEIR AGE.
THE SUMMER LEARNING PROGRAM, A NON IMPACT AREA, WILL HAVE 20 VOLUNTEERS ASSISTING 60 CHILDREN WHO HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS "AT RISK".  VOLUNTEERS WILL PROVIDE TUTORING, ASSIST DURING STRUCTURED ACADEMIC TIME, ACCOMPANY ON FIELD TRIPS AND PROVIDE POSITIVE REINFORCEMENT TO REDIRECT UNACCEPTABLE BEHAVIOR.  VOLUNTEERS WILL PROVIDE 6,000 HOURS OF SERVICE, 6 VSY'S.

AN ESTIMATED 70 UNDUPLICATED FOSTER GRANDPARENT (FGP) VOLUNTEERS WILL SERVE, ALL IN OUTCOME ASSIGNMENTS. SERVICE ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ASSISTING IN CLASSROOMS AND TUTORING. SENIOR RESOURCES, INCORPORATED (SRI), THE LEGAL APPLICANT, IS A WELL-ESTABLISHED NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION, ESTABLISHED AND ACTIVE IN THE SC MIDLANDS COMMUNITY SINCE 1967.   FGP BEGAN IN COLUMBIA IN 1967 AND SINCE HAS BEEN SPONSORED BY SENIOR RESOURCES SINCE 1984. THE MISSION OF SENIOR RESOURCES IS TO PROVIDE COORDINATED SERVICES, RESOURCES AND PERSONAL CHOICES TO PROMOTE HEALTHY, INDEPENDENT LIVING THROUGH THE SUPPORT OF STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS.  THE AARP FOUNDATION  (JULY 2014) STATES THAT A PURPOSE IN LIFE CAN PREVENT ISOLATION AMONG SENIORS AND VOLUNTEERING IS A GREAT WAY TO MAKE A DIFFERENCE AND BRING MEANING BACK TO LIFE. FGP OF THE MIDLANDS IS ALSO UNIQUELY POSITIONED AND QUALIFIED DUE TO BEING HOUSED IN AN ORGANIZATION THAT OFFERS COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAMS AND SERVICES ALONG WITH ESTABLISHED RELATIONSHIPS WITH EXISTING AGING SERVICE PROVIDERS, STATE AND LOCAL OFFICES ON AGING, AND CURRENT VOLUNTEER STATIONS.

THE PRIMARY FOCUS AREA OF THIS SAVE THE CHILDREN PROJECT IS K-12 SUCCESS AND SCHOOL READINESS. OUR LITERACY INITIATIVE IS THE HALLMARK OF OUR LITERACY BLOCK, WHICH CONSISTS OF GUIDED INDEPENDENT READING PRACTICE (GIRP) AND EMERGENT READER LITERACY PROGRAM FOR 30 MINUTES OF UNINTERRUPTED TIME, FOUR DAYS A WEEK. THE SHORTFALL IN READING PROFICIENCY IS ESPECIALLY PRONOUNCED AMONG CHILDREN LIVING IN POVERTY, YOUTH IN LOW-INCOME COUNTIES, AND POOR COMMUNITIES, A QUALITY EDUCATION IS BEYOND REACH. OUR GOAL IS TO IMPROVE CHILDREN'S ABILITY TO READ FOR ACADEMIC, PERSONAL AND EVENTUALLY, CAREER PURPOSES. SAVE THE CHILDREN'S LITERACY PROGRAM PROVIDES CHILDREN IN KINDERGARTEN THROUGH SIXTH GRADE WITH OPPORTUNITY TO INCREASE THEIR READING ACHIEVEMENT BY SUPPLYING THE TOOLS THEY NEED TO DEVELOP READING SKILLS AND THE GUIDANCE AND SUPPORT THEY NEED TO GROW FAST. 
SAVE THE CHILDREN SEEKS TO ENGAGE 27 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS IN THE GIRP AND EMERGENT READER LITERACY PROGRAM TO SERVE 234 CHILDREN IN 8 PARTNER SCHOOLS IN KINDERGARTEN THROUGH SIXTH GRADE. VOLUNTEERS WILL EACH WORK WITH SIX CHILDREN DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR ON READING READINESS SKILLS FOR APPROXIMATELY 30 MINUTES OF UNINTERRUPTED TIME, FOUR DAYS A WEEK DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR. THE STUDENTS TARGETED THE INTERVENTION STRUGGLE IN SCHOOL LARGE PART BECAUSE THEY DON'T HAVE THE FAMILIARITY WITH BOOKS AND LANGUAGE THAT ARE THE BUILDING BLOCKS FOR LITERACY. THESE ACTIVITIES HELP RELUCTANT LEARNERS TO ACCESS BOOKS AND LANGUAGE IN A NON-THREATENING MANNER.
TWENTY (75%) FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL ASSIST INDIVIDUAL CHILDREN IN GIRP BY HELPING THEM CHOOSE BOOKS ACROSS THEIR READING RANGE AND EXPLORE EACH CHILD'S INDIVIDUAL INTERESTS. VOLUNTEERS WILL LISTEN TO THE CHILD READ, PROVIDE OCCASIONAL SUPPORT WITH WORDS OR VOCABULARY AND ASK HIGHER-LEVEL THINKING QUESTIONS. THE QUESTIONS QUICKLY DETERMINE IF THE STUDENT UNDERSTANDS AND PROVIDE SUPPORT TO ENSURE THAT CHILDREN MAINTAIN A MONTHLY AVERAGE OF 90% ON ACCELERATED READER QUIZZES. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL HELP PARTICIPATING STUDENTS TO DEVELOP READING STRATEGIES BY PREVIEWING MATERIAL READ, FOCUSING ATTENTION ON PICTURES IN STORIES, AND ASSISTING WITH THE SUMMARIZING BOOKS TO INCREASE THEIR SKILLS TO BECOME SUCCESSFUL INDEPENDENT READERS. INDEPENDENT READING ALSO LEADS TO INCREASED VOCABULARY DEVELOPMENT AND ACHIEVEMENT IN READING.
THREE (10%) FOSTER GRANDPARENTS PLACED IN THE EMERGENT READER MODULE (GRADES K AND 1ST) WILL ASSIST WITH SIGHT WORDS, LETTER RECOGNITION, AND SHARED GUIDED READING ACTIVITIES. VOLUNTEERS TUTORING CHILDREN IN SIGHT WORDS WILL USE FLASH CARDS, SIGHT WORD BINGO, PHRASE CARDS, AND WORD BASEBALL T HELP BEGINNING READERS READ AT LEAST 100 SIGHT WORDS CONSISTENTLY. VOLUNTEERS WORKING WITH CHILDREN USING LETTER RECOGNITION MODULES WILL ENGAGE IN THE ALPHABET SONG IDENTIFYING LETTERS UTILIZING CHARTS, AND OTHER RECOGNITION ACTIVITIES REQUIRING IDENTIFICATION OF UPPER/LOWER CASE LETTERS. IN SHARED GUIDED READING, THE VOLUNTEERS WILL READ BOOKS ALOUD TO THE CHILDREN ALLOWING THEM TO LOOKS AT THE POINT AND FOLLOW ALONG OVER THE COURSE OF SEVERAL DAYS. BOTH THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT AND THE CHILDREN WILL READ AND REREAD THE SAME TEXT TOGETHER TO HELP DEVELOP EMERGENT READING SKILLS FOR BEGINNING READERS.
AT THE END OF THE THREE-YEAR GRANT, SAVE THE CHILDREN WILL HAVE 27 FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERING IN 8 PARTNER SCHOOLS IN BARNWELL COUNTY DISTRICT 19, BARNWELL COUNTY DISTRICT 29, BARNWELL COUNTY DISTRICT 45, CLARENDON COUNTY DISTRICT 2, FLORENCE DISTRICT 7, LEE COUNTY DISTRICT 8 AND ORANGEBURG COUNTY DISTRICT 5. AT THE END OF THE FISCAL YEAR, SAVE THE CHILDREN FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR REINFORCING EMERGENT LITERACY SKILLS AND IMPROVE THE ABILITY OF 168 (85%) CHILDREN TO READ. 75% OF CHILDREN BEING ASSISTED VIA FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM WILL BE MONITORED TO ENSURE THEY SHOWED SIGNIFICANT READING GROWTH BEYOND THE EQUIVALENT OF ONE SCHOOL YEAR. GREENE LAMP COMMUNITY ACTION, A 501 (C)3 NONPROFIT, INCORPORATED IN 1965 IS RESPECTFULLY SUBMITTING APPLICATION FOR THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS PROGRAM TO SERVE GREENE AND LENOIR COUNTIES.  THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM, WHICH BEGAN IN LENOIR AND GREENE COUNTIES IN 1972, PROVIDES LOVING AND EXPERIENCED TUTORS AND MENTORS TO CHILDREN AND YOUTH WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES.  OUR FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL PROVIDE ONE-ON-ONE INTERACTION AND SERVE BETWEEN 20 AND 40 HOURS A WEEK TO OFFER EFFECTIVE SERVICES TO OUR VOLUNTEERS, VOLUNTEER STATIONS, AND THE INDIVIDUALS AND CHILDREN BEING SERVED.  FROM THE INITIAL DATE TO THE PRESENT TIME, APPROXIMATELY FIVE HUNDRED VOLUNTEERS HAVE SERVED IN GREENE AND LENOIR COUNTIES TOTALING OVER 3 MILLION HOURS.  
THIS FISCAL YEAR GREENE LAMP IS REQUESTING 53 VOLUNTEERS AND THE AMOUNT OF $246,679. THE SERVICE CATEGORIES OUR PROJECT WILL ADDRESS ARE SERVING PEOPLE WITH INTELLECTUAL AND DEVELOPMENTAL DISABILITIES, HUMAN NEEDS, JUVENILE JUSTICE, HEAD START, LITERACY AND MENTORING.
OUR FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS WILL PROVIDE MUCH NEEDED SUPPORT AT FIVE VOLUNTEER STATIONS, INCLUDING CASWELL DEVELOPMENTAL CENTER, GREENE LAMP HEAD START/ EARLY HEAD START, DOBBS YOUTH DEVELOPMENT CENTER, NC PRE-KINDERGARTEN, AND KENNEDY HOME, AN NC BAPTIST CHILDREN'S HOME. AT CASWELL DEVELOPMENTAL CENTER, THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL PROVIDE SOCIAL OPPORTUNITIES AND DEVELOP STRONG PERSONAL RELATIONSHIPS WITH THE INDIVIDUALS WHO MAKE THE CENTER THEIR HOME, THEY WILL ASSIST CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL NEEDS AND INDIVIDUAL EDUCATION PLANS (IEP) AT HEAD START CENTERS, AND AT NC PRE-KINDERGARTEN CENTERS IN THE COMMUNITY, AND WILL PROVIDE MENTORING AND SUPPORT TO ADJUDICATED YOUTH AT DOBBS YOUTH DEVELOPMENT CENTER. AT KENNEDY HOME, GRANDPARENTS WILL ASSIST WITH SCHOOLWORK, AND INTERACT AND CARE FOR INDIVIDUALS FROM ABUSED, AND NEGLECTED BACKGROUNDS.   EACH INDIVIDUAL WILL HAVE A WORK ASSIGNMENT PLAN AND WE WILL ENCOURAGE THE FOSTER GRANDPARENTS TO STRIVE TO GET THE MOST OUT OF THEIR TIME WITH THEIR INDIVIDUALS AND POSITIVE RESULTS AT THE END OF EACH GRANT YEAR.  STUDIES SHOW THAT VOLUNTEERING HELPS YOU LIVE LONGER AND WILL PROMOTE A MORE POSITIVE OUTLOOK ON LIFE.

BLUE RIDGE COMMUNITY ACTION, INC (BRCA) IS A PRIVATE, NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION ESTABLISHED IN 1965 TO ADDRESS AND RESPOND TO THE CONCERNS AND NEEDS OF LOW -INCOME FAMILIES AND INDIVIDUALS WITHIN THE COMMUNITIES THEY SERVE.  COMMUNITY ACTION AGENCIES (CAAS) ARE NON-PROFIT PRIVATE AND PUBLIC ORGANIZATIONS ORIGINALLY ESTABLISHED UNDER THE ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY ACT OF 1964 TO FIGHT AMERICA?S WAR ON POVERTY.  TODAY THERE ARE NEARLY 1,000 CAA?S ACROSS THE UNITED STATES.  WITH THE UNDERSTANDING THAT PROBLEMS OFTEN DON'T COME ALONE AND THEREFORE AREN?T SOLVED ALONE, BRCA WORKS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE COMMUNITY TO IDENTIFY CONCERNS AND SOLVE PROBLEMS.  THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT (FG) GRANT APPLICATION REQUESTS 57 VOLUNTEERS TO SERVE 5 COUNTIES IN WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA: ALEXANDER, BURKE, CALDWELL, CATAWBA AND MCDOWELL COUNTIES.  TOTAL ANNUAL FUNDING ANTICIPATED IS $68,728 THAT INCLUDES $240,606 FEDERAL AND $28,122 GRANTEE AND COMMUNITY DONATIONS.  FOUR SERVICE CATEGORIES ARE ADDRESSED: HEAD START, PRE-ELEMENTARY DAY CARE, ELEMENTARY EDUCATION AND INTELLECTUAL DISABILITIES.  COMMUNITY NEEDS INCLUDE SUPPORTING EARLY INTERVENTION IN LOCAL HEAD STAT AND DAY CARE PROGRAMS TO INCREASE CHILDREN'S SUCCESS IN KINDERGARTEN. HEAD START AND PRE-SCHOOL CHILDREN IDENTIFIED THROUGH DEVELOPMENTAL ASSESSMENT PLANS, RECEIVE GREATER KINDERGARTEN SUCCESS.  IN SCHOOL, FG VOLUNTEERS WILL MENTOR SPECIAL NEEDS CHILDREN, IDENTIFIED BY THEIR TEACHERS, IN ACTIVITIES TO STRENGTHEN LITERACY, ACADEMIC CONFIDENCE AND INCREASE EOG READING SCORES WITH THE FINAL OUTCOME OF PASSING TO THE NEXT GRADE LEVEL OR ACHIEVING IEP GOALS.  THE INTELLECTUALLY DISABLED SERVICE AREA WILL ASSIST RIDDLE CENTER RESIDENTS THROUGH INCREASING SOCIAL ACTIVITIES, CLASS SITE ACHIEVEMENTS AND CONFIDENCE AND SAFETY FOR RIDDLE CENTER RESIDENTS WITH OUTCOMES TO ENRICH THEIR QUALITY OF LIFE AND REFLECT PROGRESS IN THEIR PERSONAL CARE PLAN GOALS.

THE APPALACHIAN FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM IS REQUESTING $375,396 FROM THE CORPORATION FOR NATIONAL AND COMMUNITY SERVICE FOR THE GRANT CYCLE OF 2017-2018 AND WILL MAINTAIN 79 VSY'S, CONTRIBUTING $58,859 FROM IN-KIND AND OTHER NON-FEDERAL SOURCES. OUR MISSION IS TO PROVIDE MEANINGFUL VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES FOR SENIOR CITIZENS THAT WILL ENHANCE THEIR LIVES AND AT THE SAME TIME ENHANCE AND IMPROVE THE LIVES OF THE SPECIAL NEEDS CHILDREN THEY SERVE. OUR GOALS ARE TUTORING AND CHILD LITERACY. THERE IS A GREAT NEED FOR FOSTER GRANDPARENTS TO CONTINUE SERVING CHILDREN IN KINDERGARTEN THROUGH SEVENTH GRADE IN THE PUBLIC SCHOOLS IN ALLEGHANY, ASHE, AVERY, WATAUGA AND WILKES COUNTIES AND OUR LOCAL SCHOOL OFFICIALS HAVE IDENTIFIED THE NEED FOR ONE-ON-ONE ASSISTANCE FOR CHILDREN WHO ARE STRUGGLING TO REACH THEIR REQUIRED READING LEVEL. FOSTER GRANDPARENTS HAVE BEEN REQUESTED BY PRINCIPALS IN ALLEGHANY, ASHE, AVERY, WILKES AND WATAUGA COUNTIES. OUR ANTICIPATED OUTCOME IS THAT 200 CHILDREN WHO ARE TUTORED BY A FOSTER GRANDPARENT WILL IMPROVE THEIR READING SKILLS BY THE END OF THE SCHOOL YEAR. TWO HUNDRED STUDENTS TUTORED BY THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS AND COMPLETING A CNCS-SUPPORTED EDUCATION PROGRAM WILL RESULT IN AN OUTCOME OF 100 STUDENTS WITH IMPROVED ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE IN LITERACY BY THE END OF THE SCHOOL YEAR. THIS OUTCOME WILL BE MEASURED USING ASSESSMENT FORMS ADMINISTERED AT THE BEGINNING OF THE YEAR,  MID-YEAR, AND END OF THE YEAR.  THESE ASSESSMENTS WILL BE COMPLETED BY CLASSROOM TEACHERS. 
	IN 2016, HEAD START OF THE BLUE RIDGE OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION, AVERY AND YADKIN COUNTIES SERVED 175 LOW-INCOME AND AT-RISK INFANTS AND TODDLERS, PRE-SCHOOL CHILDREN, AND THEIR FAMILIES. FEDERAL PERFORMANCE STANDARDS REQUIRE ALL HEAD START PROGRAMS TO COMPLETE DEVELOPMENTAL SCREENINGS IN ORDER TO IDENTIFY CHILDREN WHO MAY BE IN NEED OF DISABILITY SERVICES. THE  APPROVED DEVELOPMENTAL SCREENING TOOLS INCLUDE: AGES AND STAGES, FIRST STEPS, BRIGANCE, AND LAP D. THESE TOOLS ADDRESS THE PRIMARY DOMAIN AREAS RELATING TO COGNITIVE ABILITY, LANGUAGE AND COMMUNICATION SKILLS, SOCIAL AND EMOTIONAL DEVELOPMENT, AND FINE AND GROSS MOTOR SKILLS. BLUE RIDGE OPPORTUNITY COMMISSION HEAD START STAFF WILL IDENTIFY CHILDREN NEEDING EXTRA ASSISTANCE WITH SPECIFIC DELAYS AND/OR DISABILITIES. IT IS LIKELY THAT WITHOUT INTERVENTION THE IDENTIFIED CHILDREN WILL NOT ACQUIRE THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO BE SUCCESSFUL IN SCHOOL. THE RESOURCES AND FUNDING FOR EXTENSIVE ONE-ON-ONE INTERVENTION ARE NOT CURRENTLY AVAILABLE TO THE HEAD START PROGRAM; APPALACHIAN FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL PROVIDE SOME OF THE MUCH NEEDED SUPPORT TO THE HEAD START CENTERS IN ASHE, AVERY, ALLEGHANY, AND WILKES COUNTIES. UNDER SUPERVISION OF CLASSROOM TEACHERS, FOSTER GRANDPARENTS WILL PROVIDE ASSISTANCE TO 30 HEAD START CHILDREN. OUR ANTICIPATED OUTCOME IS THAT 30 CHILDREN  WILL RECEIVE ON-ONE-ONE ASSISTANCE FROM THE FOSTER GRANDPARENT VOLUNTEERS AND THAT  20 OF THOSE CHILDREN WILL COMPLETE  THE CNCS SUPPORTED HEAD START EDUCATION PROGRAM AND WILL SHOW A 25% IMPROVEMENT IN TWO OUT OF THREE IDENTIFIED PRIORITY AREAS AND THEY WILL BE PROMOTED TO THE NEXT LEVEL. 
AN ASSIGNMENT PLAN INSTRUMENT WILL BE COMPLETED BY THE HEAD START STAFF AND RETURNED TO THE APPALACHIAN FOSTER GRANDPARENT PROGRAM OFFICE. ACCORDING TO SCHOOL RECORDS, 3,318 SPECIAL EDUCATION STUDENTS ARE IN THE SCHOOLS AND 168 CHILDREN ARE IN DEVELOPMENTAL DAY CARE FACILITIES IN ASHE, ALLEGHANY, AVERY, WATAUGA AND WILKES COUNTIES (NORTH CAROLINA PUBLIC SCHOOLS EXCEPTIONAL CHILDREN DIVISION CHILD COUNT REPORT, APRIL 2016).
